AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.33 am): Our government has been working very closely with the Prime Minister, the federal health minister and representatives of the federal government to ensure that the proposed Commonwealth health reform package delivers real benefits for Queenslanders. At the last COAG meeting held here in Brisbane in December last year, Queensland highlighted the following areas that must be addressed to achieve a better health system. We outlined the need for more funding for hospitals to match growing demand, the need to fix aged care to take the pressure off our hospitals, tackling the disconnect between GPs, hospitals and community health, the need to tackle workforce shortages and the need to have a much greater focus on disease prevention.

For the first time, the Prime Minister has recognised that the federal government needs to do more and not less in meeting the costs of providing hospital services around Australia. States have carried this burden for too long with much lower revenue raising capacities than the Commonwealth.

Queensland therefore welcomes the Commonwealth becoming the dominant funder of our hospital systems. While we as a state will have to give up some GST revenue for this to occur, it will help secure a more sustainable financial future for the health system as a whole and for all of us as taxpayers. Why? Simply because the Commonwealth has accepted responsibility as a 60 per cent funding partner in the hospital system for funding growth. I also said that I would not be signing up unless there was extra money to meet the growing demand for hospital services.
Mr Horan: It’s just taking it out of the GST. What’s the difference?

Ms BLIGH: The Commonwealth’s recent announcements regarding additional investments in elective surgery and emergency departments will also assist in treating more patients and reducing waiting times in Queensland public hospitals. I also expressed a number of concerns to the Prime Minister and through officials that the proposed model for activity based funding could seriously disadvantage small, rural and regional hospitals throughout Queensland. I have demanded that any agreement will have to include specific protections for such hospitals and the Commonwealth has agreed that those hospitals can and will be block funded.
Mr Horan: And big hospitals, difficult cases will get shoved over to them.

Ms BLIGH: I note the interjections from the former health minister under the Liberal National Party whose contribution to health was to introduce a tax on hospitals. I also called on the Prime Minister to take pressure off our public hospitals by addressing the Commonwealth’s own areas of responsibility: aged care, primary care and health workforce shortages. I am pleased that the Prime Minister’s recently announced additional funding initiatives recognise the need to do more in these areas. States can only get on with the business of running public hospitals if the Commonwealth makes sure that its own parts of the surrounding health systems are functioning effectively.

On any given night there are around 340 aged-care patients occupying expensive acute public hospital beds due to the lack of available alternatives. Under the Commonwealth’s reform package, Queensland’s hospitals will get about an extra 400 flexible aged-care places to help offset the costs of elderly patients in public hospitals. Around $56 million will be available to Queensland to especially deal with these patients.

We know that our health system can do better in terms of coordinating care for people who are frequent users of the system. Queensland welcomes the Commonwealth’s new primary health care organisations and the $436 million investment in coordinated care for people living with diabetes. These new organisations will need to work closely with the new local health networks to improve the integration of hospital and community based services for patients, particularly the chronically ill and the elderly.

One of the great difficulties experienced across a regionalised state like Queensland for many years has been the insufficient number of GPs in rural, remote and regional Queensland. This is an issue that I and the health minister, the Deputy Premier, have repeatedly pushed with the Commonwealth. The increase in the number of GP training places, including a doubling of the number of GP training places in rural and remote communities, by 2014 is welcome. It will assist in improving access to services in Queensland communities that are currently missing out.

Without doubt stopping people from becoming ill in the first place is key to relieving pressure on our health system and improving health outcomes. This has been recognised by the Commonwealth with the new primary health care organisations also delivering health promotion and preventative health programs.

Australians and Queenslanders want reform of the hospital system. They want to see a better deal between the levels of government and, in my view, they want to see levels of government working together in their interest. Queensland will be heading off to COAG on Sunday and at the meeting on Monday looking for a good deal for Queensland, a better deal, and a deal that is right for our state.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.38 am): The first two people’s question time sessions of this year on the future of education and the challenges and opportunities of growth have been a success. Thousands of Queenslanders have taken up the opportunity to take part in people’s question time, watching live online or submitting their questions and ideas for discussion. So successful has this new initiative been that it seems that even the UK Prime Minister, Gordon Brown, is following in Queensland’s footsteps, holding his first people’s Prime Minister’s question time session just last week. I do not know about our UK counterparts, but Queenslanders certainly have not been backwards in coming forwards so far, with tough questions and thought-provoking suggestions about the topics that we have covered.

I am pleased to announce today that Queenslanders will have their next opportunity to be involved in people’s question time on 27 May. Instead of having a specific theme, this session will be a general session open to questions about anything and everything that Queenslanders want to ask about. I look forward to discussions on any topic, whether it is job creation, law and order, assets sales, our health system, daylight saving and everything else in between. As always, I do not see any of the questions before the session and those that get asked on the day will be chosen by our independent moderator. Questions can be submitted online. Just go to the Queensland government website and click the people’s question time link. I hope Queenslanders take this opportunity to again raise their concerns with their government.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.40 am): On a more cultural note, it is with pleasure that I inform the House that later this year Queensland will welcome to Brisbane one of the world’s most acclaimed performance companies, the Ballet Nacional de Cuba, which will perform in Brisbane from 24 September to 3 October. The Queensland Performing Arts Centre will be the only venue in Australia to host this magnificent company--another in a string of significant cultural coups for Queensland. This extraordinary company will present its production of Don Quixote, one of the most famous ballets in the world.

The Ballet Nacional de Cuba was created in 1948 and has toured in more than 58 countries, drawing on its vast repertoire of both the classics and modern ballets. This exclusive presentation follows in the footsteps of last year’s exclusive to Brisbane season for the Paris Opera Ballet and is again part of the ongoing collaboration between QPAC and Queensland Events. The Ballet Nacional de Cuba will feature in the Brisbane Festival and coincide with another international blockbuster also taking place at the cultural centre, and that is ‘Valentino, Retrospective: Past/Present/Future’, which will be presented at GoMA from 7 August to 14 November. It will be a cultural smorgasbord in that part of the year.
Mr Reeves interjected.
Ms BLIGH: As the Minister for Sport has just interjected, there will also be that other great cultural event--football finals. So people will have more than enough to satisfy every taste.

I am also pleased to inform the House that QPAC will offer specially discounted tickets to dance schools and school groups to ensure that young people have access to this very rare opportunity. Last year’s sell-out season of the Paris Opera Ballet attracted 25,000 people, 5,000 of whom travelled from other parts of Australia to be part of it.

These major productions mark a new era for QPAC, with last year’s $34 million refurbishment funded by our government. The Ballet Nacional de Cuba presentation is also a great coup for QPAC when it is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. This is an exclusive opportunity for Brisbane. These performances by the Ballet Nacional de Cuba will further cement Queensland’s profile as a cultural destination of growing international renown.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.43 am): I rise to update the House again on the ongoing efforts to resolve the Queensland Health payroll system difficulties and determine what went wrong. As I set out in parliament yesterday, there is a range of steps in place to provide support to staff who are facing hardship from the payroll transition. From payroll 1, 1,800 people have been identified as receiving no or little pay. All 1,800, I am advised, have been subsequently processed. From payroll 2, as at 5 pm yesterday I am advised that 879 staff have been identified as experiencing hardship and all 879 are being case managed. Yesterday an additional 134 staff were identified as experiencing hardship, and all 134 are being individually case managed and offered support to meet their particular circumstances. These numbers do not include the numbers of other workers with required variations to their pay.

To fix this problem we need to be clear about what went wrong and why. As I advised the House yesterday, it has long been a matter of public record that the development of Queensland Health’s new payroll system faced significant technical hurdles that delayed the project prior to ‘go live’ sign-off. The project was delivered by a project board, including a representative of IBM, which was responsible for tailoring the software, the chief information officer of Queensland Health and CorpTech. I described in the House yesterday the numerous delays the project faced before delivery. Each one of these delays represents a decision by the expert members of the project board that the system was not ready for use and further work needed to be done on it.

In July, September and November 2008 and in May, June and October 2009, the board determined that the project was not yet ready for go live and more work needed to be done. This is a matter of public record. I table a copy of a document that has been referred to in the media today which was drafted as a brief to me in June last year describing problems in the system as at that time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Briefing note, dated 6 July 2009, titled ‘Interim Payroll Replacement--QHIC’.
XML.Hansard-Body: The document is apparent on its face that it was not signed and approved by the relevant executive director or the deputy director-general or the director-general. Nor, am I advised, was it sent to my office at that time. But the fact that the payroll system development had very significant issues at the time was well known. I stated as much in the House yesterday. The fact is that when the document was drafted in June 2009 the payroll system was still in development. That is why the project board decided not to go live at that time or indeed for another nine months. The Courier-Mail this morning on its front page included a tear-off of the top of the brief. If it had added the very next part of the brief--that is, the act of recommendation--it would have clearly shown the words--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That you note issues in relation to the IBM contract with CorpTech and that both CorpTech and Queensland Health are working to obtain a solution to the issues.
XML.Hansard-Body: As a result of the issues identified in that document, the system ‘go live’ was delayed in June 2009 and again in October 2009. In late 2009 my office was advised--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The ... Project Board met on 19 October 2009, to assess the progress of User Acceptance Testing. The Board agreed that the criteria defined to allow for exit from UAT had not been met.
The Board has extended UAT so that the criteria can be met. The consequence of this decision is that a system Go Live is not possible in 2009.
XML.Hansard-Body: It also noted the significant issues with the current payroll and rostering systems Lattice and ESP. It was returned by my adviser for further action. I table a copy of that brief.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Briefing note, dated 17 November 2009, titled ‘Status of Interim Payroll Replacement--QHIC’.
XML.Hansard-Body: So there were issues. A decision was made not to proceed with go live until they were fixed and a commitment was given to fix them. In February of this year, some eight months after the issues were raised in the June document and one more month before go live, the same officer--the same officer--signed off a briefing note to project board managers stating that all outstanding issues were ‘manageable risk’ and can be completed on time for go live. I table of a copy of that.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Brief for decision, Queensland Health QHIC project board meeting on 1 February 2010, titled ‘Recommendation to commence with cutover activities’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ultimately, on 14 March 2010, the project board--made up of the four most senior IT officers involved in the project--certified that the project was ready to go live. The board includes a senior representative of IBM, the chief information officer of Queensland Health, the general manager of CorpTech and Queensland Health’s executive director of corporate services. I again table the ‘go live’ decision note from the project board.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Brief for decision, Queensland Health QHIC project board meeting on 14 March 2010, titled ‘Business to go-live for the QHIC Lattice Payroll Replacement Project’.
XML.Hansard-Body: KPMG has been engaged to review what went wrong. I want very clear answers about how this happened. It is simply not good enough. As I have stated very clearly, Queensland Health staff and indeed the taxpayer are entitled to rely on IT and payroll executives who are well paid to get their job done properly. When senior people certify that the payroll system is approved for go live, we are all entitled to expect that to be an accurate assessment. But my immediate priority is to get the problems rectified and get our hardworking staff their money. Our staff did nothing wrong. We need to fix this.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.48 am): I join the Premier in recognising the benefits for Queensland of the Prime Minister’s proposed health reforms. In the short term, over the current forward estimates period from 2010-11 to 2013-14, the Commonwealth government has recently announced a range of initiatives to support the establishment of a new way of funding health into the future. The announced Commonwealth investment across critical areas of hospital services, GP and primary care, workforce training and aged care, like any investment in health, is welcomed by this government. I note that no-one in this debate is arguing for less funding for the health system.

Of the almost $3 billion earmarked nationally over the next four years, approximately $600 million will be to the benefit of health services in Queensland. That is around $150 million per annum against a health bottom line that already stands at $9 billion. In reality every bit helps. Voters and patients do not want a debate about funding splits. They want to see a health system that has the capacity to meet current and future demand.

Critical to the Prime Minister’s health reform plan is a longer term commitment for the Commonwealth government to become the major funder of hospital and primary healthcare services. Forget about the here and now of the debate--the colour and light and the posturing--what this debate should be about is the longer term future of health funding.

The Bligh government is unashamedly pro reform. We know that the proportion of the population aged over 80 years will quadruple in the next 35 years, that the proportion aged over 65 will double and that the proportion of those supporting this population will halve. We also know that health costs are accelerating, year on year, at around 10 to 11 per cent, while the GST grows at around six per cent. Our health budget has accelerated from $4.6 billion in 2003-04 to $9 billion this year. The reality is that, at this rate of growth, the future demands of the health system bring into question the financing capacities of the states under current state-federal financial relations.

Eighty per cent of tax revenue in this nation is collected by the Commonwealth. That is the starting point for why reform that sees it become the dominant funder is, without question, the only course of action open to those who are truly acting in the long-term interests of the nation and the people who rely on our public health system. My counterparts in other states who missed this point also missed the point about the future needs of our nation’s health system. The federal government has estimated the additional funding contribution that it would make to Queensland over the six years from 2014 under the new system at around $3.4 billion. That is a fair way off, but this is also about the challenge that our ageing population presents us. Our demographic destiny is clear, and we need to act now. While this represents a model, there is no doubt that there will be real benefits in the long term from utilising the GST revenue for a Commonwealth funding commitment to meet 60 per cent of hospital funding and 100 per cent of primary healthcare services.

This weekend is a test for our federation. At stake is the future of our health system and the capacity of our federation to confront national issues. We stand ready to do the deal with the Prime Minister at the weekend’s COAG meeting--in the pursuit of real reform that will benefit Queenslanders and the Queensland health system for generations to come.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (9.52 am): So far this year cyclones, storms and flooding have caused more than $500 million in damage to communities across the state, and this figure will continue to rise. With the changing weather patterns, it is likely natural disaster events in Queensland will be more regular and more severe in coming years. That is why the Bligh government has partnered with the Rudd government to provide $44 million in funding over four years through the Natural Disaster Resilience Program to help minimise the impact of natural disasters in Queensland communities.

While this government continues to boost community resilience against natural disasters, the National Party continues to undermine public confidence in our disaster response system. Last week, the member for Mirani circulated a media release making ridiculous claims about the government’s response to the flooding situation in Burketown and surrounding communities. What he was actually criticising was the commendable efforts of the Local Disaster Management Group under the leadership of the acting mayor with support from Emergency Management Queensland. While the member for Mirani typed up his whingeing media release, Emergency Services staff and volunteers, local council staff and members of the Burke Local Disaster Management Group were proactively responding to their community’s needs. I was also receiving regular advice from local member Betty Kiernan, my new Parliamentary Secretary for Emergency Services, along with the acting mayor and Emergency Management Queensland. Activities on the ground included resupply of food and essentials, helicopter rescues and evacuations, and forward planning for the recovery phase.

Communities in the region are still affected by flood waters, and I commend the Local Disaster Management Group and EMQ for the support they have provided. This is just another example of how the government is getting on with the job while the National Party continues to whinge and whine. I just note that, under the National Party’s promised three per cent cut to departmental expenditure, initiatives such as the Natural Disaster Resilience Program would have been under severe threat.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr ROBERTS: A three per cent cut to departments, 12,000 jobs lost a year. That is what you promised.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I think both sides have contributed to the noise so I will wait for order.

Mr ROBERTS: Today I will be announcing the successful applicants for the program’s first round of funding. The Department of Community Safety received 58 applications for this round valued at more than $14 million. Applications were assessed by a group including representatives of the Local Government Association, Emergency Management Queensland and Queensland Fire and Rescue Service. Thirty-seven projects valued at $7.1 million were recommended and I have approved that funding. Some of the funded programs include: a community disaster preparedness and education program in the Fraser Coast area; a flood plain management strategy for the Fitzroy River in Rockhampton; an evacuation plan for Gold Coast city and the Cairns region; a local area natural disaster risk assessment in Toowoomba; a flood mitigation program for the southern section of the Cairns CBD; an early warning system for Mount Glorious; and a coastal erosion investigation and mitigation in the Whitsundays.

Projects funded in this round and subsequent rounds will ensure communities across the state are better placed to respond to, and recover from, future natural disasters. The Natural Disaster Resilience Program is just another demonstration of the government’s commitment to emergency services and community resilience.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (9.55 am): Today I have been granted leave from parliament to represent the Premier at the Central Queensland Leading the Way Regional Summit in Dysart. The Central Queensland regional summit will include representatives from local, state and federal governments, industry and business. I will be very interested to hear what they have to say about growth in regional Queensland.

At the recently held Queensland Growth Management Summit, attendees gave a strong message--that we need greater regionalisation for Queensland. At the Queensland Growth Management Summit, the Premier committed to developing a Queensland Regionalisation Strategy for consultation by the end of the year. The discussion at today’s Central Queensland regional summit will feed into the policy development of that consultation paper. The strategy is aimed at managing regional growth for the benefit of the regions.

The message was clear from the Queensland growth summit: more people will be attracted to live in regional Queensland if the infrastructure is in place to support them. This means not only jobs but also housing, schools, health care, transport and lifestyle requirements need to be met. Central Queensland contains some of the most valuable mineral resources on earth, with vast reserves of coal and coal seam methane gas. Over the last 50 years, the Bowen Basin has become the world’s largest exporter of seaborne coal. At the same time, we are witnessing the creation of the new liquefied natural gas industry, with an estimated $40 billion to be invested in the next decade, creating 18,000 jobs. Our challenge is to ensure that this extraordinary economic and population growth over coming years leads to attractive lifestyles and secure communities.

The recent Queensland growth summit was a great platform to discuss the issues of economic and population growth and how it can be managed to be liveable and sustainable. The Central Queensland regional summit aims to follow on from this success and give a voice to those in the regions to discuss how they see the future management of population and economic growth working in their area.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (9.57 am): Today I am releasing the Queensland Treasury Corporation’s report into 25 council submissions regarding the cost of their local government amalgamations. Twenty-four of the 25 councils are included in the report, with the Torres Strait Island Regional Council subject to continuing review. The report will be available online this afternoon and on the department’s website. This is the summary report prepared by QTC. Each of the 25 councils will also receive individual reports prepared by QTC responding to their submissions and detailing the costs and the benefits of amalgamation and each council’s liquidity and financial sustainability position.

At the time of amalgamation, it was signalled by the Local Government Reform Commission that North Burnett and South Burnett regional councils had financial sustainability issues. Further review by the QTC has confirmed the need for assistance for these two councils. The report identified that North Burnett and South Burnett regional council forecasts indicate ‘that sustainability remains a significant issue for these local governments’. The QTC report identified a further three local governments that, while having access to adequate liquidity, also have weak forecast operating positions. I quote from the report--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: However, the reviewed cost of amalgamation, while contributing to the operating deficit, is not the prime reason for the deficits. These deficits are predominantly structural in nature as the cost of ongoing service provision exceeds the revenues available to the local governments through rates and utilities income, fees and charges etc.
XML.Hansard-Body: These three councils are Southern Downs, Toowoomba and Whitsunday regional councils. Southern Downs Regional Council, in line with the recommendation, will receive funding. However, in relation to Toowoomba and Whitsunday regional councils, recent events have led to both of these local governments already having received a considerable financial boost. The Bligh government committed $112 million to Toowoomba Regional Council for the huge Toowoomba pipeline project, and Whitsunday Regional Council has received a commitment of $15.6 million toward sewage treatment plant upgrades and another $7 million for the upgrade of the Whitsunday coast airport.

Another two councils will also receive funding. The QTC individual reports identified financial liquidity and sustainability issues for both Scenic Rim and Isaac regional councils, and accordingly they too will receive government assistance. A preliminary assessment of sustainability issues for Torres Strait Island Regional Council recommends further assistance for that council also. In summary, then, a total of $18.3 million will be provided as follows: North Burnett Regional Council, $348,524; South Burnett Regional Council, $1.127 million; Scenic Rim Regional Council, $2.79 million; Southern Downs Regional Council, $2.38 million; Isaac Regional Council, $4.06 million; and the Torres Strait Island Regional Council, $7.58 million.

While those other councils that put in submissions may be disappointed to not receive top-up funds, the QTC report is nonetheless good news for them because the independent adjudicator has examined their financial position and confirmed their financial sustainability. The department will work with those six councils receiving this funding to ensure that satisfactory proposals are in place to address operating deficits and other transitional tasks.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.02 am): Today I am announcing the extension of the moratorium on hotel gaming machines for two years. In 2001 hotel gaming machines were capped at 18,843 and increased to 20,000 in 2005 due to population growth, with the increase to be made available over five years. In 2008, the progressive increase in the cap was put on hold by the Queensland government to slow the growth of gaming machines. At that time the cap stood at 19,310. The two-year moratorium was due to end on 16 April 2010.

The release of the Productivity Commission report on gambling is imminent, and it is appropriate that the government give thorough consideration to its recommendations before making further decisions that may affect the availability of gambling. Also, it is unlikely that the hotel industry will be significantly disadvantaged by the extension of the moratorium as the demand for gaming machines has slowed significantly in the last couple of years. We understand community concern over poker machines and need to ensure that they are distributed throughout Queensland responsibly. A cap on poker machines results in an inevitable hit to gaming revenue, but it is action that we are prepared to take in the interests of community safety.

In addition to the cap on hotel gaming machines, the Queensland government permanently capped club gaming machines at 24,705 in 2008 and put an end to gaming in pubs and clubs before 10 am throughout the state. As a result of these harm minimisation measures, the most recent household gambling survey indicates that problem gambling affects only 0.37 per cent of the adult population in Queensland, but of course one problem gambler is one too many.

The Queensland government provides funding to community groups and non-profit organisations that are derived from gambling. In the 2008-09 financial year more than 2,250 community groups throughout Queensland received over $42.2 million from community benefit funds.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.04 am): The Bligh government has entered a new era in social housing. We are in the middle of the biggest housing investment by the Queensland and Australian governments that this state has ever seen. The former Howard government starved the states and territories of funding for social housing. We are building a range of new housing integrated into communities where it is needed, and where children and families get the best possible life opportunities. The high concentration of public housing on the fringes of towns is a legacy we want to leave well in the past.

Social housing is needed on the Gold Coast, so we are building it on the Gold Coast. It is needed in Cairns, so we are building it in Cairns. It is needed in inner-city Brisbane, so we are building it in inner-city Brisbane. People who register for social housing live in all of these communities, and usually want and need to stay in these communities.

Yesterday I joined federal housing minister Tanya Plibersek to officially launch a groundbreaking homeless accommodation and support service at South Brisbane for up to 145 people. The development will bring hope to the new tenants who will call Hope Street home on the former Gambaro’s Seafood site. The development is modelled on the highly successful common ground model first introduced in New York in the 1990s. Under the common ground concept, long-term accommodation for people caught in a cycle of chronic homelessness is coupled with on-site support. The building will be developed in line with Brisbane City Council’s vision for the area. It will be a positive addition to the street, with ground level retail areas and 24-hour concierge style security. Brisbane not-for-profit organisation Micah Projects has been funded with almost $2 million for support and street-to-home services.

The federal government is providing around $40 million for construction and land under the nation building stimulus package. The project is expected to create around 300 jobs for Queenslanders. Around 300 people sleep rough in inner-city Brisbane each night. A safe place to live and appropriate help will offer tenants a real chance at sustaining accommodation and getting back on their feet. The Bligh government is helping people who are doing it tough to find a roof over their head. We are achieving this through a number of initiatives from the biggest social housing investment ever to initiatives to help people in the private rental sector like Rentconnect and the National Rent Affordability Scheme. Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.11 am): On Tuesday the Premier and I announced the new Queensland government Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme. They understand that our sun is one of our greatest resources and understand the environmental benefits of going solar. They also know a good deal when they see one. Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.15 am): Last month I travelled to Blackwater to inspect temporary workers’ accommodation for the region’s mine employees. I thank the member for Gregory and the Central Highlands Regional Council Mayor, Peter Maguire, for conducting me on that firsthand look at the accommodation. Frankly, I was shocked by what I saw.

The pressures of rapid resource development, particularly in coalmining areas, has resulted in the use of temporary buildings of a poor standard that fail to adequately provide for the health, safety and general comfort of the workers who reside in them. While many providers of temporary accommodation deliver an outstandingly good product, current building regulations do not address minimum standards for temporary accommodation buildings, particularly those in mining regions. As far as I am concerned, that is just not good enough. Those in the industry work hard and deserve better.

After extensive consultation with key stakeholders, the Bligh government has created a new code under the Queensland Development Code which will be delivered state-wide. This new code will apply wherever temporary accommodation is provided for rent or as part of a workplace agreement. It will also apply to other temporary accommodation buildings such as granny flats or where a person lives on site while a permanent building is being constructed.

The changes will: create a limit of 24 months for the definition of temporary accommodation; require compliance with the relevant provisions of the Building Code of Australia; and improve the health and safety of the occupants. The state government is aware the Queensland Resources Council has concerns about the changes, which are estimated to cost the mining industry approximately $18 million per year. However, given the thousands of Queensland workers directly impacted and the potential expansion of the industry across the state, improving conditions is imperative. The Bligh government is committed to improving conditions for mine employees who work hard and deserve better.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.17 am): Yesterday response teams, headed up by Maritime Safety Queensland personnel, undertook clean-up operations on North West Island and Tryon Island. Late Monday we received reports that oil, likely to have been spilled from the Shen Neng 1 after it grounded on Douglas Shoal, had washed up on a nearby island. On North West Island more than 25 people worked to clear oil from a stretch of beach. Small globules of oil about the size of a 50c piece were removed and crews filled and removed five bags of oil mixed with sand. There was significantly less oil on Tryon Island, with around half a bucket full of oil and sand removed. While the amounts of oil removed may have been small, this remains a serious issue. Crews will conduct further inspections today so that any oil that does wash up can be identified and cleaned up as quickly as possible.

The Shen Neng 1 itself remains safe at anchor off Great Keppel Island. Salvage experts are expected to provide their latest update on the ship’s condition later this morning. I can advise the House that two Chinese nationals have been charged by the Australian Federal Police with offences relating to the grounding of the Shen Neng 1 and will face the Gladstone Magistrates Court this morning.
The Australian Transport Safety Bureau will hand down its preliminary fact report at 10.30 this morning, and we await that report with great interest.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.19 am): The Bligh government has been consistently tough on crime across the full spectrum of the criminal justice system. We have increased police numbers, we have toughened up penalties for serious offences and we have introduced laws to dismantle criminal organisations. Another important aspect of our ongoing campaign against crime is our proceeds of crime legislation. This legislation allows the Crime and Misconduct Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions to seek court orders restraining and forfeiting proceeds of crime and tainted property, including cash, possessions and even people’s homes. The incentive to become involved in crime is reduced when criminals face the prospect of losing their ill-gotten gains, as well as any other penalties a court may impose.

The impact of our legislation was highlighted last year when the CMC reached an important milestone--the $100 million mark for the value of proceeds of crime collected. Last year we passed amendments to the Criminal Proceeds Confiscation Act 2002--amendments that have now been in place for almost 12 months. During the development of the Criminal Organisation Bill last year, the government made a decision to review the effectiveness of these changes, and I can inform the House that this review has started. A working party has been convened by the Department of Justice and Attorney-General and key stakeholders will be asked to make submissions to the review. In particular, the review will look at how last year’s amendments are working, along with recent developments in other jurisdictions in relation to unexplained wealth and the sharing of proceeds of crime between jurisdictions following successful cases. The review will also consider any changes that may be required to further strengthen and improve the act. If the review finds that we can do more in relation to cracking down on criminals, particularly those involved in organised crime, then the government is prepared to consider further changes to this legislation. The Bligh Labor government is determined to continue its tough-on-crime stance, and this latest review will help identify and investigate any further areas to ensure that crime does not pay in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Queensland War Memorial Register; Community Memorials Restoration Program
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (10.21 am): Just before Anzac Day last year the Department of Public Works launched the online Queensland War Memorial Register website. One year on, there are now some 1,100 war memorials listed on the online register, with more going up every week. The War Memorial Register helps to further honour Queenslanders who served and often died for their country. In the past year the standout addition to the Queensland War Memorial Register has been that of the Centaur . As members would be aware, the Centaur was attacked and sunk off the coast of Queensland during World War II, killing 268 people. The Centaur ’s final resting place was found in December last year, some 56 kilometres east of Moreton Island, and is now one of Queensland’s most well-known war memorials.

That is one of the most significant war memorials in Queensland’s history, but the register covers memorials big and small across the state. The Department of Public Works’s Community Memorials Restoration Program is providing funding to help restore many of those war memorials across the state. Since 2004-05 the program has contributed more than $3 million towards restoring more than 290 memorials and icons. The latest and final round of funding is helping to restore some significant war memorials. Restorations will be carried out on the Maryborough Cenotaph, Cunnamulla Memorial Fountain and Esk War Memorial, along with memorials at Stanthorpe, Yeppoon, Weipa, Thangool, Tambo and on the Julia Creek War Memorial. In Mapoon, a Second World War Japanese anti-shipping mine will be the centrepiece in a re-established community war memorial. On Thursday Island, the Torres Strait Veterans’ Memorial will be restored to enhance the greater recognition of local service personnel. All are great examples of the Department of Public Works helping to help others to reflect on and honour those who served our country.

As a history buff, I am pleased to announce that the Department of Public Works has another informative project in the development stages as we speak. The Queensland World War II Historic Places website is being built along the same concept as the War Memorial Register. It will identify and acknowledge historic places in Queensland from the Second World War and include historical content and images. The World War II Historic Places website will be developed progressively and will be up and running by the end of the year. This unique project is part of a commitment by our government.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (10.24 am): I lay upon the table of the House the Economic Development Committee’s Issues Paper No. 3, Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism .
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Economic Development Committee: Issues Paper No. 3 titled ‘Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Grey nomads are those older tourists who have taken to a road travel lifestyle, frequently visiting Australia’s rural and regional sights. Defined by their active and social lifestyles, grey nomads tend to visit these rural and regional areas in off-peak periods. Not only do grey nomads like to get off the beaten track, providing important economic benefits in regional Queensland, but grey tourism can be less prone to the peaks and troughs of the tourism market. The committee recognises that grey nomads are an important part of Queensland’s tourism industry, particularly in rural and regional Queensland. The committee is calling for public submissions from all over Queensland on what grey nomad tourism contributes to Queensland and what this tourism market needs. The committee’s inquiry will consider the issues and challenges in responding to the needs of grey nomads to ensure that Queensland continues to provide the first-class tourism services that draw this group to Queensland. I commend the committee’s issues paper to the House.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. The last Labor health minister who claimed his department did not warn him about pending disasters was Gordon Nuttall. The Premier leapt to Gordon Nuttall’s defence and exonerated him, and I ask: will the Premier do the same thing for the current health minister, who, just like Gordon Nuttall, claims his department never warned him about impending disasters?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. Like so many of the honourable member’s questions, it is founded on a false assumption and is a gross dishonesty. What we have seen in the Deputy Premier and health minister for a number of weeks is, firstly, a minister who has taken full responsibility, as he should, for the issues involved in the implementation of a new pay system in his department. Not only has he taken full responsibility; he is someone who is driving every effort to ensure this is rectified as quickly as possible and who has put in place a comprehensive and independent review of the circumstances that has led to these matters.

Secondly, at no stage has the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health indicated that he had never been advised or warned of problems in the system. Quite the contrary: if those opposite had listened to the Deputy Premier’s ministerial statement yesterday they would have heard him advise this House of the issues over a number of months whereby the original planned implementation date to go live on the new pay system was, in fact, put back and delayed because of concerns about possible implementation issues.

So far from denying that he was aware of problems, it is a matter of public record--not only from the Deputy Premier but from a range of media outlets--that the implementation of this system was put off on a number of occasions because, being such a large and complex project, implementation issues were not sufficiently settled to allow it to go ahead on the scheduled dates.

So the assertion made by the Leader of the Opposition that the Deputy Premier has in some way denied that he was advised of these problems is not only completely and utterly false but also a matter of public record. Not only did the Deputy Premier know that there were issues; these issues were in the public arena for a number of months. As usual, I would suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that he get out of the hammock, that he get up early enough in the day to do a little bit of work--to go and do some homework. If he does, he will find the facts.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. When Gordon Nuttall claimed that his department had not warned him about pending disasters, Queensland Health bureaucrats were allowed to be questioned to see if they would validate Mr Nuttall’s claims. Will the minister allow Queensland Health staff to now be questioned under oath to see if they agree with his claim that the minister was never advised about pending disasters with Queensland Health’s payroll system? Or does the minister have something to fear and something to hide?

Mr LUCAS: If the honourable member has any evidence to suggest that anyone has undertaken anything improper, he knows where he can go with those suggestions. He can take those suggestions to the Crime and Misconduct Commission, or indeed anywhere else, where they have the full powers that are granted to standing royal commissions. That is what he should do.

Let us have a bit of a talk about honesty and deputies. I am reminded of report No. 103 in relation to a matter of privilege referred by the Speaker on 25 November 2009, which the member’s deputy was required not long ago in this House to stand up and apologise for. This is someone who was elected to parliament in 1989. The report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The committee finds it difficult to reconcile Mr Springborg’s statements in his submission with his extensive experience as a Member of the Legislative Assembly and his experience on previous ethics committees including deliberating on Standing Order 209 matters.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what the members of that committee said about the member’s deputy--a committee involving not only members on this side but also members of his own side.

It is a matter of public record that there were issues with implementation, and that is why its implementation was delayed. It is very clear from that brief that it was not signed by other people up the chain well before ministerial officers--crystal clear. Additionally, people in this state--Queensland Health employees and taxpayers--are entitled to assume that these matters, which are in the custody of people to deal with and resolve on the basis of their expertise, are dealt with.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr LUCAS: I ultimately accept responsibility for this because I am the health minister. Having said that, anyone who suggests that a minister should personally make decisions about individual aspects of compliance of an IT system or, in fact, medical treatment is wrong and false and misleading.

This is about addressing these issues, and address these issues I will. I just feel so sorry and I am so apologetic to our Queensland Health staff, who are the meat in the sandwich of this. I want this sorted out. When you have a sign-off on a document from IBM, from CorpTech and from Queensland Health--from senior people--people are entitled to expect that they can rely on that advice. Why else?
Ms CROFT: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier outline to the House the issues that must be addressed at COAG in Canberra on Monday before Queensland signs up to a health deal?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I know her very keen interest in health issues generally and particularly in the effective and good operation of our public hospitals. As I have said on a number of occasions, I will be heading to Canberra on Monday, along with the Treasurer, to get the best possible deal for Queensland. We have already seen significant increases in the Commonwealth’s offer as a result of lobbying from Queensland and a number of other states. We unashamedly want to see the Commonwealth government make a much bigger contribution and take a bigger share of the cost of running the hospitals of this country.

For too long, frankly under both sides of politics, we have seen the states bear the lion’s share of the burden of funding for health and funding for hospitals in particular. But be under no illusions: it was the Howard years that left the worst legacy of Commonwealth absence in this area. What is the legacy of the Howard government? How do we fund hospital costs now? The states fund 65 per cent and the Commonwealth funds 35 per cent. That is the legacy of the Howard years. That did not used to be the case. It used to be the case that the Commonwealth went 50-50. And John Howard walked backwards out the door, aided and abetted by those opposite.

Mr McArdle:
Why aren’t you going? You’re the health minister.
Mr Lucas: I’ll be here to sort out the payroll.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: That is right--exactly where he should be. I believe that, on balance, the deal that is on the table, with some further detail refining over the next couple of days, is a good deal for the states. But the states are right to be careful about this prospect. The states are right to be asking questions, because this signals potentially quite a big shift in the nature of the Federation. What we will be looking for is a guarantee that Queensland will be no worse off financially and in terms of service delivery; protection for the small rural and regional hospitals of Queensland; a much better deal on aged care and the relationship between our public hospitals and the aged-care sector, for which the Commonwealth has always been responsible; and for funding to be maintained over the long term.

This is a very serious issue, but it is a once-in-a-generation opportunity for us to change the relationship between the Commonwealth and the state and to get a better deal for our hospitals. That is what we will do. We will not impose a hospital tax, like that side of politics did.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. During the overseas doctor debacle a number of years ago, former health minister Gordon Nuttall released every single briefing note received by him and his office on the issue. My question to the minister is this: is the minister prepared to do exactly the same as former minister Gordon Nuttall and release every single briefing note he and his office have received on the implementation of the Queensland Health payroll system and its subsequent debacle?

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member has made a request under RTI and has been provided with that information. In fact, he gave to it the Courier-Mail last night; he did not give it to everyone else in the media. He accessed it under RTI. This government and this Premier have provided the broadest coverage of RTI of any government in the history of Australian Federation. I have made it clear that we know that there were issues with the implementation of this system as far back as 2008--in fact, before my time in the portfolio.
Mr Nicholls: So why did you go live with it?

Mr LUCAS: Why? Because the expert people, and indeed the person who was referred to in the document that was referred to in the Courier-Mail this morning, on 1 February 2010 himself certified that it was right to go. Then the project board, consisting of a representative from IBM, one of the largest companies in the world, Queensland Health, CorpTech and the chief information officer of Queensland Health, certified it. Imagine asking a member of parliament to certify a software system. It is about getting the expert people to do that.
Mr Seeney: So whose fault was it?

Mr LUCAS: There is a very legitimate question about what went wrong. That is why it is being investigated. That is why KPMG will look at it. They will have a look at the software system because clearly it did not work and people have been inconvenienced as a result of that and that is an awful situation.

In response to the honourable member about honesty, I have never in my 13 years in this parliament--unlike him in his 20--been required by the privileges committee to apologise and have the sort of finding against me that was found against him.
Ms MALE: My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier please update the House on the latest efforts to make Queensland the solar state?
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for her question and her interest in solar energy. I note that those opposite do not have an interest in solar power. I believe that Queenslanders are enthusiastic about solar energy and we see that in the data about the take-up of the solar hot water rebate and solar panels and the data about the access to our Solar Bonus Scheme.

As I said on Tuesday, we have a very clear goal for Queensland. We want to double the rate of solar energy use from 250 megawatts to 500 megawatts within five years. What I am announcing today is that we are taking another step forward. It is not just the occupants of the homes of Queensland who are enthusiastic about this agenda; the University of Queensland at its St Lucia campus is investing in a 1.2 megawatt solar photovoltaic project on one of the buildings at UQ. This is equivalent to 800 standard household PV systems and it is the largest rooftop solar panel installation in Australia. So the largest solar panel rooftop installation in Australia will be at the University of Queensland, here in Queensland.

It is not just a rooftop panel; this will be a panel that will be on top of a globally significant research effort providing researchers with real-life data on energy management and the impact of solar on our electricity network. Not only will it be generating 1.2 megawatts of power--and be the largest in Australia--this will be part of a globally significant research effort into the use of solar power.

I congratulate the University of Queensland. This is, in fact, the University of Queensland’s centenary year. In its 100 years of operation it has earned a well-deserved international reputation for groundbreaking research and academic rigour and excellence across a range of disciplines. One of the reasons it has earned that reputation is that it has, throughout its history, constantly sought to be at the cutting edge of new and emerging areas of endeavour. Solar energy is one of those areas of endeavour. I want to see every one of our universities being part of the cutting edge of research in that area. The more research they do the more affordable, achievable and widespread solar energy can become, not just for householders but in large scale solar plants across a state like Queensland so abundantly blessed with sunshine.

We will continue as a government to be great champions of solar energy and continue to make it affordable and accessible for Queenslanders, whether in their schools, their homes or their businesses. Unfortunately, I know that we will continue to hear nothing more than moaning and whingeing from the other side on this as well as other issues. We will deliver while they dither.

Mr McARDLE: My question is to the Minister for Health. I table another leaked external report by the private company SAP Australia into the high-risk status of the faulty computerised pay system which has not been tabled by the minister in the House today. From its findings and recommendations I quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is only a two to four week window to roll back the legacy system after ‘go live’ in case of major issues.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report titled ‘PM Review Report, SAP Project Management Review--Queensland Health 14 September 2009’.
XML.Hansard-Body: The ‘go live’ date was 14 March. Does that mean the window is now closed and no matter how bad it gets workers are just going to have to cop it--cop not being paid?

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member is referring to a report from SAP in relation to the project with a date of review 31 August to 11 September 2009 and the date of report 14 September 2009. What we know is that the implementation of this project was delayed on numerous occasions in relation to its rollout due to lack of satisfaction with same.
Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition was brandishing around here a document and he conveniently forgot to mention what it said about Lattice and the issues with Lattice, the existing system.
Mr Springborg: At least it worked!

We have had someone who has been asked to withdraw by the privileges committee for misleading the House, we have had the Leader of Opposition Business who did that as well and now we have the member for Caloundra who dares ask anyone about these things when his signature, rolled gold, is on a Boyce Garrick mortgage scheme saying Mark McArdle is responsible for compliance.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That you note issues in relation to the IBM contract with CorpTech and that both CorpTech and Queensland Health are working to obtain a solution to the issue.
XML.Hansard-Body: We note from documents tabled here today in 2010 that he said to go ahead and then the project board did. This document tabled by the honourable member is interesting. They said--
