XML.Hansard-Body: Did they go live on 20 November? No, they did not.
Mr CHOI: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Could the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health inform the House of the importance of national healthcare reform?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. The statistics show that Australians have the second longest life expectancy on earth. This is about making a good system even better. At the same time, it is a system that has ever-increasing demand, growing well in excess of our population rate. Not that it is a state responsibility but, for example, with the population increasing by 11 per cent, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme increased by 31 per cent. The nature of the health system--increased success in medical conditions, ageing population, rising demand and more expensive treatments--dictates it.

The number of people aged 65 to 84 years has more than doubled and the number of people aged 85 years will quadruple by 2050. Rising expectations and demands on our hospital system are ever increasing and those ever-increasing demands then again drive further demands. If one has a look at kidney replacement therapy figures for people aged 70, 20 years ago essentially they did not present themselves in any number at all. So health is like a running race where you always want to set the next target in front of you.

As demand for health services also grows, we need to employ more people to deliver those services. Since 2005, we have employed an extra 12,500 doctors, nurses and allied health professionals. Correspondingly, in 2003-04, Queensland Health provided around 8.8 million occasions of service. In just five years this figure has skyrocketed to 10.8 million--a 22 per cent increase in occasions of service under Queensland Health. Simply we have had to employ more people, pay them more and do more surgical and medical treatments against a state budget limited in its capacity to collect revenue.

The member for Clayfield always likes to parrot on about John Howard putting more money into health. He did grow the dollar funding for health, but it nowhere near matched state increases. That is one thing we do agree with John Brumby on--nowhere near did federal Howard funding increase it. In fact, it was responsible for the worst public health policy decision ever--the Mersey Hospital takeover. For the first time, the Commonwealth government has committed itself to funding growth.

So what are the areas that we see as important? The Premier’s contribution to aged care has simply been outstanding. We do need--and I note that a number of members have raised this--more money for aged-care funding. We welcome the low-interest loans, we welcome the support for doctors to do more treatment in nursing homes, but more needs to be done. Critically, critically, critically, outpatients--for which Queensland is $240 million worse off without patient specialist clinics--need to be addressed. The additional funding for training positions will assist but Queensland needs not to be penalised compared to other states. Rural and regional training I think is very, very exciting. One of the things that we need more of is more people in those regions.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Minister for Health and Deputy Premier. Minister Schwarten says that the health payroll system has no problems. With reports that Queensland Health staff are receiving payslips for as little as 1c and as much as $2 million, does the minister still agree with his Labor cabinet college that ‘nothing that has come to light has suggested a breakdown in this system’?

Mr LUCAS: The Minister for Public Works has made his position very, very clear in relation to this and he joins with me in wanting this sorted out. I do not think either me or the Minister for Public Works have any reputations in this place for being blushing violets or accepting things as they are with some fatalistic attitude. What we both agree on is that this needs to be investigated and investigated properly. Frankly, the Minister for Public Works and I are not interested in squabbles between SAP, Queensland Health, CorpTech, Workbrain or anyone else. Our motivation is to get this sorted out. That is what we want to do.

That is why KPMG has been appointed to do a number of things. First of all, KPMG is there at the moment supervising what we are doing--supporting what we are doing to make sure that the next payroll run is as hiccup free as possible and other matters are attended to. I might say parenthetically that any payroll system that Queensland Health has, being such a complex payroll, would require adjustments due to late changes in shifts, meal allowances and all those sorts of things.

Secondly, KPMG will look at issues surrounding the assessment and the rollout of this software. Frankly, I do not care who wants to cover themselves and protect themselves in relation to it. I want it investigated and it will be investigated independently by KPMG.
Mr Nicholls: So has there been a breakdown in the system?
Mr LUCAS: Clearly the system has not worked. Clearly it has not worked because people have not been paid, and it is not on.
Mr Nicholls: That’s not what your colleague said. He said there’s no breakdown.
Ms Bligh: He didn’t say that--dishonest again.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Stop the clock so I can have order in the House.
Mr Nicholls: Have a look at Hansard from yesterday.
Ms Bligh: Yes, go and read it--read the whole paragraph.
Mr SPEAKER: Just resume your seat. I will wait for both sides to stop interjecting. The honourable Deputy Premier and Minister for Health.

Mr LUCAS: Thirdly, and also very critically, we will need to roll out new payroll systems across the Queensland government from time to time. What we want KPMG to do is to assess the appropriate procedures in relation to doing them. We cannot let this happen again. Queensland Health staff have been let down. They have been let down badly. It is not good enough. They have not only been let down badly and not been paid. But when you pay big money for a system and when you have people there to assess and implement systems, they have every reason to expect as taxpayers, as does anyone else in Queensland, that that would happen. The Minister for Public Works and I are not qualified IT professionals. We are there making sure that there is an investigation into this so it can be sorted out into the future.

Ms O’NEILL: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer update the House on government initiatives supporting Queensland’s growing aviation industry?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Kallangur for her interest in the aviation sector, for her interest in the fact that it delivers jobs in Brisbane and for people on the north side. The aviation industry has been a policy priority for this government and it is an industry that now sees 16,500 Queenslanders employed in that industry. It has been an industry that we have supported.

Over the last 30 days I have seen firsthand three businesses that are creating jobs in this area. On the south side in the electorate of the member for Chatsworth is Ferra Engineering, working with Lockheed Martin, producing and manufacturing components for the joint strike fighter--an aircraft that will be the new standard for air forces around the world. At the Brisbane Airport we have the joint venture between Airbus and Qantas Defence Services, converting four A330s into flying petrol tanks to support the Royal Australian Air Force for the future. Finally, last Friday, with the CEO of Qantas, I was there to launch the plans for heavy maintenance of the A330 fleet right here in Brisbane, securing the future of another 450 jobs. That is our support for the aviation industry--delivering jobs, delivering jobs for the future.

Speaking of take-offs, we are now inside the last 14 days until the launch of the opposition leader into the flight of fancy that is his attempt at policies. At T minus 14 this would have to be the most anticipated shuttle launch in recent times. Of course he announced that he would be on the launch pad nearly 360 days ago, and it is more than 300 days since the shadow Treasurer lit the fuse underneath him and put him on the spot and said that he would be delivering in the budget reply. You can imagine the questions that are out there as we head towards the next 14 days. You can imagine the count down.

Here we are at T minus 14 and the count down will get there. You can imagine at T minus 7: what is the opposition leader going to do about the balance sheet? At T minus 6: what projects will he cut? At T minus 5: what is the status of their previously stated pro-privatisation policy? At T minus 5: what is the status of this document? At T minus 4: will he repudiate once and for all their plan to slash three per cent across the public sector? At T minus 2: will he repudiate once and for all his pledge to cut 12,000 jobs out of the public sector? At T minus 1: will he set a jobs target of above zero? What we know is that, while Queenslanders will be tuned in, while they will be on their BlackBerrys, while they will be lining the streets, while the member for Warrego will turn on the crystal set waiting to hear the policies that come from the opposition leader, the people of Queensland want to know what the opposition leader stands for, what his policies are. Is it just fury and light and smoke and steam? Or does he actually stand for something other than just another whingeing opposition leader without a policy and without an idea?

Mrs STUCKEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. In relation to Queensland Health’s bungled payroll, the minister yesterday said ‘nothing that has come to light has suggested a breakdown in this system’. After 24 hours, I ask the minister to ponder his statement and these facts: some workers have not been paid overtime, some workers have not been paid at all, some workers are receiving gross overpayments, and the health minister cannot guarantee the next pay cheque to workers. Does the minister continue to deny there have been any breakdowns with this system?
Mr SCHWARTEN: Let me just go back to what I said yesterday. What I said was that nobody had come to me and told me there were any problems in the IT system--the IT system.
Mr Springborg: That’s not what you said.
Mr SCHWARTEN: That is what I referred to; it is a system. But then I went on to say--
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Well, if you go back two days, that is exactly what I said. I have consistently said that, in regard to the system that I am responsible for, no-one has come forward with those things. What I then went on to say is: that is why we have got KPMG looking at it.
Mr Nicholls: ‘Nothing has come to light’.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Nothing has come to light, and that is exactly what I had been told by IBM yesterday. I have been told about the IT system, which is different from an overall payroll system--I did not say the payroll system. People are not getting paid--blind Freddy can see that--and that is happening in my electorate, and I am well aware of that. But it is my job to drill down and get the people in the Department of Public Works to engage with CorpTech and IBM to determine what those problems might be.

I have been told that they are not IT related. However, we have then said, ‘Okay, that’s all very well. We want to run the ruler over those statements. We want KPMG to get to the bottom of those.’ As far as all of my investigations have gone, every single person, from IBM down to CorpTech, has said to me that this is not a problem in IT, that this is a problem elsewhere. I am responsible for that and I have never ducked that responsibility. Indeed, neither has the Minister for Health in his regard. We have spoken with IBM. I got the director in yesterday, and he assured me that they welcomed the KPMG report but he was confident in his advice to me.

Also, the director-general went down to the ASU this morning and met with them. These are the poor people who are trying to pay these people, and we wanted them to ask it there was any issue with the actual IT system. The feedback I have received from them this morning is they would like it to be quicker, so we are going to get into that. The reality is that KPMG is being hired to do this--
An opposition member interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I know it is very difficult for you to understand this, but there is an IT system. When an IT minister talks about a system, he is talking about an IT system. That is common knowledge in the IT industry. I do not expect you to understand it.

Mr O’BRIEN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. The north and west of our great state are perfect for solar energy. Could the minister please inform the House of any solar initiatives planned for these areas?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for the question, as he is someone who is passionate about opportunities for renewable energy in one of the most isolated electorates anywhere in the world. Queensland’s isolated communities are, as the member for Cook said, perfect for renewable energy solutions. Some remote communities in his electorate of Cook are about to do the bright thing with solar power. Many of our remote and isolated communities are in places with the potential to harness intense solar energy.

There are 33 remote communities in Western Queensland, the Torres Strait and Cape York which are not on the electricity grid. At present they rely on diesel generators. About 5,800 Queenslanders live in these communities. They use about 28 million litres of diesel fuel for their electricity generation each year. This releases about 80,000 tonnes of greenhouse gases every year. It is expensive for both those residents and of course the environment. We think we can do better by doing the bright thing.

What we are doing as a government is investing 200 kilowatts of renewable energy in four different isolated communities in Far North and Western Queensland. Thursday Island, Horn Island, Bamaga and Boulia are the communities that have been selected as the first four communities to trial renewable energy alternatives. They have been selected because together they represent over a third of the total residents who live in isolated communities, but there are also different solar radiation levels in the three areas selected.

Just over $1 million in solar systems will be installed on rooftops in these four communities beginning from June this year. They are not just getting solar; they are also getting energy efficient programs to cut overall electricity use, like audits, efficient lighting and water heating, and efficient shower heads. We hope that they will be saving up to $300 a year on their electricity bills by adopting these energy efficient technologies. Ergon Energy will be installing solar PV systems on the roofs of strategic community buildings like hospitals, schools and local council owned facilities and housing. We hope that the experience from these four communities will help us roll this program out to other communities. It would be indeed the bright thing to do. This just gives a further indication of how innovative our government owned corporations like Ergon Energy are in terms of exploring opportunities to reduce the load from diesel power generation and adopting renewable energy alternatives that will also help with the hip pocket.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. The minister has always insisted that he is a champion of workers rights. Does the minister stand by the claim he made yesterday that the SAP system driving the bungled Queensland Health payroll was not a failure? Will the minister finally admit that his head-in-the-sand attitude demonstrates an arrogant disregard for the rights of Queensland Health workers who are suffering due to his incompetence?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Again, we have a question that has no basis in fact, because what I said yesterday was that all the advice that was given to me had said that this SAP system was working. That remains the advice that I have. Certainly there are people who have not been paid, and every worker is entitled to be paid. Every worker is entitled to be paid regardless, and I have never, ever suggested otherwise, and nor would I. No-one on this side of politics has ever done that. You are the party that took away people’s superannuation rights, so do not start lecturing us about what working class people should have.

The reality is--and I stand by what I said--that every piece of advice that has come to me on this IT system tells me that it is functioning appropriately. But we have not accepted that at face value. I have drilled down. I have spoken to the individuals concerned in this as hard as I can. I have done that consistently. The answer has been consistent. So what are we doing about it? We are not just accepting that at face value. We are getting a third party to go in there and dig around and find out exactly why people are not getting paid. That is what we are doing. It is not as though we are sitting here blindly doing nothing about it. We are acknowledging there is a problem.

We have drilled down and asked questions, and the questions I have asked have been answered by people whose signatures appear on the document to say to go live. They have told me that the system they signed up to is working. That is what they are saying. We are saying it is not working in that it does not pay people in certain cases. They are saying to me that the majority of people are getting paid and so on. Those conversations have been held. I have gone as far as I can go with it. I have talked to these people and the advice remains the same. We have talked to the people at the coalface, and now we have an inquiry that will rapidly, I hope, report to us on just what is the nature of the issue.

If it is an IT issue then there will be some serious ramifications for IBM, I can tell you that. No-one from that side of the parliament has yet produced any evidence of IT failures. I have not seen anything that says that. I have asked all the questions, as I said. I am not sitting here with blinkers on or trying to pretend that the issue is not there. I have asked all the questions of the people who were there and I have got the same answers consistently. As I said, this morning we talked to the people who are implementing this. They are saying that they would like it to be quicker. We are addressing that issue, but in reality no-one has come forward to me and said that this is an IT failure. But KPMG will tell us that.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Can the minister inform the House what the state’s police and emergency services agencies are doing to harness the power of the sun?

Mr ROBERTS: I am pleased to also have an opportunity to talk about the solar initiatives of my department. Queensland police and emergency services are not only looking after the safety of Queenslanders but are also taking significant steps towards improving the environmental outcomes of the facilities being built. There are a number of solar initiatives that I would like to outline to the House.

With respect to the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service, solar hot-water systems have been installed at new stations--and this will be an ongoing matter in terms of new developments--at Kippa-Ring, Burpengary, Redland Bay and Cairns. The Queensland Ambulance Service, similarly, with its new developments, new stations and refurbishments, has installed solar hot-water systems recently in Julia Creek, Duaringa, Mount Morgan, Clermont and South Brisbane. The QAS Kowanyama field office has solar panels installed on its roof as well. In addition, both the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service and the Queensland Ambulance Service have repeater stations which have solar panels that support those as well.
With respect to the Queensland Police Service, as the Minister for Public Works outlined yesterday, the joint contact centre at Zillmere is at the leading edge of environmental design--
Mr Schwarten: The greenest building in Australia.

Mr ROBERTS: It is the greenest building in Australia. It has received a six-star green office design rating. It will include photovoltaic cells which will help reduce its dependence on the electricity grid and reduce emissions and peak demand.

Some of the police facilities with solar hot water recently installed include Wujal Wujal, Laura, Burpengary, Sippy Downs, North Lakes, Crestmead, Yeppoon Water Police, Springfield, Cooktown, Julia Creek and Marian--and the list goes on. The QPS has solar panels supporting its repeater stations throughout the network.

While I am on my feet, yesterday during question time the member for Mirani asked me a question relating to 000 call centres. He made a claim that over 4,000 Queenslanders have had to call 000 up to four times before they got through. I indicated to the member for Mirani that that was a problem which was news to me, and I gave him an opportunity to present the evidence to me. Did he do that? No, not at all. Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Premier. The Premier last weekend promised that heads would roll in the Queensland Health pay fiasco. Two ministers this week have denied that the system has failed, they have denied they were warned--

Mr LUCAS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker. The assertion in the honourable member’s question is offensive and untrue. At no stage have I denied that the system did not fail people. I have repeatedly made that clear.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Do not get into a debate.
Mr LUCAS: I find it offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Similarly, Mr Speaker, I find it offensive.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr LUCAS: I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker. At no stage have I denied that the system has failed. I have repeatedly made it clear. The honourable member’s assertion in this House that I have denied the system failed is patently clear, and it reflects on me.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I will allow the question.

The Premier last weekend promised that heads would roll in the Queensland Health pay fiasco. Two ministers this week have denied that the system has failed, denied that they were warned and denied that they made any wrong decisions, and they have both denied that they could have prevented the fiasco. Does the Premier now deny that she needs to keep her promise and sack these incompetent ministers?
Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. Of course, the honourable member did not name any such minister because there is no such minister.
Mr SEENEY: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. If the Premier was not listening yesterday in question time, I refer her to the library clips--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is no point of order.

Ms BLIGH: More tactical dishonesty from the master of it. There is no minister who has denied that there is a problem with the Queensland Health pay system. The problems are self-evident. Every minister in this government is aware of them, just as I suspect every Queenslander is aware of them. Those opposite for their own political purposes are seeking dishonestly to deliberately misconstrue what I think are patently clear statements from both ministers concerned. What has the health minister done about this? From day one he has been open about it, he has at every opportunity been willing to speak--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I want to hear the Premier’s answer. I cannot hear any member being offended by the Premier’s answer so far.

Ms BLIGH: He has been open, he has been honest, and he has been willing to talk to the media and make any public comments on this. The nonsense of what is being asserted by those opposite is that the health minister has denied there is a problem, but he has put in place a comprehensive, independent review of a problem they allege he says does not exist. It is a nonsense. It is absolute nonsense. What we will be doing is looking at the outcomes of the KPMG inquiry.
Mr McArdle: Will it be released?
Ms BLIGH: That will be released into the public arena--of course it will be. If there is any evidence that anybody has breached their duty, then of course appropriate action will be taken.

I know that those opposite have a long history of preferring to put the penalty in place before they have any evidence of who they should in fact be penalising. But we will have a very clear approach--evidence followed by action. That is how this will be managed. It is an absolute patent nonsense from those opposite to suggest that the Minister for Health and the Minister for Public Works are in any way denying there is a problem. Of course there is a problem. It is the most self-evident problem in Queensland. Whose responsibility is it to fix it? It is the responsibility of the government, led by the health minister, and that is what we are doing.

Mrs MILLER: My question is to the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. Could the minister please update the House on what the state government is doing to help skill plumbers for a brighter solar future?

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I thank the member for Bundamba for her question. The Bligh government is doing the bright thing and helping to upskill plumbers as more Queenslanders switch to solar hot water. Plumbers are being offered face-to-face training from registered training organisations like the Master Plumbers Association of Queensland and simple online courses to ensure that they are solar skilled. While the skills of plumbing might date back to Roman times, it is a trade that is highly responsive to changing needs and the application of this in this 21st century trade. Solar hot water is an excellent example of this continuing adaptation.

From 1 January 2011 plumbers and provisional plumbers will need to have an endorsement on their plumber’s licence to install, commission and test solar and/or heat pump installations. As mentioned, registered training organisations, including the Master Plumbers Association of Queensland and SkillsTech Australia, are already providing an accredited course to ensure plumbers have the skills and endorsements to do the bright thing.

In addition, administered through the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, a Plumbing Industry Council online assessment option has been established for licensed plumbers unable to attend the training course to do the bright thing. Approximately 200 plumbers have already undertaken the training and passed the requirement with a further 64 currently enrolled. They are all doing the bright thing. This initiative will reduce the administrative burden on local government, speed up the approval process and provide Queensland plumbers with invaluable professional development.

My department is currently conducting a state-wide roadshow to inform plumbers and other stakeholders of the latest opportunities for training around the licensing requirements and provide support to them. This roadshow is being run in centres from Cairns to Coolangatta until June. It follows on from the Bligh government’s generous Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme. It again highlights the state government’s commitment to deliver on solar and do the bright thing.

With support from this government, plumbers will play a key role in doing the bright thing, helping Queensland householders reduce their energy consumption and cut their electricity bills. We can see that Queensland households can, on average, reduce their carbon footprint by about two tonnes per year with initiatives like the installation of solar hot water. This is part of taking Queensland homes further into the 21st century. Plumbers will play a key role and the Queensland government will play a key role in supporting them to do the bright thing.

Mrs PRATT: My question is to the Treasurer. Mining companies are currently acquiring properties in the Darling Downs area which have been sold by the registered titleholder and have the added bonus of coming with a private royalties agreement. It has been estimated that over the 20-year life of the Felton mine alone the royalties lost to the Crown will be in the vicinity of $560 million. This would supply much needed state infrastructure. Treasurer, when mining entities purchase private properties with these private royalty agreements is the government considering implementing legislation which automatically returns these royalties to the Crown? If not, why not?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Nanango for her question. It may come as a surprise to some members of the House and indeed to some members of the community that, for reasons of history, there is a minority of Queensland where governments of yesteryear--not this government or its immediate predecessors--did provide for land to be sold into the marketplace that uniquely also included the rights to the minerals contained underneath. This is a matter of history.

I think it is fair to say that there would not be any appetite on either side of the House for such divestments to occur into the future. But it is the case now that, given that those private property rights exist, it would only be under the relevant legislation and under the Constitution possible to resume those property rights as they now are by paying the full compensable value of the minerals contained underneath. So it is a false economy that is being proposed by the member for Nanango. There is no ability to secure the private royalty rights of the minerals that lie on that land without paying the full compensation.

There is no ability, therefore, for this state government or indeed its predecessors or those into the future to otherwise acquire those private property rights and therefore gain access to an additional income stream. The value of those royalty rights that exist in that minority of land that exist for historical reasons is the exact equivalent of what we would have to pay them in order to acquire it.

I think this is best described as an accident of history. It is not a policy that is pursued by this government nor I expect will it be pursued by governments into the future. But I do note that, for reasons of history which are on the record, a good many of the properties in question do in fact reside in and around the townships of the Nanango electorate. I am sure that is why this matter has been brought to the member’s attention.

When it comes to royalties, the Henry taxation review is on foot. We expect that it will be in the public arena in accordance with the commitment of the federal Treasurer. These are matters that will be resolved in the context of the Henry taxation review. Our government’s resolve in the first instance is always to protect the sanctity of the state’s revenue base. That is our starting position. We also recognise that the constitutional capacity exists within the Commonwealth to make other policy proposals. The position that we will be putting forward is that we will not be dealing with these issues one by one; we will be dealing with the arrangements proposed and ensuring that when it comes to taxation reform, royalties and otherwise, that the deal for Queensland is a good one.

Mr WELLS: My question is to the Minister for Transport. I ask the honourable lady will she explain how Queensland Rail is adapting solar power to new railway stations and reducing our carbon footprint?

Ms NOLAN: I thank the member for Murrumba for his question. As we all know, public transport is already the green way to travel, but now Queensland Rail is doing the bright thing too. At all of its new railway stations Queensland Rail constructs solar panels as part of the design and those solar panels feed into the electricity grid creating clean, green solar energy for all Queenslanders to consume.

When Indooroopilly Railway Station was upgraded in 2008 that redesign included solar panels. The new Varsity Lakes Railway Station, as part of the Labor government’s commitment to extend rail back to the Gold Coast, includes solar panels as part of its sustainable design. Now the new Richlands Railway Station, which is currently under construction and due to open next year, also includes solar panels generating clean, green electricity as part of its design.

Public transport is already the green way to travel. For every kilometre travelled on public transport each passenger generates on average 30 grams of carbon dioxide. If that same person were travelling in a car 250 grams of CO2 would be generated.

Queensland Rail is not stopping there. In addition to doing the bright thing with its solar panels on new stations, new stations also include other elements of sustainable design. Varsity Lakes Railway Station, for instance, has an airy, subtropical design with natural air flows and lighting and a tremendous use of glass. Queensland Rail is in the process of rolling out a major recycling program with 250 recycling bins being established across the Queensland Rail network.

Queenslanders want to go green. They want as individuals to do the right thing. That is why they are in increasing numbers choosing public transport, and Queensland Rail--not just in providing sustainable ways to travel but also doing the bright thing and creating sustainable stations as part of its new design--is helping Queenslanders every day to make the green choice.

Mr ELMES: My question without notice is to the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. If the minister is serious about protecting dugong and turtles in Queensland waters, why will she not act immediately to ban the hunting of these animals in the green zone areas of Green Island, Michaelmas Cay and Low Isles near Cairns--areas heavily visited by tourists--and make this government’s supposed attempts to stop the inhumane slaughter of dugong and turtles real and not just a myth?
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, you have 30 seconds.

Ms JONES: Great! Firstly, native title legislation is federal legislation. One would expect the shadow minister to know that. Secondly, the best way to protect dugong and turtles in Queensland is to protect their habitat, and what have those opposite done? They voted against protecting their habitat, the Great Barrier Reef. They then asked me to wind back the protection in Moreton Bay, home to over 800 dugong and thousands of turtles. The LNP’s record shows that this is mock outrage from the shadow minister for the environment. If the honourable member truly cared about dugongs, then he would vote with our government to protect their habitat.
Mr SPEAKER: The time for question time is over.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 14 April (see p. 1416), on motion of Mr Robertson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (11.31 am): The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to amend various acts in order to enhance safety and health measures, streamline and simplify the government’s mining lease application process in order to it speed up, improve credit support arrangements for electricity retailers, and improve customer service obligations. Our state’s wealth and growth are due largely to the strength and diversity of our resources industry. It contributes around $30 billion a year to the Queensland economy and employs thousands of people, with estimated flow-on effects showing that the sector accounts for more than one in every eight Queensland jobs. It provides funding for programs in Queensland such as school based activities, sporting donations and sponsorships, welfare initiatives, and improving access to education and training and medical services. Even going back six years before the mining boom, a Queensland Resources Council survey showed that the resources sector spent $4.2 billion on goods and services sourced in Queensland, more than $1.3 billion on wages and salaries and over $22 million on community and Indigenous programs in which Queensland generally and regional communities specifically were major beneficiaries.

The contribution of the resources sector to employment, infrastructure and services in rural and regional areas cannot be underestimated, and it is our responsibility to ensure that further development of the sector is not impeded. We must do everything we can to drive this viable and environmentally sustainable use of our resources and ensure that the benefits flow back to Queensland. Exports of lead, copper, zinc, gold, silver, bauxite, tin, oil and gas provide the income that stimulates the investment we rely on. The export of coking and high-quality thermal coal in particular is vital to the Queensland economy.

In his second reading speech the minister said that this bill would enhance health and safety measures, and nothing is more important in the mining industry than health and safety. It is important that we closely monitor mining companies’ compliance with safety requirements and the reporting of injuries. Mining is a hazardous industry, and this is demonstrated by the fact that there have been a number of deaths in the mining industry, including in my electorate. It is vital that everyone involved in the industry is focused on ensuring the safety and health of mineworkers. It is paramount that the Queensland Mines Inspectorate is adequately resourced and funded.

I now turn to the issue of improved credit support arrangements for electricity retailers and improved customer service obligations. Since full retail competition electricity prices have gone up by 40 per cent. Before deregulation it was promised by the government and the minister of the day that electricity prices would be competitive and that there was even a chance that prices would come down. Obviously that has not happened. For example, an electricity bill of around $600 before deregulation has now increased to around $1,000. This is not a great example, especially given the impending sale of our profitable assets. People in rural and regional Queensland never had the opportunity to advance from full retail competition because it was not viable, but that really did not make any difference because electricity prices have gone up by 40 per cent. As I said, given the upcoming sale of our profitable assets, this is not a great example of what is to come.

We acknowledge the value of our great coal industry, the push for clean coal technology and the further need to meet electricity demand. There are many warnings of the coming demand/supply imbalance and urgent need for a baseload power station in North Queensland, and there is much talk about upgrading the high-voltage network between Townsville and Mount Isa. This will help and will support investment in the mining belts of those western areas of regional and rural Queensland and into North Queensland. However, there is no use expanding the high-voltage network if there is no baseload power station to transmit the power, because mining development and investment in North and Western Queensland have been put on hold because of the lack of a reliable power source. The further you transmit power, the more costs are associated with that transmission.

It is logical to identify--something we on this side have pushed on many occasions--Pentland as an alternative site for a clean coal baseload power station. Major stakeholders have already done extensive investigations into the feasibility of building a power station at Pentland, including a $2 million drilling program completed by the owners of the Pentland coal reserve, Xstrata, which confirmed that the ore body is of good enough quality for an economically viable 600 to 800 megawatt power station for the next 35 to 40 years. This site makes common sense because it has one of the biggest river systems in Queensland. There is plentiful water supply, a nearby rail facility, a rural environment and a potential power station that sits on unlimited coal reserves, and Pentland is a vital link to North-West Queensland. This proposal has the support of federal and state members of parliament, the Charters Towers Chamber of Commerce, the city and shire councils, Townsville Enterprise, visitors and investors.

Mr HOBBS (Warrego--LNP) (11.37 am): I am pleased to rise today to speak to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. I commend the contribution by the shadow minister, who went into great detail about those issues in the mining industry that are important to us, particularly the coal seam gas industry. I want to talk about electricity generation, in particular coal seam gas electricity generation, and the resource that is used for that generation. I also want to speak about the issue of pipelines, which are significant in this legislation.

One thing we need to get our minds around is the new technologies. It is wonderful to see the enormous development that is happening in the Surat Basin in my electorate. However, there are some serious impacts because of that. Some changes have been made in recent days that will go some way towards helping understand some of those complications, and I refer to the fact that there will be something like 40,000 coal seam gas wells in the Surat Basin in the next three to 10 years. With that number of wells being put down, there will be something like 196 gigalitres of water annually brought up from those coal seam aquifers. While we welcome the development, there is a concern about the diminishing water supply for those aquifers below and above.

A lot of the towns in my area rely entirely on the Great Artesian Basin--towns such as Dalby, Roma, Charleville, Tambo, Blackall, Mitchell and many others--as the major water source for their urban development. There are something like 2,700 bores in the artesian basin and 15,000 sub-bores as well. They come in at different levels. This enormous amount of water going out of those coal seam beds means that the pressure drops--the head drops--and the Santos EIS has indicated that that may be as much as 65 metres. If that happens, you can get leakage from the other aquifers into that vacuum, so to speak. Therefore, urban water users and farmers who use bores may find that their pressure drops--their levels drop--and that there is a significant impact on them. That is the unknown. There is a lot of concern out there--and there has been for a long time--that there will be this impact.

Now we have a starting point, I guess. I raised the issue last year that, when the companies were putting down the wells, they were not doing the monitoring. That is occurring now. We need to ensure that the benchmarking is done so that if those 15,000 bores or the 2,700 sub-bores reduce in volume, there can be an investigation to determine whether there has been an impact by the coal seam gas industry. So we need to be able to monitor that. It is a difficult situation, but it is one that we have to manage.

The use of the water needs to be considered as well. Certainly, urban water use is a potential use. I think we have to look much more seriously at reinjecting that water, once it is cleaned, back into those aquifers--and as much as possible into the right aquifer. I know that that process costs a lot of money but, then again, we are generating gas at the surface. So I think some more serious thought needs to be given to what we do with that water.

In relation to the pipelines that obviously crisscross the area, we need to have better corridors in which to utilise these pipelines. I know that is difficult to do when there are so many wells being put in, but I think providing better corridors needs to be considered. Also, in a lot of cases the state government does not allow the pipelines to traverse state forest or state owned land. It is okay to put pipelines across farmers’ land but, in doing that, they always take the cleared paddock as it is easier because there are no trees to clear. The companies take the easy route. But I think the state government and the landowners should be sharing this responsibility equally. The state government should certainly be pulling its weight.

Another concern--and this was shown in the Santos EIS for the Gladstone pipeline--is that there is the possibility of subsidence in some areas, and there was mention of up to five inches in subsidence in the Injune area and maybe two inches in the Roma area if the enormous pressure goes off those lower aquifers. It is hard to believe that there would be much drop from that distance, but there seems to be that possibility. So there is certainly a need to monitor that, because landowners do not want to have any significant impact, particularly on the good farming areas. I guess it does not matter so much if it is on the grazing areas rather than on the farming land.

As I mentioned before, some of those pipelines are significant. There have been some difficulties and some heartache between landholders and the companies in relation to access. I believe the situation is improving but, when you get into the smaller farming areas and most certainly into those prime agricultural land areas where, for a start, there should not be any mining at all, if pipelines have to traverse those areas the companies need to be very careful about how they do it because the black soil particularly moves. If you get wet seasons, it is not hard to push down to almost the same level as where some of those pipelines are laid. So there needs to be a lot of consideration given to that issue.

Another particularly serious issue relates to the management of prime agricultural land. Although this government has released a paper on this issue that talks about having different categories of land, I do not think that it has looked seriously enough at the issue. Over 12 months ago we announced that we would protect prime agricultural land. I think that that needs to be done sooner rather than later.

This legislation is important. Once again, I do not want to repeat what others have said. The shadow minister has summed it up fairly well. I hope that the issues that I have raised, particularly in relation to the coal seam gas areas, are taken into consideration.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! Just before I acknowledge the next speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge in the gallery this morning teachers and school leaders from the West Moreton Anglican College, represented outstandingly in this House by the member for Ipswich West.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (11.45 am): I rise to participate in the debate on the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. I will follow on from the comments of the member for Warrego and say that I also do not intend to repeat the matters that have been raised, but simply put on the record my support for the bill and my congratulations to the minister on trying to find ways to remove the red tape in the application process that sometimes chokes our courts.

It makes a lot of sense to remove the mandatory requirement for the Land Court to assess mining lease applications when there have been no properly lodged objections. The bottom line is that we should not allow people to abuse the court process, or whatever the process is. I think that is a good move. It demonstrates that the government is trying to remove unnecessary red tape. I believe that it is an attempt to try to free up the Land Court system. Quite frankly, if someone has an objection, it is incumbent upon them to substantiate that objection and not just simply use a legal technicality to draw out a process for ulterior purposes.

I congratulate the minister on trying to close down this legal loophole. I thank him for trying to remove that unnecessary red tape. I understand that this bill is being supported by the opposition as well. I look forward to it proceeding to the consideration in detail stage.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (11.47 am): I rise to speak to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I can understand the reasoning behind trying to shorten the application process--to take it out of the court system when there are no objections et cetera--but I have one qualification and that relates to emerging new technologies, which are coming through all the time. When I say that, I am talking about UCG--underground coal gasification--which is going on my area at the moment with a pilot plant.

Recently I was talking with the CEO of the company involved, Cougar Energy. He was involved in a pilot plant at Chinchilla and is now involved in one just on the outskirts of the Kingaroy township, very close to a densely populated area. He told me that when he was in Chinchilla there was absolutely no objection to the project. Nobody said anything. Nobody raised an issue. But in Kingaroy it is a totally different situation. He was very unprepared for the amount of community sentiment that arose in this area. I explained to him that the reason there is such a sensitivity to this new technology is not just that it is new but that for the past 10 to 15 years there has been much land acquisition for mining purposes going on in the area and that it has been a very long and painful process.

I have concerns about new technology like UCG. I am not talking syngas; I am talking UCG. I can assure members that the concerned citizens group has avidly searched the net and everywhere possible for information about UCG production. No-one has been able to find a successful operation that has been going for any length of time--not even for a short time--but they can find so many negatives.

As was mentioned by the member for Warrego, a lot of the concern is around soil quality and the structure of the land. One might say it is very unstable land. I will go into a bit of technical detail here so that people can understand why there is such concern in the Kingaroy area. The pilot plant is on top of a hill. I can see it from my own house, which is on top of the neighbouring hill. They are not very big hills because it is not very high country. The coal seam that they are mining is down very low in a very low water table. There is water running through the coal seam. There is also an aquifer on top that most, but not all, farmers in that area access for their water. It was revealed last Monday night, at a meeting of concerned citizens with DERM and Cougar Energy representatives, that some people actually take water for livestock and private purposes from the coal seam stream. This has been going on for quite some time in our area, but the company and DERM have only just discovered that people are accessing water from the coal seam stream.

People want to know whether some time down the track--maybe not tomorrow but in five years time when the pilot is finished or in 50 years time--any of the contaminant will come out as the water flows very slowly through the coal seam. A major issue is where it will have an effect in the future. We all know that there will be contaminants from the burning of the coal underground--the company knows that and so does DERM. The people are concerned where it will come out.

The other issue is whether there will be subsidence on the top aquifer which alters the flow of that water. Officers from DERM say that it is unlikely; representatives from Cougar Energy say that they do not believe it will. It is all right to say that, but what if there is subsidence? Livelihoods and farms are ruined if there is any subsidence at all. We know the aquitard, which is above the mine and below the water table, is very stable and very strong, but this kind of pilot has not been conducted in this area before. We know that it had to be conducted somewhere. The questions being asked are: why was it put so close to the town and why is any risk at all being allowed to occur without pre-research? Only after the pilot program is completed will DERM be looking at the information and the data. People are asking why, with a new technology, was there not a lot more research done by the government to ensure that there is no detriment to the people.

We are talking about safety in this bill, but what about the safety of the people. There are all these questions and people just want answers. I have spoken with Minister Kate Jones about this and she is going to find out a lot of information for me. I am very grateful to her, as is the community. Once concerns were raised she acted very quickly to get DERM personnel to the area. When there is new technology why is there not a lot more thought put into it by government? Why was a lot more certainty not asked for? The government says that we have a lot of rules for mining. Open cut mines have been going on for many years in this country and there are many successful mines, but find me one UCG program that passed the pilot and is good and safe and can guarantee people that they will not be affected.

Another issue with regard to this relatively new technology is that the company, a small company, has a cap of $600,000 if any damage is caused. I look at things differently and I think to myself that if they do not think there will be any damage why would they need a cap. They must expect some sort of damage down the track to have a cap. The amount of $600,000 would not cover one property if it was damaged. We are asking who will pick up the rest of the tab if anything goes wrong with this new technology.

I have to say that the majority of the people in the area think this is great technology if it reduces greenhouse gases, it is great technology if it works well and can be proven to work well, and they would not be averse to it going ahead with assurances that it will not be detrimental to our particular area. On the other hand, if they are not convinced that it will be beneficial to the area and will do no damage they will fight it tooth and nail because, as I said, the community has been so sensitised to mining in our area that it will take a lot to satisfy it.

Whenever there is new technology the government needs to ensure the safety of the people--not only the workers who work there but also the people who live there. It needs to ensure that there are no contaminants and there will be no impact on the farming community in any way, shape or form. The other good thing about this technology is that it does not disturb the topsoil like open cut mining. It has a lot going for it. People just need to be sure it will do no damage.

I do support this legislation. I will not go into the other things that people have talked about. The issues I have raised are particularly relevant to my area and the concerns of the people of my area. When ventures are relatively new and have not been carried out before in Australia, perhaps a lot more has to be done to ensure that no damage is done before any licences are issued to a company. It is a bit like buying a bull, putting it in a fenced paddock with only four wires in it and saying, ‘Well, if he gets out we will put two more wires on the fence and make it a bit higher’. It is a bit late when the cows are pregnant to the wrong bull. That is the kind of analogy that people in our area use.
Ms Grace interjected.
Mrs PRATT: It might be a nice bull but that is not important.
Mr Seeney: I don’t think they understood that. The member for Brisbane Central is totally confused.

Mrs PRATT: They all know about the birds and the bees, I am sure, so I do not need to go into graphics. The truth is that there a lot of concerns when one lives in the country. The quality of the land is important. The value of the land does drop when mines come into an area. People worry about being able to sell their properties. It is a real issue for people on the land. It should not be pooh-poohed and thought that it is not a big issue because there are not that many people out there. As other members have said, these are the people who put the food on our table. They need a lot more consideration. As is often said, every family needs a farmer. At the rate we are going there will not be one farmer for every family, a whole city will get one farmer. We must value the assets we have. We have to be 99 per cent sure that nothing will happen. For some people 100 per cent sure would not be enough.

I will be supporting this bill. I have those reservations and I ask the minister to seriously think about requiring a lot more information to be given when new technology comes in before permission is given for the pilot to go ahead.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP)
(12.00 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. This bill before the House is the next step in the Bligh government’s commitment to develop an environmentally sustainable and economically prosperous LNG industry in Queensland.

After the Premier announced the world’s biggest liquefied natural gas contract for Queensland on 24 March, we saw nothing but the usual negative banter from the opposition. The most insightful comment the LNP spokesperson for mining could muster up was a suggestion that the government played absolutely no part in securing the contract worth $60 billion in export activity for Queensland. Of course he would say that. This could not be further from the truth. I take the opportunity to highlight some of the innovative ideas and forward thinking from the state government to promote Queensland as an environment which encourages and creates business investment.

We are on the front foot, building strong foundations for the industry and clear guidelines for investors to secure the validity of the sector in the future and achieve the balance between economic prosperity and environmental sustainability in the emerging CSG and LNG industry. In September 2009, the Bligh government released its blueprint for Queensland’s LNG industry which included a number of commitments in relation to environmental and natural resources management. The LNG blueprint is the basis of the Queensland government’s policy platform and aims to provide investor certainty and guidelines for environmental impact assessment processes.

The blueprint included a commitment to the current flat royalty rate of 10 per cent of wellhead value. This will provide a clear and stable royalty regime that will support and encourage investment in the LNG projects. To provide further investor certainty we will allow certain components of this wellhead valuation to be determined prospectively where necessary. This will be particularly important in ensuring that royalties are calculated correctly for LNG projects, which are often characterised by high degrees of vertical integration or joint venture arrangements.

In terms of managing environmental impacts and in keeping with the government’s blueprint, the government engaged with the CSG industry through the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association water working group to develop trigger thresholds for impacts on private water bores affected by CSG water extraction. We also led development of a cumulative management regime for groundwater impacts where the Queensland Water Commission will be the agency responsible for modelling, groundwater management and government reporting where CSG operators’ impacts overlap. We also developed industry guidelines which outline for industry the information needed in an environmental management plan for CSG activities under the EPA.

The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to amend various acts administered by the mines and energy portfolio to achieve three key outcomes for Queensland and build on the strong foundation set by the abovementioned initiatives. It will simplify the regulatory process to achieve savings for business and government. It will improve safety and health measures--which is of utmost importance to this government--in Queensland mining, explosives and gas industries. It will also improve electricity retailer credit support arrangements and customer service obligations.

The first point is in line with the Bligh government’s moves to create an environment which encourages and creates investment in the emerging Queensland LNG sector. The amendments will improve efficiency of regulatory and other approvals processes for mining projects while maintaining a balance with strict environmental and land use approvals. A new industry means that new checks and balances are necessary, and these amendments are part of the Bligh government’s response.

Amendments to the Mineral Resources Act 1989 will streamline the processing and assessment of mining lease applications by removing the current requirement for the Land Court to hear mining lease applications where no objections have been lodged. The applications will instead be assessed by the minister administering the act, thereby cutting red tape and reducing the waiting time by up to six weeks.

This bill will also make amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1992. Currently this act applies to the state’s internal waters as well as its territorial waters. Queensland’s internal waters are the waters between the mean low water mark and the territorial waters, which covers the area three nautical miles seaward from the territorial sea baseline. Because of the interaction between the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1982, companies wishing to construct pipelines between Queensland and the islands located within Queensland’s internal waters would currently be required to apply for and obtain pipeline licences under both the PG(PS) Act as well as the P(SL)A Act. This would also mean that companies intending to do this would be subject to two safety and health regulatory regimes.

The proposed amendments to these two acts are intended to simplify the approvals process for pipelines that traverse both the mainland and Queensland’s internal waters. This means that pipeline proponents will only need to comply with the safety and health obligations under one act, that being the PG(PS) Act. This dovetails with the goal of streamlining the approvals project by lessening the administrative and regulatory burden on the proponents and thereby encouraging resource investment in Queensland.

This is an exciting time for Queensland. I can remember that some four years I joined the Speaker, the then the Minister for Trade, on a trip to PNG to investigate the possibility of a major gas pipeline from the highlands of PNG all the way to Queensland and then to South Australia. Four years ago as a state we had a desperate need to find new resources to support the growing economy of our state. Four years later, today not only do we not need to import gas from other countries but we are becoming an exporter of gas in our own right. This emerging CSG and LNG sector has the potential for huge economic and social development in Queensland by creating thousands of new jobs and adding tens of billions of dollars to our economy.

Foresight and leadership from the Bligh government have allowed us to get on the front foot and lay the foundations for this growing industry, and this bill is a continuation of that work. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (12.06 pm): I am happy to give this contribution to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, and I certainly offer my support to the bill. Many facets of these amendments attempt to enhance Queensland’s position and provide the mining and energy industries, and the personnel who are involved, with increased certainty into the future. Mines and energy related industries have been the backbone of the Queensland economy for many decades. There is a reliance by the industry on government to get the right balance of legislation to ensure that these reserves are utilised in an environmentally responsible manner, a sustainable manner and a very safe manner.

There is also a very great need for legislation to keep pace with emerging industries. Currently we see that those emerging industries are in the sustainability and the technological sectors, and in recent years those emerging industries have included clean coal, solar energy, wind, geothermal and hydroelectric energy. This government is beholden to legislate in keeping with the prudent advancement of industry, and these amendments before us that we are discussing today are certainly an attempt to reflect this.

Streamlining of the mining lease application process is to be welcomed. This will occur by removing the current requirement for the Land Court to hear mining lease applications where there are no objections. The time, effort and frustration involved in carrying out a process for the sake of it have no place in today’s government and the business area. I have no doubt that this will be an improvement in the process. To simplify and clarify the compliance requirements under the Clean Energy Act will address some of the shortfalls encountered in the original legislation that related to the Smart Energy Savings Program. This applied to medium and large businesses.

In relation to the clean energy and smart energy areas, I would like to make members of the House aware of the very tangible potential for this resource in North Queensland. In my area, there is already a co-generation site at Pioneer Mill that feeds electricity back into the grid. I also understand that Stanwell and SunWater will once again be investigating a proposed 30 megawatt hydro power station at the Burdekin Falls Dam. As most members in the House are aware, the Burdekin Falls Dam is the largest in Queensland and has an enviable reliability with regard to storage holding compared to some of the more southern storages.

The development of hydro-electricity is a key driver of the Queensland government’s Renewable Energy Plan. That plan aims to have 2,500 megawatts of renewable energy installed by 2020. I would suggest though, from the perspective of the Burdekin Dam, that raising the dam wall would significantly increase the potential of this hydro-electricity generation.

In addition to this, a report has been commissioned by MITEZ, the Mount Isa to Townsville Economic Development Zone, with the input and support of Townsville Enterprise, the local councils that link this corridor and the Queensland Resources Council, titled Future Development of Queensland’s Carpentaria Minerals Province : Developing a Resources Corridor--Clean Energy and Minerals . This report was released last month. It has special relevance to this section of the amendments as it provides a tangible link to the future clean energy potential to North Queensland in particular. This document is strategic in nature and shows the potential for this project to be harnessed for the benefit of North Queensland and also naturally for Queensland as a whole.

The energy potential derived from this would complement the recent announcement that the Premier made during the Queensland Growth Summit in relation to growth in regional Queensland, and Townsville in particular. Townsville is being groomed to play a very large part of that plan. Infrastructure planning is a large element of this, and electricity provision to act as a catalyst for sustained growth is paramount.

I would like to share some of the salient points from that report with members of the House. The renewable energy projects would provide economic opportunities for the towns along the clean energy corridor between Townsville and Mount Isa. As many members are aware, it is a long distance and it is very sparsely populated, and some of those towns and communities along that corridor are really struggling. Small mines that have got the capacity to start along that area would be able to access electricity at a lower cost than through their own diesel or gas-fired generation, and that of course would encourage more investment into the north-west minerals province.

The co-location of sites suitable for large scale solar, wind and geothermal generation with a grid connection avoids the problem of remoteness associated with many potential renewable sites in inland Australia. Once enabled through a transmission line, this clean energy corridor would provide a significant contribution to the Commonwealth government’s renewable energy target and of course the state government’s emissions reduction target as well.

A transmission line to North Queensland would traverse the northern Galilee Basin, dramatically improving the economics of establishing a baseload power station around Pentland. There has been quite a lot of talk about the establishment of a potential baseload power station there.

Three renewable energy projects positioned along the route of the proposed AC transmission line were presented at the North Queensland renewable energy roundtable forum in November last year. I will share with the House those projects that were at that roundtable: Windlab Systems Pty Ltd’s proposal for a 600-megawatt wind farm at Hughenden; Australian PhytoFuel Company’s proposal for producing biodiesel feedstock and using the waste biomass to generate power around Hughenden and Julia Creek; and Samsung’s presentation of a solar/biomass project at Pentland. All three projects would require the AC transmission, so this would require the transmission line from Mount Isa to Townsville to access the electricity grid. The location of these projects is too far from either the proposed HVDC line to Central Queensland or the existing grid in North Queensland to make connection at these points economically feasible.

By 2015-16, there is a potential for up to 900 megawatts of installed renewable capacity to be connected to the grid through the AC transmission line. So 300 megawatts of this installed capacity would be baseload power, biomass and solar thermal with a further 600 megawatts coming from wind power. Adjusting for the low factors for solar and wind power, potential renewable generation of around 400 megawatts could be available by 2015-16, which I understand would be equivalent to the projected demand of the north-west minerals province.

But of course here again we have the chicken and egg problem for the clean energy corridor. The renewable energy projects, along with the clean energy corridor, cannot proceed without a transmission line. However, the cost competitiveness of a transmission line to Townsville depends on there being sufficient generation in North Queensland to offset the additional load in the north-west. There is a risk that the major users will dismiss the option of a transmission line traversing the clean energy corridor on account of it not being the initial lowest cost option. However, by the end of the decade, North Queensland could be a net exporter of renewable energy to Central Queensland, and this would be a major positive for North Queensland.

There is a major opportunity currently for North Queensland’s major energy users, not only to secure reliable competitive energy for future use but also to foster development in both the north-west minerals province and along the proposed clean energy corridor. For the clean energy corridor to proceed, the proposed renewable energy sites would have to be connected to the electricity grid, and only the AC transmission line to North Queensland would be able to connect the majority of the renewable sites currently under investigation and have the additional benefits of providing development opportunities for the towns along the corridor, and of course enabling the smaller mining operations to access the affordable grid electricity.

Returning to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill, I note the implementation of the two recommendations from Brokering Balance: A Public Interest Map for Queensland Government Bodies , the Weller review. The findings of that review are supported within this legislation. The Weller review recommended the current Coal Mining Safety and Health Advisory Council and the Mine Safety and Health Advisory Council be retained and renamed as committees. It is actually a very broad review. The public interest map was actually applied to 459 government bodies that were within the scope of the review, and these were just two of those government bodies.

Other bodies that came within the scope of that public interest map were the category 2 water boards. Two of those were the north and south Burdekin water boards. On the advice of the public interest map, category 2 water boards should be abolished and their responsibilities transferred to local government jurisdiction.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! Could the member just explain to me how this is relevant to the bill that is currently before the House?

Mrs MENKENS: Yes, I would be very happy to do that. It refers to part 3 clauses 17 to 34 within the bill that refer to changes as recommended in the Weller review. I guess I am just enlarging on some of the broader areas of the Weller review.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Rather than enlarging on the Weller review, perhaps you could talk specifically to the provisions of the bill that is currently before the House.
Mr Seeney: The Weller review is in the legislation. Come on!
Mrs MENKENS: Yes, the Weller review--
Government members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The member for Burdekin has the call for the moment.

Mrs MENKENS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As we know, the Weller review does apply to a large number of category 2 water boards which do use a great deal of electricity and are definitely involved with the electricity business. I see that the minister does not agree with me on this particular case.

Mr Robertson:
You’ve got that right.

Mrs MENKENS: Well, there we go. However, they are a very important part of the Burdekin district, and it is very disappointing to see the changes being brought about to the water boards as a result of the Weller review.

The section of the legislation which results from the Weller review relates to the enhancement of safety and health measures in Queensland’s mining, explosives and gas industries--which is perhaps the area that you would prefer me to talk about, Mr Deputy Speaker--and it is one of major importance. Requiring smaller mines to now implement the development and maintenance of a safety and health management system will come at some financial impost, but the safety of all mine ventures, whether large or small, is definitely to be supported.

The mining industry is one of major importance in Queensland, and the importance of it must never be underestimated. In my electorate of Burdekin it is an essential industry. It is an essential industry that creates major employment. From the perspective of smaller mining ventures, Conquest Mining is poised to begin mining its gold, silver and copper deposits. This mine is situated behind the township of Gumlu. I know there are many people in the area poised for the commencement of that mine because they are aware that it is going to generate potentially quite a lot of employment.

Gold was historically mined at Mount Coolum earlier last century with a very colourful history as well. There are certainly gold and mineral deposits that still create various levels of interest. Stringent legislation, albeit often necessary, puts significant imposts on smaller mining companies, but the safety of all personnel is paramount.

Coalmining, of course, centres around Collinsville and it has done for many years. The original Xstrata mine and the newer QCoal mine are there. It is very exciting that Drake Coal, which is a subsidiary of QCoal, is set to open a second mine in Collinsville. In the electorate we also have the Xstrata mine at Newlands. When it comes to workplace health and safety, the mining industry in the Burdekin area is no stranger to mining fatalities. Very sadly, Collinsville was the scene of a mining tragedy in 1954 when seven miners perished in an outburst of gas in the underground mine. This was a huge tragedy. Most of the families of those men are still living in the town and mourn their loss.

As the ambitious plans of Waratah Coal and Hancock Prospecting in the Galilee Basin work toward fruition, safety is a present-day necessity. These mines will require massive rail infrastructure to move this coal to Abbot Point, where an equally major upgrade will be required to meet the increased demand for stockpiling prior to a very buoyant export shipping demand. Amendments in this legislation affecting the gas industry include changes to the certification of gas devices to provide national consistency. In the last decade it would be fair to say that technology has gone ahead in leaps and bounds when it comes to extracting gas from the earth. Australia and Queensland are leading that charge.

Those people who were able to attend the briefing by Carbon Energy yesterday on underground coal gasification would no doubt have been as impressed as I was to learn so much about that process. It is exciting times in gas extraction when we see what is happening, particularly with the extraction of coal seam gas and the UCG process. The environmental implications of this form of energy production are certainly at the forefront.

Associated with gas is the allied piping of the gas and the associated industries that can be and are being developed as a result of that. The approvals process for pipelines that traverse both the mainland and Queensland’s internal waters ensure pipeline proponents only need to comply with the safety and health obligations under the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004. This amendment is intended to make a significant reduction in unnecessary regulatory burden. It is to be hoped that this really does achieve its purpose.

There is also an amendment to improve electricity retailer credit support arrangements and customer service obligations. This amendment is supported as there has been a history of customers negatively affected from regional areas. It is to be hoped that there will be very positive outcomes from this particular amendment.

The legislation encompasses a raft of amendments. As the shadow minister has outlined, the opposition will be supporting this legislation. The mining industry is a very important industry for Queensland. It is also important that we acknowledge the efforts that companies within the mining industry are making to make their workplaces safer, healthier and more environmentally friendly areas.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (12.26 pm): I rise to speak to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. In addressing this legislation I acknowledge, as other speakers have, that mining, in particular, is a major generator of jobs, of income and of royalties to this government. It is an important player in the financial stability of the state.

On the converse side of that, there is also a need to recognise that mining impacts on landowners and the right of landowners to retain security of their rural pursuits. Where that security or the tenure of their land has to be taken from them, adequate compensation needs to be given to them in recognition not only of the rural value of the property but also of the loss of income and displacement that is caused.

This bill is proposed to enhance safety and health measures, and that is always welcome.
