I think it was the Queensland government that ran a series of ads on and off at various times about workers returning home to their families safely. I think it is an important message. It is one that can be validly reinforced in all workplaces. With mining, in particular, there are areas of high risk. The enhancement of workplace health and safety measures in particularly high-risk work sites is critically important.

The second tenet to this bill is to streamline and simplify government processes. It is probably in this area that I wish to speak in more detail. As I said, there has to be a balance in streamlining the process. There has to be a balance between recognising the investment of mining companies that invest significantly in preliminary investigation and in mining as a result of investment decisions and the rights and freedoms of landowners who are impacted. Invariably, mining--whether it is coal or gas mining--will impact on landowners.

The member for Capalaba talked about LNG and royalties. In my electorate, there are many people who are very welcoming of LNG as an industry and the jobs that will be created in both construction and in operation but there are also those who are concerned about the placement of LNG on Curtis Island, which is a greenfield site. Their concerns are valid and need to be listened to. There are also landowners affected by the pipeline process. I have had several landowners very concerned about the process come to my office. Previous speakers have mentioned--and I am sure the minister will too--the responsible attitude of mining companies in relation to their obligations to the government and to the community. Overwhelmingly, I would say that that is true. That is a statement that is made by all companies.

The reality is, however, that landowners do not have to deal with the company but with the individuals. Those individuals can be company representatives and they can be government department representatives. Depending on the attitude and manner of those representatives, the dealings of landowners with the government and with the companies can be either productive and positive or absolutely hellish. There have been instances--and, sadly, more than I would have cared to occur--where landowners in my electorate have been dealt with very poorly.

This bill intends to simplify the approval process for petroleum and gas pipelines that traverse both the mainland and Queensland’s internal waters and ensure pipeline proponents need to comply with the safety and health obligations under only one act. It also deals with the approval process in relation to the mandatory requirement for the Land Court to assess mining lease applications.

We have been dealing with the concerns of a constituent of mine, Mr Jim Reynolds, through the department. His current concern relates to access--that is, the ability of the company and government representatives to access properties without the permission of the property owner. This matter relates to the LNG pipeline. Jim told my office that an excavator went through Des Dingle’s place--that is another landowner--and through his land on a Saturday. Jim said that he came home from work on Saturday evening and the excavator was in his front yard. The company, in this instance Santos, organised for the excavator to go through the land. Jim rang Santos and complained and also contacted the Mount Larcom police because he was pretty irritated by all this. There was talk of charging the owner of the business that operated the excavator with trespassing.

There is another story to all of this that does not relate to this bill. The incident highlights the fact that landowners are significantly disadvantaged. There are access obligations, notification obligations and procedures under the mines and energy legislation that should be adhered to. Very often in reality those processes are not adhered to and the loser in the end is the landowner.

This bill is proposing to remove the mandatory requirement for the Land Court to assess mining lease applications where there are ‘no properly lodged objections’. Where there are no objections at all I have no problem with the Land Court process being dispensed with. I do have some concerns--and I would seek the minister’s response on this--about the statement ‘no properly lodged objections’. That phrase could be applied pedantically.

When landowners lodge objections they usually lodge them with the best intentions. If one wanted to be pedantic or if one wanted to be difficult, some objections made with the best of intentions on the part of the landowners could be ruled to be ‘not properly lodged’ because maybe they were on the wrong form or the wording was incorrect. It could be an unintentional error on the part of the landowner or an error that was not vexatious. Or a lack of experience may have caused that objection to be not properly lodged. I seek from the minister a comment about specifically how the department and the Land Court will look at these objections and whether genuinely made objections will be ruled out of order because technically they were not properly lodged. The landowner should have the right to make an objection and have minor errors accepted as human error.

My fundamental concern is for those people who are suddenly impacted by mining projects. Even though there are a lot of landowners in my electorate who have been affected by mining projects, there will sometimes be new landowners who are affected and for them it is a whole new process and a whole new dilemma.

In relation to pipelines, there are issues in my electorate--and my electorate is not unique; there would be issues when it comes to the pipeline coming up from the Surat--that need to be carefully monitored. Issues around pipelines are ones that rural property owners bring up all the time. I am sure that for some people and even some councils this is an old chestnut that they would rather not deal with. Most councils are very responsible and the government needs to be, too, and not just pay lip-service to things like weed control and the protection of waters. People who have what has historically been a spring fed dam or a water supply on their property may not have the engineering but they know anecdotally that that water has not failed in long, protracted dry spells. They have to fight tooth and nail to keep government departments from approving gas line corridors through waters that have historically been reliable for stock and domestic use. These are the practical problems that landowners face.

In reality, an objection can be funded by the department but not an appeal. If somebody feels that their objection has not been properly heard--I am not talking about legally--or that certain matters have not been given enough weight and they want to appeal that objection, they actually have to pay for the appeal process themselves. Often that means that they are not legally represented. I believe that funding should be there for reasonable appeals as it is there for reasonable legal costs.

I do have concerns about the need to retain Land Court oversight of any mining leases that have objections, whether they are properly made or not. I understand that there would be times when individuals, but more particularly entities, would put in vexatious objections. We have seen that with legislation that has been brought before the House. Large companies can afford to be litigious over a long period. Most rural landowners cannot afford to be unnecessarily litigious. They have to get on and try to make a living and survive.

I am concerned that landowners at all times are treated properly and with respect and that their concerns are properly dealt with and not dismissed out of hand. I am also concerned that the streamlined process will not in any way disadvantage landowners who have usually invested a great deal of time, effort and soul into their properties and at times feel that they are treated very shabbily.

In relation to the issues around electricity retailers and improved customer service obligations, people in my electorate are very concerned about the increasing cost of energy. I believe that we as a legislative body have to take care to protect the ability of all Queenslanders to access affordable energy. I look forward to hearing the minister’s comments.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (12.39 pm): I rise to support the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I find it amazing that while the opposition supports this bill it still finds a lot to criticise. As the chair of the Environment and Resources Committee I was concerned about the level of criticism regarding my committee’s first report into energy efficiency tabled in parliament on 25 February this year. I find it typical of the opposition to say one thing and do the opposite.

The committee is a bipartisan committee and its report was supported unanimously. That means that even members of the opposition voted for it in its entirety. However, they still included--at the last minute--a dissenting report which, quite frankly, was dismal. In fact, their first recommendation was very similar to the one in the report. It appears that they either did not read the report in its entirety or did not understand it fully. The opposition spokesman, the member for Callide--and I acknowledge his presence in the chamber--was also very critical last night of government agencies like the Office of Clean Energy and the Office of Climate Change. Of course he would be, because the opposition does not believe in climate change and therefore does not think we have to do anything about our energy usage and, more importantly, our wastage of it. Those opposite sit on their hands oblivious to what is going on around them. However, I want to place on record my thanks to all agencies involved in assisting the committee with information that helped us finalise our report. I also appreciate the input from members on the committee, particularly the members from the government side and the member for Maryborough, who did see the real value in the committee’s work. Yes, we are all very keen to hear from government in the near future about the recommendations that are in the report, and I hope that the government will take our recommendations on board and adopt them.

As I stated earlier, I am pleased to support this bill introduced into the House by the Minister for Mines and Energy, the Hon. Stephen Robertson, earlier this year. It assists in streamlining and simplifying those processes about savings, not only for the government but for business as well. It also addresses improvements to credit support arrangements for electricity retailers, resulting in improved services for electricity consumers. This bill amends a number of acts, including the Clean Energy Act 2008, and provides enhancements to safety and health measures in the state’s mining, explosives and gas industries, and I wish to concentrate my remarks on these enhancements. Mine safety is paramount. We have seen the devastating effect mine incidents have on workers, their families and fellow workers, and there have been several disasters televised just recently. Every mine, whether underground or open cut, must be safe to all workers in and around the mine site. Our mine safety in this country must be the envy of other countries. Queensland is leading the way in Australia with regard to mine safety but, as we all know, there is always more we can do.

The 2008-09 Queensland mines and quarries safety performance report statistics reveal that deaths in mines have been greatly reduced but there were still four deaths during that time. The bill’s reform ensures that the health and safety management system which currently applies to mines with more than 10 employees will now apply to those small mines with less than 10 employees, and I welcome this change. It is only fair that miners have the best protection irrespective of the size of the mine workforce. The government is not only implementing these changes; it is assisting those mines in implementing their safety obligations. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--LNP) (12.42 pm): The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 amends a number of acts, as we have heard from other members this morning. It amends 11 acts in total, and I will not run through them. However, I want to address one of the key areas of this bill--that is, the safety and health measures of Queensland’s mining, explosives and gas industry, and this bill aims to enhance those safety and health measures in small mines. The minister in his second reading speech said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A 2006-07 Queensland Mines Inspectorate review into metalliferous mine and quarry fatalities over the previous 10 years found there was a decrease in the number of fatalities at large mines but an increase trend in fatalities in small mines.
XML.Hansard-Body: We are worried about that, and I want to take the opportunity to commend the mining industry on its health and safety work. There are many people in the Burnett electorate who work in the larger mines to the north and to the west of the Burnett, and those mines produce a lot of wealth for our community. In speaking with the mums and dads who work at those mines, they tell me about their world-class occupational health and safety standards. They have very stringent records and safety mechanisms such as drug testing and occupational health and safety tests. I was told by one gentleman that if they do not use the hand holes on a dragline as they ascend and descend the draglines they can be sacked--they can be put off just for that breach of that occupational health and safety record--and that is appropriate. They know that if they break the laws in the mining sites then they are liable to be kicked off the site. Those high standards should be copied in other industries as well.
Mr Robertson: Like parliament?
Mr MESSENGER: I take the minister’s interjection. Maybe we should have those high standards.
Mr Robertson: If you break the laws you should be sacked?

Mr MESSENGER: In the mining industry we always talk about life and death issues, and there are many of us here in this parliament, especially on this side of the parliament, who talk about saving lives and life and death issues, and the lives of small children are very, very important to those on this side of the parliament.

In bringing smaller mines with 10 or fewer workers into line with larger mine safety and health systems under the Mining and Quarrying Safety and Health Act 1999, the existing laws have not addressed small mines’ safety operations and therefore have not required them to actually maintain safety and health management systems whereas the larger mines have had to maintain these systems for the past nine years. There is a community in my electorate that is very interested in mining and specifically quarry safety. There is a proposition for a quarry at South Innes Park. Holcim Australia Pty Ltd is preparing a development application to open a new quarry to be located in the Burnett at the corner of Elliott Heads Road and Barolin Homestead Road. It is anticipated that this quarry would produce 350,000 tonnes per annum and have an estimated life as a mine of 20 to 30 years. An increase in traffic from trucks is estimated to be between 70 to 90 trucks per day along Elliott Heads Road. That is 140 to 180 trucks each way per day.

I have received overwhelming and significant opposition towards this new quarry from the residents of the region. In fact, one community survey found that 95 per cent rejected the proposal. Members of this community stress that they are not against progress. We must have mines and quarries to increase the wealth of our community and of our state. However, they are against putting this quarry in suburbia, which is where this quarry will be located. This quarry will be located, as the crow flies, about two kilometres from the coastline and a marine park. So there are significant environmental concerns as well. One of the other major concerns relates to the council. If the quarry is approved and it goes through the development process with the council approving it, there are then overriding departmental officers and different regulations applying to this quarry. The council may put in place a development exclusion zone around this quarry. That development exclusion zone is up to the discretion of the council. It can be anywhere between 200 metres and 1,000 metres, or a kilometre, from the site. That exclusion zone from this quarry will have a massive impact on landowners and residents of Innes Park. The exclusion zone could stop housing development and could therefore limit economic development for the next 20 to 30 years in an area that is significantly residential. The exclusion zone will immediately and significantly devalue land without the chances of compensation.

As we heard earlier, with the addition of a quarry in a suburban area, there will be damage to roads, creating unsafe conditions, and major intersection upgrades will be needed. There are also concerns around air pollution, dust and noise created by the quarry and the trucks. There is already dust and noise from the existing quarry in the Burnett, and another quarry would create more noise and dust and more respiratory problems caused by that dust. There are also other environmental concerns. There is the problem of waste products going into the estuaries and the ocean and the quality of the water in rainwater tanks. The coastal areas are pristine and my residents say that these areas are not the place for quarries.

There is also the problem after the quarry has exhausted its life. There are massive scars left behind on the landscape after a quarry has been closed. There is the problem with blasting that occurs in quarries and the digging. There are concerns about further development of an existing quarry. If the area is allowed to be changed, it could hinder the ability to move stormwater away from a place at Innes Park called Reid Crescent in an estate on Back Windermere Road. There is also possible damage to underground water supply that has to be considered. It would then threaten farm sustainability. These are all issues that must be taken into account.

My call today in this place is for the company proposing this quarry, Holcim, to genuinely listen to the community, find a win-win situation and relocate its proposed quarry to one of the other six sites, which are located within 100 kilometres of Bundaberg, but so far the company has refused to divulge the details of their location. I will be meeting with the company this weekend at a community meeting and I look forward to talking it through and finding a win-win situation for my community, which is situated in one of the best places in the world, and also for Holcim, because we both recognise and realise that the material that comes out of quarries is essential for building roads and, once again, for creating wealth. There are concerns, too, from workers of the existing quarry about their job security. Those workers do a great job in the quarry. Every day they risk life and limb so that we can have the quality of life that we now enjoy.

The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill also amends the Clean Energy Act and the Electricity Act. This morning--indeed, this week--we have heard from many ministers and the Premier about the government’s commitment to clean energy, specifically solar energy. I think every member of this place has a genuine commitment to clean energy. In relation to clean energy, I have a constituent who has highlighted to me a problem with the costs that he has incurred on upgrading to clean energy. I will write a letter to the minister about this issue on his behalf. I have been approached by Mr Bob Collinson of Childers seeking my assistance with regard to the charge by Ergon Energy for the removal of his load control unit owing to him changing to solar power--he wants to upgrade to solar. I am advised by Mr Craig Harris from Ergon Energy that the charge for the removal of the unit is currently $179.99. I am at a loss--and so is Mr Collinson and many of my other constituents--to understand why this charge is allowed. Previously, I have received complaints from constituents with regard to this issue and I now have concerns that those residents who are doing the commendable thing and saving energy by changing to solar power are being penalised by having imposed on them what I believe is a ridiculous charge. So now that the minister is here and is able to listen to these concerns directly, I would hope that he would make inquiries about this charge for those units.

Although the opposition and other members of this House support this legislation in a bipartisan way, the member for Pumicestone made a comment in her speech that I just cannot let pass without challenging it. The member for Pumicestone said that the opposition does not believe in climate change. From my perspective that is untrue. Of course there is climate change. Climate change happened 110,000 years ago, when the average world temperature increased by five degrees--from 14 degrees to 19 degrees. Of course, 110,000 years ago there were no man-made carbon emissions. So those on the other side of the House have failed to explain why there are those cyclical changes in climate. What we on this side do not believe is that by paying money to politicians in Canberra--$20 billion worth of tax--we can stop climate change. That is what we do not believe. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MALONE (Mirani--LNP) (12.54 pm): It is with pleasure that I rise to speak to the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. The shadow minister has spoken in depth on this bill. Certainly, it is wide-ranging and covers quite a considerable area of resource management legislation. I would like to raise a number of issues that relate to the legislation and the direction that it takes. I also want to talk a little bit about the progress of mining in my electorate and its surrounds.

Initially, I would like to refer to a win-win situation that can be achieved if the Mount Morgan process goes ahead whereby Norton gold holdings will move in and reprocess most of the slag that was left from the previous goldmining operation. I understand that currently the company is waiting for finance to enable it to do that. That would certainly be a huge step forward for the community of Mount Morgan, which has gone on to the backburner over the past 30 or 40 years since the mine closed down. It will be a huge opportunity for the young people of Mount Morgan to achieve gainful employment at the mine.

Norton gold holdings is talking about not only extracting the gold out of the slag pits but also generating sulphuric acid out of the pyrites, which is a big part of some of the ongoing environmental problems with the operations at Mount Morgan. If that can happen, it would certainly take away some of the risk that is currently inherent in the toxic dam at the original site of the Mount Morgan mine. So there is a real benefit from this proposed mining operation, particularly in terms of the financial liabilities of the Queensland government, if it indeed goes ahead. I would implore the minister and his department to be supportive of it and to look at all opportunities for this mining operation to go ahead.

In terms of the major ports at Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point and their possible expansion to Dudgeon Point, which is an approximately 600-acre land resource alongside that area, there are some environmental issues in terms of the people who live around the area. It is important that that environmental process is taken to the nth degree in terms of satisfying people’s concerns about dust and noise. As many people would realise, some years ago the Ports Corporation of Queensland had to virtually buy out the small community of Louisa Creek simply because of dust and noise issues. Of course, it is very obvious as we move forward and shipping increases through Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point that there are constraints on QR in its endeavours to move the coal down the coast. That is becoming more and more of an issue. Over many years there has been talk of a second access for QR down Connors Range. Quite frankly, I believe that until that second access is progressed, QR is always going to be a bottleneck in terms of moving increasing amounts of coal from the hinterland down to the coast.

As has been spoken about in the House earlier, we also have the development of the Galilee Basin and the proposal to have a standard gauge rail line from that area through to Abbot Point. That line will certainly have an impact through my area and other areas through to Abbot Point. There is also the possibility of having a spur line down to Dalrymple Bay. Under normal circumstances, standard gauge rail will carry almost double the amount of coal per train set as can be carried on narrow gauge rail. I think that, as we move forward with increasing amounts of coal, we should be thinking clearly about how we develop our rail network throughout Queensland. One of the big impacts--and other members have spoken about this issue--of coalmining in Queensland is the impact that it is has on small communities and the provision of housing.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Mr MALONE:
Before the lunch break I was speaking about the impacts of mining on smaller communities. I pointed out the cost of housing in some of the smaller communities. For instance, around Dysart where the Saraji mine operates, a four-bedroom house a little while ago was going for $1,800 a week. Even though there are mining camps in the area there are other people who live in the community who have to access accommodation as well. The Minister for Infrastructure has become aware of issues around Blackwater. There are some real issues in communities such as Middlemount, Dysart, even up in Glendon, where there are police officers, teachers and workers in the community who are finding it difficult to find affordable housing under those conditions. When the Minister for Housing stands up in this House and talks about affordable housing and the communities in which she is building it, maybe she needs to look at building affordable housing in areas that are covered by the mining industry.

One of the biggest impacts of mining throughout Queensland is in terms of infrastructure and roads. The old Bruce Highway from Sarina through to Marlborough was taken back to a state road. There are a number of single-lane bridges on that road. Currently as a result of the mining industry we are finding a lot of people using the old Bruce Highway to either go through to Rockhampton or come back from Mackay. I can assure members that those single-lane wooden bridges are very dangerous. The quality of the road is becoming pretty ordinary as well. There is a real issue with the state government lifting its game in terms of maintaining those state roads and hopefully improving the state roads that service the mining industry.

One of the issues that I am finding as I move around the electorate is the impact of corridors. I am particularly talking about the corridors that have been set aside from the Fitzroy River through to Gladstone for mainly water but quite a lot of other industries are looking at utilising the same corridor. There seems to be a real move to put those corridors through private land. I cannot for the life of me understand why they do not follow the corridors that are already set aside for roads et cetera. These are having major impacts on people’s lives. It is not just about the corridor going through and the disruption to their services or lifestyle; it also has an impact in terms of weed management and a whole lot of things that go along with that. It would seem so much simpler--to me, anyway--for those services, such as the proposal for a gas pipeline and a nickel slurry line coming through from Marlborough, to be legislated to enforce that those sorts of services should be run parallel to roads and be contained within the gazetted road corridor. There are many people living in those areas who would totally support that.

The legislation also makes changes in relation to the gas industry. I am a person who has played around with air conditioning and refrigeration a little bit--very much in an amateurish way. When fluorocarbons were banned because of the greenhouse gas effects, there was a push at that time to use hydrocarbons for the refrigerant. It is good to see that we are moving along those lines with this legislation. Although I have not consulted with refrigeration mechanics, hopefully it overcomes many of the problems that have been around for quite some time now. That is a step in the right direction.

In terms of renewable power, I heard the member for Burdekin talking about sugar mills in the Burdekin producing green power. Mackay Sugar has announced an upgrade of its boiler. I will quote some of the facts in relation to that upgrade--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Cogeneration Project at Mackay Sugar’s Racecourse mill involves:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • the construction of an efficient high pressure boiler on the Racecourse mill site to replace the existing No. 1 Boiler. The boiler has been designed for firing on Bagasse, coal and a combination of both Bagasse and coal; and

• an STG designed to supply steam and electricity to the mill and the adjacent refinery and electricity to the North Queensland grid. The anticipated average output of the generator is approximately 36kW.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Cogeneration Project is being managed by Mackay Sugar with the cogeneration plant delivered under the EPC Contract and other major associated works will be delivered under separate contracts.

The Cogeneration plant will be fuelled by Bagasse during the crushing season and for part of the non-crushing season. In a normal year there will be surplus of Bagasse at Racecourse mill and additional tonnage of Bagasse which can be trucked from Mackay Sugar’s other mills. It is expected that there will be sufficient Bagasse stored at the end of the crushing season to operate the cogeneration facility for approximately three months after the end of the crushing season.

When the Bagasse supplies have been deleted, the boiler will then be fuelled by coal. Coal is currently purchased from Blair Athol Coal Pty Ltd and Mackay Sugar is extending this contract to receive coal from Blair Athol Coal Pty Ltd’s new Clermont mine in the future.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a real step forward and cements again the green credentials of the sugar industry on top of the trash blanketing system that it has in place. It has been interesting to be in the parliament in the last couple of days while the state government has made much of its solar power project. We all believe that solar power is a step forward. The interesting claim that it will save the building of one power generator in Queensland I think is a bit over-the-top. The fact of the matter is that solar power is a great source of green energy but at the end of the day when the lights go out and the sun goes down there has to be a back-up power source. The bulk power source that we currently have is mostly coal fired. Right through Europe there is a reliance on solar power and wind generation and it does not go well in the middle of winter when there is no sun and very little wind. I would be a little cautious in the claims that are being made by this government in terms of its solar power projects. With those few words I support the bill.

XML.Hansard-Body: Reviews of the Local Government Act 1993 and the City of Brisbane Act 1924 were initiated when I was the minister for local government in 2006. So it is with pleasure that I inform the House the new Local Government Act 2009 received assent on 12 June 2009 and will commence on 1 July 2010. Today I introduce a bill for the City of Brisbane to parliament. Both these new statutes provide for contemporary governance for the councils of Queensland.

The new City of Brisbane Bill 2010 is the result of hard work by officers of the department’s Local Government Services and Brisbane City Council. Through this hard work I believe we have got the balance right between Brisbane City Council as Queensland’s largest local government and Brisbane City Council as a major corporation providing infrastructure and services for over one million people. This bill will strengthen and support the council and provide it with greater capacity and flexibility to serve the people of Brisbane.

The current City of Brisbane Act is 86 years old, so it is clearly out of date for a progressive and fast-growing city in 2010, especially one that seeks to be Australia’s new-world city. Though Brisbane was proclaimed a municipality on 6 September 1859, Brisbane owes its status as Queensland’s capital city to custom rather than statutory authority. This bill gives formal legislative acknowledgement to Brisbane as our Queensland capital, appropriately so as it is the largest local government in Australia and so warrants this stand-alone legislation.

Though modelled on the Local Government Act 2009, this bill also contains updated provisions from the old City of Brisbane Act which are unique to Brisbane City Council, such as the City Botanic Gardens and Brisbane River crossings. Important provisions in the Local Government Act 2009 that will also apply to the Brisbane City Council in the bill include a principles based approach, a chief executive officer with defined responsibilities, and requirements for long-term financial planning and reporting. The principles based approach gives Brisbane the flexibility to develop its own policies, operational procedures and processes, and it also makes the new legislation more user-friendly for council practitioners, residents and ratepayers.

Brisbane ratepayers today rightly expect high standards from their elected representatives. From time to time, Brisbane residents want to understand how council processes work and they also want to know who is accountable. As a result, the bill before the House today clarifies the responsibilities of the mayor, councillors and the chief executive officer. The existing 1924 act was written for its time. Brisbane is now a totally different city.

Where powers and responsibilities of the mayor and councillors were once poorly defined, they have now been spelled out and strengthened. The mayor’s responsibilities include leading and controlling the business of council, preparing and presenting the budget for adoption, managing the strategic direction of the council and, with the chief executive officer, achieving a modern, responsive and sustainable administration. Importantly, the City of Brisbane Bill 2010 supports the wider community’s expectation that its elected representatives will look after the interests of all residents in an open and transparent manner.

To ensure a continuation of the highest standard of transparency and accountability by councillors, the bill retains provisions and serious penalties relating to the misuse of information to cause detriment to the council. Detriment here is not about political embarrassment, or disagreements between councillors; neither is it about matters that are and should be in the public domain. It is right that there is public debate about the positives and negatives of council’s projects, plans and policies. This is in the public interest and this will not trigger the misuse of information provisions.

To cause detriment to the council has been clearly defined in the bill to include: to sabotage a lawful process of the council, including adopting a budget or conducting a tender process, for example, or; to cause the council to suffer a loss in its lawful performance of a function or commercial activity, including the loss of a future contractual arrangement, for example. I am advised that Brisbane city councillors are currently able to view commercial-in-confidence material such as tenders and contracts. This is continued in the new bill.

Apart from senior executives, the chief executive officer is responsible for appointing council staff and can direct and take disciplinary action against workers. When and what type of disciplinary action may be taken will be prescribed by regulation. A regulation will also cover employee discipline appeals.

The Department of Infrastructure and Planning will continue to work closely with stakeholders to develop a regulation that protects the rights of council employees whilst recognising the needs of the council. The bill recognises the importance of councillors being able to access council information relating to their own ward and supports councillors in their representation of constituents. This bill makes it clear that councillors have rights to access information. However, with those rights come responsibilities about the use of this information.

By empowering the chief executive officer to decide what requests for information and advice are reasonable, councillor access to information has been balanced with the need to ensure the administration is not overly burdened and confidential information is not released. Acceptable request guidelines will be adopted by the council to support this.

Following a request from the Lord Mayor, Brisbane City Council will be exempted from requirements under the Right to Information Act 2009 for documents created in the course of local government budget deliberations. During the budget process, council considers a range of options and possible projects as they work towards reaching a balance between income--with its impacts on ratepayers--and expenditure, capital works programs and employment generation. Though this issue was brought to my attention by the Lord Mayor in relation to Brisbane’s budgetary processes, the provision under RTI will apply to all local governments in Queensland. This provision is endorsed by the Local Government Association of Queensland.

The bill recognises the Brisbane City Council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee. This is a reflection of the unique size and status of BCC. The bill also amends the RTI Act given the recognition of the Establishment and Coordination Committee. Committee information will be exempt for 10 years after its relevant date. Exempt information includes the committee’s submissions, briefing notes, agendas and minutes. In balancing these exemptions, the public will have access to information through an amendment to the Right to Information Act 2009. This will allow for the development of publication guidelines about available information of or about the council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee.

At the end of the day, the performance of the local government system remains the state’s constitutional responsibility but the complexity of the Brisbane City Council, its party political nature and its continuous strong performance over many decades mean the Minister for Local Government requires few powers of intervention. The minister may, however, require Brisbane to provide information to monitor and evaluate council’s compliance with its obligations and legal responsibilities.

The local law-making process includes a state interest check and new local laws will have to be approved by the minister prior to gazettal. This is also reflected in an amendment to the Local Government Act 2009 to ensure sound local laws across the state.

To reduce and streamline the legislative burden, the City of Brisbane Bill repeals the Brisbane City Council Business and Procedures Act 1939, the Local Government (Chinatown and the Valley Malls) Act 1984, the Local Government (Queen Street Mall) Act 1981 and the Australian Estates Company Limited, Hastings Street, New Farm Viaduct Authorisation Act 1962. Any relevant, continuing provisions from these repealed acts that apply only to the Brisbane City Council are covered in the new legislation.

Electoral provisions contained in the repealed City of Brisbane Act 1924 and electoral provisions relevant to the Brisbane City Council in the repealed Local Government Act 1993 have been continued and will apply to Brisbane City Council elections. These operate with the Electoral Act 1992 and provide for elections, 26 councillors and a directly-elected mayor.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to let you know that following discussions with the Local Government Association of Queensland, an amendment will be made to the Local Government Act 2009 to clarify the parameters of the material personal interest provisions. This amendment makes it clear in the definition of an ‘ordinary business matter’ that a person does not have a material personal interest merely because they are a member of a non-profit, charitable or religious organisation involving no personal financial gain or loss to the person.

In response to concerns about what constitutes family in relation to material personal interest declarations, the legislation will now stipulate that this is a parent, child, sibling or partner and should therefore only very occasionally require the councillor to withdraw from participation in council business. The bill presented today provides for a new, modernised statutory local government framework for the City of Brisbane. This is an important step forward for Australia’s premier growing capital city. I commend the bill to the House.

XML.Hansard-Body: The bill primarily implements key measures for the second stage of the Queensland government’s swimming pool safety improvement strategy. In the five years from 1 January 2004 to 31 December 2009, 35 young children drowned in Queensland residential swimming pools. All, except one, were under five years of age. It is also estimated that 50 young children present to emergency departments each year due to immersion injuries, some of whom suffer permanent brain damage.

In 2008 and 2009 the Queensland government conducted a review of its swimming pool safety laws. An independent swimming pool safety review committee, including representatives from Kidsafe Australia, the Queensland Master Builders Association, Housing Industry Association, Australian Institute of Building Surveyors and the Swimming Pool and Spa Association, was established and provided a report to the government with 23 recommendations--all of which will be put in place.

Following extensive consultation, and to allow pool owners and local government time to adjust, the government has adopted a two-staged swimming pool safety improvement strategy to implement these recommendations. Stage 1, which applies to new pools, commenced on 1 December. Stage 2, which affects existing pools, is expected to be brought before the House later this year.

This bill amends the Building Act 1975 to facilitate a new swimming pool safety inspector licensing system and establish a Pool Safety Council to oversee the administration of that licensing system. The licensing system needs to be in place by mid-2010 to ensure a smooth transition for the draft stage 2 measures that include mandatory inspections at the point of sale or lease.

Coronial findings on the pool drownings of young children have repeatedly found defective fences at fault. Many of these children have gained access to a fenced pool through a gate or door including instances where a pool gate has been propped open, an automatic latch found to be defective, or via a door that forms both part of the house and the pool barrier.

Tragically many of these incidents occur shortly after families with young children move into a new and unfamiliar environment. This is why the state government has proposed pool owners who want to sell or lease a property will first need to obtain a pool safety certificate. We want to ensure residential pools are safe before a new family moves in.

In order to facilitate this requirement, the bill creates a swimming pool inspector licensing system and a new class of licensed pool safety inspectors. Under the amendments, licensed swimming pool safety inspectors will be empowered to conduct pool safety inspections on swimming pools controlled by state law. Inspectors will issue a pool safety certificate only if a pool meets the prescribed standard. Organisations such as the Local Government Association of Queensland and the Royal Life Saving Society have voiced their support for this new pool safety inspector licensing system. A licensed pool safety inspector will also be able to carry out ‘minor repairs’ prescribed under the Building Regulation 2006. This is expected to help reduce costs for pool owners by reducing the need for multiple inspections.

Under the bill an independent Pool Safety Council will be established to oversee the swimming pool safety licensing system. Council’s role will include approving pool safety inspector training courses, licensing inspectors, responding to complaints and imposing disciplinary sanctions on inspectors. To ensure pool safety inspectors receive high-quality and relevant training, amendments under the bill provide that registered training organisations and other approved training organisations deliver approved courses. Guidelines to specify the required content for these courses will be published.

The bill also provides the authority to create and maintain a state based swimming pool register. The pool register will contain information gathered by licensed swimming pool safety inspectors, building certifiers and local governments. Owners of regulated pools will be required to register, and an offence will apply to owners who fail to register their pools. These amendments are necessary to ensure a smooth transition to the mandatory point-of-sale and lease inspection system. This will allow owners preparing to sell or lease their properties time to obtain a pool safety certificate.

The bill also includes amendments to the ‘ban the banners’ provisions under the Building Act 1975. Following the passage of the ‘ban the banners’ amendments through the parliament last year, I made it clear that I was keen to listen to concerns from the property sector based upon its practical experience of the legislation’s operation. As a consequence of subsequent extensive consultation with key stakeholders and the community, the decline in industry confidence in the wake of the global financial crisis was identified as being put at further risk by some elements of the amendments.

For this reason, the government proposes to amend the ‘ban the banners’ provisions to ensure legislation does not hamper confidence in the residential property sector. However, the government remains committed to its election pledge, and the bill provides that covenants relating to house orientation remain valid when they require an orientation for energy efficiency purposes.

While there will be no changes to the current prohibitions relating to minimum floor area, covenants will be able to require a minimum frontage to preserve street amenity. This will be allowed except where imposing a minimum frontage would result in the construction of less energy efficient housing.

The bill will have no effect on the existing prohibitions on solar hot-water systems, photovoltaic cells, dark coloured roofs, energy efficient windows and the minimum number of bathrooms and bedrooms. Other elements of these provisions are proposed to be removed. However, it is important to note that it is in the interest of industry to deliver a diverse product suitable to the needs and desires of Queenslanders. To help industry help provide certainty to the residential property sector, the ‘ban the banners’ provisions will start at the commencement of the act.

The bill also amends the Urban Land Development Authority Act 2007 to enable the authority to approve a proposed development if it is consistent with either a previous preliminary approval, obtained from local government, or the land use plan prepared by the authority. The amendments also provide certainty as to the process the authority is required to undertake to seal plans and will support the authority’s primary function of bringing land to market quickly.

Finally, the bill also amends the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association Act 1971 to provide the Governor in Council the power to approve of the association selling land and for the Governor in Council to attach conditions on any such approval. This amendment will ensure the proposed redevelopment of the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association showgrounds can proceed without undue obstacles, thereby preserving the future of the RNA and one of Brisbane’s most iconic events, the Ekka, into the future. I commend the bill to the House.

XML.Hansard-Body: This bill will deliver three significant reforms. First, it will better facilitate the development of infrastructure to deal with the challenges of a growing population. Specifically, it will deliver a clear legislative framework for the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project--a project that will literally transform the Gold Coast. Second, the bill will strengthen protection of the marine environment by providing tougher powers to Maritime Safety Queensland. Particularly, we will increase penalties for marine pollution.

Third, the bill will amend legislation to create a robust port planning regime for the future, maintain Queensland Rail as a passenger focused government owned corporation and establish QR National as a proud, Queensland based company. In addition to these significant reforms, the bill also includes a range of amendments designed to improve the clarity and effectiveness of legislative requirements.

The government has a proud record of investing in infrastructure to improve the public transport system. The increasing complexity of projects, advancing technology, complex urban footprint, and the scale of capital investment means that legislation needs amendment to facilitate delivery through, for example, public-private partnerships. We are on the threshold of engaging in a public-private partnership for the delivery of the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project, which will transform the city of the Gold Coast.

The Gold Coast Rapid Transit light rail system is expected to take 75,000 cars per day off the coastal strip by 2016. Consistent with the government’s commitment to reducing emissions from household fuel consumption by one-third by 2020, the Gold Coast Rapid Transit is projected to reduce local greenhouse gas emissions by 114,000 tonnes within the first 10 years of its operation.
Amendments to transport acts to facilitate the delivery of this and other transport infrastructure projects throughout the state specifically:
XML.Hansard-Body-Hanging-Indent1: • enable the state to enter into an operator franchise agreement under a public private partnership for light rail;
• strengthen mechanisms to protect transport infrastructure and the safety of the community and users of the system; and
• enhance the ability of the state to manage the interface between transport land and surrounding areas for the protection of the public, other landowners and state interests.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Pacific Adventurer incident and Shen Neng 1 ’s grounding east of Great Keppel Island highlight the importance of robust national and state marine pollution legislation.

The bill amends the Transport Operations (Marine Pollution) Act 1995 to provide greater protection for Queensland’s marine and coastal environments. Given the magnitude and complexity of such incidents, legislation will be strengthened to ensure Maritime Safety Queensland is empowered to respond effectively and that penalties are appropriate. Penalties already apply where a ship has spilled oil, oil residue, noxious liquid or jettisoned harmful substances, such as containerised cargo, into Queensland coastal waters. However, they do not adequately reflect the potentially catastrophic consequences for Queensland’s economy or marine environment.

The bill increases penalties for these offences to a maximum of $500,000 for an individual and $10 million for a body corporate. These financial penalties are the equal toughest in the country. They reflect the government’s commitment to protecting Queensland’s pristine marine environment and send a message to the thousands of ship crews who pass through Queensland waters that nothing but the greatest attention to safety and care will be tolerated.

Authorised officers will have greater powers to act when a pollution risk is identified, and to ensure that appropriate action is taken to address risks before a ship is allowed to operate again. The bill will improve Maritime Safety Queensland’s access to corporate information when investigating the causes of marine pollution incidents.

The Transport Operations (Marine Safety) Act 1994 will be amended to give shipping inspectors powers to direct ships with non-compliant safety equipment to return to port or to an area for which their equipment is compliant. The bill facilitates the framework into the future for the commercial restructure of the Port of Brisbane, Abbot Point Coal Terminal and QR Ltd’s above-rail coal and freight business and below-rail coal network.

New provisions will be included in transport legislation to protect Queensland’s interests following the divestment of these entities. Specifically, the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994 will be amended to require QRNational to maintain its headquarters in Queensland. A 15 per cent shareholding cap will be imposed on any one person or entity or their associates owning shares in QRNational.

For the Port of Brisbane, major amendments in the bill relate to setting a solid planning regime under the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994 applicable to the port. Port operators have a range of statutory powers under this act. This bill amends the existing regime in relation to port charging and control powers to take into account that the Port of Brisbane will be managed by a private sector entity. Currently, the Transport Infrastructure Act provides a planning regime for strategic port land. The bill will establish a modified framework for the Port of Brisbane to reflect that the port operator will not be a government entity.

The amendments also include provisions relating to state toll road corridor land declarations. Recent transport legislation amendment bills have introduced nationally consistent transport legislation for heavy vehicles, including legislation for driver fatigue, speeding and overloading. This bill introduces a wider range of enforcement measures and court based orders for heavy vehicle offences, based on the national heavy vehicle compliance and enforcement reform package approved by the Australian Transport Council. The new measures and orders will provide more options to transport inspectors and police officers when enforcing heavy vehicle laws.

Combined with existing penalties and demerit points they are designed to help reduce the number of offences committed by heavy vehicle drivers and other parties in the chain of responsibility, and improve road safety for all road users. These amendments are supported by the transport industry, transport union and freight customers and will play an important role in ensuring professional and efficient road transport.
There are many important amendments in this bill that are vital for managing growth in our state. I commend this bill to the House.
