XML.Hansard-Body:
Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP)
(3.12 pm): I rise in support of the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. I reluctantly support this bill due to the amendments to the Coal Mining Safety and Health Act 1999 and the Mining and Quarrying Safety and Health Act 1999. In my view, it is a shame that the Weller review recommended that the current Coal Mining Safety and Health Advisory Council and the Mining Safety and Health Advisory Council be retained but that they be renamed as committees and that the membership should not be remunerated.

Whilst I am aware that the government has accepted these recommendations, I am personally saddened that the public administration semantic seems to have been played here. If the coal industry is to be respected and if coalminers themselves are to be respected and valued in our community I am concerned that these councils have been downgraded in terms of status from councils to committees.

I believe that Queensland rides on the coal industry’s back and there are many people in my community who believe the same thing. Therefore I cannot fathom at all why these two important councils have been downgraded to mere committees whose members are not to be paid, and I do not care who recommended it or why. The coalminers that I have spoken to both in my local area--most of whom are retired--and in Central Queensland cannot understand it either. Therefore I ask the minister: is their contribution not to be valued? Are coalminers’ lives to be valued? Was there any consultation with the coalminers at the coalface?

Last year at the Miners Memorial Day, which I attended on the minister’s behalf, the miners wore red T-shirts. They did this because they wanted industry specific legislation and they also wanted industry specific bodies to look after their health and safety matters. They wanted the councils kept. They did not want them downgraded to committees. I agree with them. But I also acknowledge that it is better to have committees than nothing at all--but it is not much better.

I would also like the minister to outline in his summing-up to this parliament whether or not the resourcing of these committees will be the same as it was for the councils. I want to know whether there will be the same budgets supplied to the committees as there were supplied to these councils. I want to know whether there will be the same number of public servants there to support these committees as there were to support the councils. I hope that in future this will not have to be reviewed again--and certainly not if there is another mining disaster or another serious accident in the coal industry. Only in the last week and a half we have seen major coalmine disasters in the United States and China. Coalmining is a dangerous industry and we need to accept that.

Everyone in this House should attend the Miners Memorial Day. Once a year they gather to remember those who have been killed in mining accidents. It is an extremely sad day. It affects me enormously personally as my great-grandfather was killed in an Ipswich coalmine. My father was injured many times in the Ipswich coalmines. He was on workers compensation for months on end and our family income suffered immensely. We worried whether or not he would come home and what state he would be in when he came home.

Only mining families understand this. Only in this chamber do people like me understand what it is like to hear and watch their father wince in pain and agony as my mother poured Condy’s crystals onto his back as he recovered from being pinned down on the floor of a coalmine with coal embedded in his back. To this day he still has a black scar running down his back. As I have said, he was on workers compensation for many months after this. But he went back down the mine as that is what coalminers do. They trust their mates to dig them out as that is what their brothers in the mining union do automatically. They protect each other and look after each other.

The coalminers and their families believe, rightly or wrongly, that these industry safety councils have been downgraded and that they are mere committees, and I understand how they feel. I never want to see the day where the next step is to get rid of these committees. Again, I ask the minister to provide advice on this in his summing-up.

I want to comment on some of the issues that the member for Mirani pointed out to us, particularly in relation to mining camps. I believe that there is no place in the coalmining industry in this day and age for mining camps. I believe that mining camps are disgraceful. Mining towns should be established in new areas where mines are being built. Mining towns where men and women miners have their families with them and where communities can be formed and developed are, in my view, the way to go. These camps sicken me. Hot bedding sickens me. Camps with raw sewage sicken me. This is 2010; it is not 100 years ago when people like my great-grandfather and my grandfathers were fighting for these sorts of conditions to be scrapped.

I also come from the mining industry. Many people in this House do not know this but I spent four years in the mining industry. I worked for Curragh. When I worked for Curragh we built two construction sites. We had a dragline camp and another construction camp. We also had a caravan park on site with individual ensuites. The workforce, our miners, were housed in the town of Blackwater in state-of-the-art houses that were built specifically for them. These houses are still at the forefront of the mining industry in Australia today. I can remember in 1982-83 when we first opened houses in Blackwater that we invited the then minister, Minister Terry White, to come up and open the first 27 houses that we built--as the member for Gregory would be aware--around the town centre in Blackwater.

I can remember Terry White saying to everyone in Blackwater at the time that they were not coalminers’ houses--they were too good for them; they were actually Mater prize homes. I make no apology for building those types of homes for the workforce in Blackwater at the time. Nothing is too good for our coalminers, especially where I am involved. In fact, I pay tribute to the mine manager at the time, Tom Kuzman, and Barry Golding, a senior civil engineer. The fact is that we employed architects like Noel Robinson and John Hockings to design the homes in Blackwater, and they were state-of-the-art houses. To this day right across Australia they are still at the forefront of coalmining housing architecture. I believe that there should be no coalmining camps and there should only be communities for families, and I ask the minister and the shadow minister to take my views on board. I am speaking from the heart here. I believe that in 2010 we should be better than this in this state. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr JOHNSON (Gregory--LNP) (3.20 pm): Well, isn’t it a breath of fresh air to hear somebody standing up for what she believes to be absolutely right when it comes to the coalmining industry, and I congratulate the member for Bundamba. I also congratulate the shadow minister for mines and energy for his speech last evening, because he gave a precise and accurate assessment of what is and should be happening in the coalmining industry.

To carry on from where the honourable member for Bundamba left off, Blackwater is a coalmining town. It is a town 100 per cent associated with the coalmining industry. Everything that town does is relative to coal. Regardless of whether it is an open-cut mine or an underground mine around Blackwater in the Central Highlands, these mines are dangerous environments. When we talk about coalmining we are not talking about draglines, longwalls, scrapers and bulldozers, power or water; first and foremost we are talking about the human lives behind these operations on a 24-hour basis. These men and women are at the forefront of an area where safety is the No. 1 factor. I do not think we can put enough emphasis on safety. There was a tragedy at Blackwater last year, and that was an unfortunate situation. We cannot take our eye off the ball for one half of one minute.

The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 is an important piece of legislation which covers many aspects, but there is only one aspect I really want to touch on--that is, coalmining safety. The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Weller Review recommended that they be renamed as ‘Committees’ and that membership should not be remunerated. The Government has accepted these recommendations.
XML.Hansard-Body: Change is good and change is always something pretty special, and during the 20 years I have been in this place there have been many changes in metalliferous mines and quarries. Over the last 10 years the Mines Inspectorate has examined fatalities in Queensland mining. The explanatory notes go on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Large mine fatalities dropped from 24 in the 1990s to eight in the 2001-2009 period, while small mine fatalities increased from five in the 1990s to eight in the 2001-2009 period. This trend is reflected in statistics for other Australian jurisdictions.
XML.Hansard-Body: Regardless of whether it is a large operation or a small operation, safety is paramount. It again comes back to that human factor. The BMA mine at Blackwater is hoping to lift productivity over the next few years. No-one denies the fact that we have to lift productivity, but we have to ensure the safety of those workers. Many people think that safety in mines relates to the mine site. They forget that it is about driving to and from work. They also forget that mine workers work 12-hour shifts. Many of them go home and go to bed, but some do not. Rather, they will get into a car and drive to Yeppoon, Rockhampton, Mackay, Gladstone or wherever their loved ones and families are who they have been displaced from over the period of that shift. That puts a safety factor into effect that has also contributed to some of the work going on in mining operations. I cannot emphasise enough the dangers of this great industry. It is an industry that is at the forefront of the wealth generation capacity of this state. The safety of these workers, regardless of whether they are travelling to or from work or whether they are at their workplace, is paramount.

I want to come back to what the member for Bundamba touched on earlier, and that is the mining camps in Blackwater--these absolutely disgraceful places where these people live, where these men and women who work in this great industry live. There are about 1,500 or 1,600 people housed in that accommodation at Blackwater. I have to congratulate the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning, the Hon. Stirling Hinchliffe, for visiting Blackwater in recent weeks and viewing firsthand the disgraceful, despicable state of this accommodation. This morning in the House the minister made reference to that deplorable housing situation. He was aghast when he saw it, because I looked at his face when he was touring the area with the mayor of the Central Highlands Regional Council, Peter McGuire. The minister was genuinely aghast when he saw that area, and he told the local media what he thought, too. It is very rewarding to see that he is putting measures in place to correct that situation.

There is certainly a long way to go in that regard, and in the past there has been too much blame passed on to the former Duaringa shire council. The amalgamated council, the Central Highlands Regional Council, incorporates those four Central Highlands councils. The Minister for Infrastructure and Planning, the Minister for Mines and Energy and the government as a whole can work in conjunction with the local authority in the Central Highlands to bring about a remedy to correct this unfortunate situation. I note that the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning has come back into the House, and I thank him for visiting Blackwater a couple of weeks ago.

The infrastructure associated with the coalmining industry is of paramount importance. At this point in time the government has Queensland Rail’s coal and mineral division up for sale. If I was trying to sell property I would make sure that that property was mickey mouse, that it was up to scratch, that everything was there and that it looked pretty good. There would be people travelling around Queensland now looking at that infrastructure unbeknown to Queensland Rail and the Queensland government to see exactly how they would be gauging their platform for sale. One only has to drive from Blackwater to Rocky and see the Pacific National crash site. On the side of the line there is twisted steel and twisted wrecks of railway wagons all over the place. How much longer are we going to see this mess lying around? Those people would probably think, ‘This must be a pretty good show this. The railway infrastructure has probably decayed and fallen over. We’ve got a twisted wreck of a train here.’ This does not paint a good image. I trust that the Minister for Transport will take stock of this situation in conjunction with her shareholding minister, the Treasurer, to ensure that we paint a better image so that, if Queensland is going to sell this operation, we get the best price possible. Given the situation up there now, which is not painting the best picture, we are not going to get the best price possible.

Another aspect of the coalmining industry I want to talk about relates to strategic cropping land. In February the government put out a paper for comment in relation to strategic cropping land. The shadow minister, the member for Callide, made reference to this matter last night. He canvassed it very well in his address. The LNP has a paper that our leader will be making reference to in the next couple of days. I have asked a question of the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning in relation to this issue. As I see it, we are talking here about pristine agricultural land--I call it black alluvial soil--in the Central Highlands region. I know that that type of soil is also on the Darling Downs area as it is in other parts of Queensland. They do not make this land anymore. Open-cut coalmines will render this country absolutely worthless. I believe that there is a power of country in Queensland that coalmining operations can take advantage of. We can use that type of inferior land for coalmining purposes. That does not mean to say that those rural aggregations are not worth the money that this prime land is worth, but over many years we have witnessed all of that beautiful area of the Redlands, which was once beautiful farming land where vegetables were grown, become residential estates. If that is going to continue to happen in this great state, we will see the guts torn out of that Central Highlands country and see it turned into coalmines. I hope that does not happen.

As the honourable member for Callide said, we have to have the mining industry work in unison with the agricultural industry. It is not about saying, ‘No, you can’t go there,’ or, ‘You can go there,’ but we have to make certain that that mickey mouse black alluvial soil is protected for all time. That land cannot be returned to its natural state by draglines, bulldozers and scrapers. That soil has developed scientifically over thousands of years to be in the state that it is in today. I hope that, through the government’s strategic cropping land planning framework discussion paper, there will be a recommendation to cement the foundations of what we in the LNP have been saying, too. As the shadow minister said yesterday, there is room for both industries. We cannot have a one-way street that will have long-term ramifications for our agricultural industry.

Today I heard the member for Mirani make reference to the cost of housing. That is certainly an impost on these rural areas in question. Time and time again we have seen that as soon as you mention mining, or coalmining in particular, the price of housing doubles or trebles. I do not believe that is fair, because there is a social divide in the wage structure of people who work in the mining industry and people who work in businesses in rural towns. I say to the government that it is very important that affordable land is made available in mining towns so that people can buy land at a reasonable rate and build their homes, so that they can relocate their families to those towns and see their children go to local schools--so that families can function in a social environment. I know that there is catch-up to be done in some of those Central Highlands regional towns in relation to mining operations, but at the same time I beg the ministers responsible to take stock of the situation so that we can remedy what is happening there now. I am absolutely fed up to the back teeth of the blame game.

The people of Blackwater have formed an action group. That group is trying to work with the local authorities, the government--all of the people in question--to put in place viable, responsible initiatives that will be advantageous to the growth of that town and the growth of that community. I believe that Blackwater can again become the great town that it was--it still is a great town--in parallel with Emerald. Owing to the recent flooding, Emerald is certainly choking itself with land--although there is a fear factor there with the flood.

We need to encourage businesses to set up in these rural towns. The Premier talks about decentralisation on a daily basis--getting people away from the south-east and living in other areas. In our rural towns we have high schools and all of the things that go with them. The issues of population and jobs growth in rural areas are going to be around for a long time. This is a grand opportunity to get the equation right. If we get the equation right now, I believe that the long-term gains after the short-term pain will be things for which we will salute ourselves forever and a day.

That group in Blackwater is not anti council or anti government; it is very pro trying to get outcomes. Many of the people involved in that group are coalminers themselves. Some of them are small business people. Some of them are just ordinary mums and dads who want to make a difference. I appeal to the ministers when they go to Blackwater to meet with this group and listen to what they have to say and the ideas they are putting forward, because they are certainly very worthwhile ideas that are going to take Blackwater forward and create an environment that is very different from what is there now.

As we progress into the next decade, I believe that many issues relating to the coalmining industry have to be weighed up and addressed. At the same time, the mining industry in this state is worth $3 billion in royalties to the Queensland government. Not much of that $3 billion goes back into those mining areas. I see the member for Mount Isa in the House. She would know about the dollars that are generated by the extractions from the north-west minerals province. Those dollars are no different from the dollars that are generated by the agricultural industry, which works in parallel with the mining industry. Not many people live in these regions, but I think it is time we saw some of that money that is generated come back into the South Burnett, the Burnett, the Callide, the Central Highlands, the Bowen Basin, the Surat Basin and now the Galilee Basin.

A huge mine is about to be put in place in the Galilee Basin, which is just north of Alpha. When that mine starts production it will feed into the Abbot Point port. Five hundred and ten kilometres of standard gauge railway line has to be built from there to Abbot Point. Water has to come from somewhere and power has to come from somewhere. All of that planning has to be done properly, in conjunction with local authorities. There is talk of 6,000 jobs being created in the infrastructure stage of the development there. Just where those people will come from never ceases to amaze me. Do we have that type of personnel in Australia in the mining industry? We are at capacity now in terms of that type of personnel. For too long the emphasis was on academia rather than on hands-on tradespeople such as mechanics, diesel fitters, plumbers, refrigeration mechanics, boilermakers and so on.

The road infrastructure that is needed in association with the Kevin’s Corner coalmine at Hobartville is something else. The road between Alpha and Clermont just barely carries the traffic now for the cattle industry, let alone the coalmining industry. Over the next few months we are going to witness those sample B-doubles--46 a day--travelling from Alpha through to Jellinbah at Blackwater for the wash plant there for processing. All of this will be a further impost on the road infrastructure that we have in the central region.

It is not plain sailing; we are talking about mountainous roads through the Drummond Range. It is unfortunate that this product cannot be carried by Queensland Rail. There is so much development occurring in this region and there are exciting times ahead for the Central Highlands and the Central Queensland region. I have not even touched on the gas industry--I know that the honourable member for Callide has--and the untapped potential there.

Queensland certainly has a huge goldmine on its hands in relation to the mineral industry. I appeal to the government to use a fraction of those royalties to build up those towns and make them great places to reside. I ask the government to upgrade the road and rail services, the hospitals, schools and other associated infrastructure that makes communities great. I hope my words have not fallen on deaf ears.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP)
(3.40 pm): This afternoon I rise to contribute to the debate on the bill before the House, the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and the 11 acts that it seeks to amend. Before I continue can I recognise some visitors that I had today who I was very pleased to host for lunch and to tour around the precinct: Mat Samson, Deputy Principal of the Victoria Point State High School, and Tomas Partington and Kate Jenkin who are the school leaders and very much interested in this bill before the House, surprisingly enough. During the tour I was able to show them all around the place and talk to them about some of the legislation and some of the procedures that we go through. Obviously having been in the House just on a year now, I was interested to get their comments and thoughts on how legislation worked. They will be watching this bill quite closely in the coming days and I will be following it up with them.

We will be supporting the bill. I note in the minister’s second reading speech that he has set out to achieve three outcomes with this legislation. Firstly and primarily it seeks to achieve enhanced safety and health measures, which is commendable; it seeks to achieve a streamlined and simplified government process--again an outcome to be supported and acknowledged; improve credit support arrangements for electricity retailers; and improve customer service obligations. Again all laudable, aspirational steps forward within those respective areas within that industry.

Let me comment firstly on the safety and health aspect. It is vital, and it was touched on by so many other speakers here this afternoon, that any workplace needs to be as safe as it possibly can be. In what has always been historically a high-risk and a dangerous work environment, it is even more critical that we place a high value on the work that they do and on the safety around the work that they perform. It is important that we strive to continuously improve.

Looking at the statistics that have been quoted by both the minister and in the briefing notes, I reiterate that fatality rates in large mine facilities dropped from 24 in the nineties to eight in the 2001-09 period, whilst fatalities in small mine facilities actually increased from five in the nineties to eight in the 2001-09 period. It is a trend, tragically, that is being reflected, as we have heard, through other jurisdictions and other Australian states and territories.
Quoting from the minister’s second reading speech--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The amendments proposed will make it a requirement for small mines to develop a safety and health management system.
XML.Hansard-Body: Again that is to be applauded and should be and obviously will be addressed in this legislation. It comes out of the findings in February 2009 of an inquest into a death in a small mine where the coroner, Mr Scott Luxton, recommended the legislation be amended to require that mines with 10 workers or fewer have an SHMS in place, which again is absolutely commendable.

I caution the minister, if I could, that when we focus on the numbers they can be misleading. They can paint a wrong picture if we do not have all the information. I trust that the minister has gone through this quite comprehensively. When one looks at the numbers--at the moment on the page they do tend to be numbers but they are not just numbers--in the period of the nineties--and when they refer to them as the nineties I am operating on the presumption that it is 1992-99--there were 29 facilities, 24 in the large mines and five in the small mines, and that trend actually changed so that through the 2000 period from 2001-09 there were eight fatalities in the large mines and eight fatalities in the small mines, which was an increase.

The information that we do not know here, and I was not able to dig it out, was whether there are more small mines operating now as compared to the numbers in the previous period. What we need to not lose sight of is the fact that over 20 years 45 Queenslanders lost their lives--45 people went out to work but did not come back. We do need to ensure that this legislation actually targets the incidents rather than the statistical deviation that may be contained within those numbers. Again it is about ensuring that case-by-case we get the relevant information and, if there are lessons to be learned from them, that they are learned and they are heeded. We do not have that specific information and it can be difficult drafting legislation in those broader terms.

Safety and health issues have also been ongoing in my electorate around a quarrying or an extractive industry. My community has raised health issues arising from things such as dust, noise and flyrock activity through the blasting process. This legislation does not consider the possibility of the wider impacts for the surrounding or the receiving environment. I heard the member for Gregory reference the fact that it is not just the mine site that we need to be mindful of, it is the journey to and from home; it is also the receiving environments around those areas and the freight handling from there on through the ports. We have had the ship run aground, which is part of that whole chain of transport that we must not lose sight of.
The second issue that came out is the streamlining and the simplification of the government processes. Again I refer to the minister’s second reading speech in which he says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We are now introducing legislative amendments that will speed up mining lease approvals. The proposed amendments to the Mineral Resources Act 1989 will streamline the approvals process for mining lease applications where no objection has been lodged.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on a little later to say in a dot point--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... to reduce the regulatory burden on participating businesses in the Smart Energy Savings Program
XML.Hansard-Body: What concerns me--and these will be my closing comments--is that obviously time is money and it is important that we have efficiencies and gains where we can, but whenever we entertain short cuts, whenever we look to streamline or fast-track processes, we run the potential risk of environmental impact, personal impact and harm in the wider community. We also expose ourselves to the risk of systemic failure where these checks and balances are watered down or are cut short. We have seen time after time examples in very recent history how quickly things can go wrong. There was the insulation debacle where things were streamlined and expedited; there was the Building the Education Revolution where money was well intentioned and in the vast majority of cases it did go to the right place but there are too many instances where things went wrong; and then, of course, we had the minister for IT telling us how fantastic it was that the new payroll system was able to go live so quickly and pay the health workers. That clearly went tragically wrong. It is those pay issues for the healthcare workers that could again be repeated when these programs are streamlined and accelerated. We will be supporting the bill.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP)
(3.49 pm): I rise to speak on the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The bill seeks to amend various acts administered within the Mines and Energy portfolio to achieve three outcomes for Queensland. It sets out a simplified regulatory process to achieve savings for both business and government. It seeks to ensure better safety and health measures in Queensland’s mining, explosives and gas industries and also address improved electricity retailer credit support arrangements and customer service obligations.

I would like to briefly comment on the two areas which address the enhancement of safety and health measures and the petroleum and gas safety and health amendments. Coming from the electorate of Mount Isa where mining is our No. 1 industry, I have to say that mine safety is a very high priority in all mines across my electorate. We have seen a great deal of work done in the last few years particularly when the responsibility of safety on mine sites is paramount. It is good to see that all of our companies have embraced it.

Since the Mining and Quarrying Safety and Health Act came into force in March 2001, Queensland’s large mines have been required to develop and maintain a fully documented safety and health management system. As I said before, the industry at large I believe is doing this very well. Small mines with 10 or fewer workers were exempt from this requirement because of the significant resources and skills needed to develop a safety and health management system.

In 2006-07 the Queensland Mines Inspectorate conducted a review of Queensland’s metalliferous mines and quarry facilities over the previous 10 years. The review found a decreasing trend in the number of fatalities at large mines but an increasing trend in fatalities at small mines. Fatalities at large mines dropped from 24 in the 1990s to eight in the 2001 to 2009 period. At the same time, unfortunately and sadly, fatalities in small mines increased from five to eight.

In light of this, the amendments proposed will make it a requirement for small mines to develop a safety and health management system. This amendment was also recommended by the coroner following an inquest into a fatality at a mine site. To assist small mine and quarry operators to manage this change, the Mines Inspectorate, in conjunction with the Institute of Quarrying Australia, has conducted 26 training seminars throughout the state on risk management techniques and development of a safety and health management system. The small mines industry has responded very positively to this initiative.

The petroleum and gas safety and health amendments, which relate to the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004, seek to enhance safety and health measures in the gas industry, particularly in relation to the certification of installations and appliances including clarifying gas compliance certificate requirements and introducing an offence provision in response to issues arising from cases of falsification of appliance approval labelling.

The proposed amendments will also change the licence type for hydrocarbon refrigerant gas--that is, the gas used in small refrigerators--from the current requirement for an organisation authorisation to an individual occupational licence. This change will better reflect that an individual is required to have particular trade qualifications before undertaking hydrocarbon refrigerant gas work.

This amendment also prepares Queensland regulations to potentially align with the Council of Australian Governments’ agenda to establish a national licensing scheme for various trade occupations by 2012. Further, amendments to the safety and health provisions of the petroleum and gas act aim to correct unintended consequences of certain definitions, such as the definition of a type B gas device--that is, industrial gas devices such as small boilers.

Currently, the definition of a type B gas device includes a device used for ‘refrigeration for which fuel gas is the refrigerant’. As the liquefied natural gas, LNG, process as a whole uses natural gas as a refrigerant, the entire LNG facility would be captured under this definition. This means LNG proponents would be subject to duplicate approval possesses--firstly, under the type B approval and gas work authorisation processes and, secondly, under the major hazard facility safety case process. Amendments proposed to the definition of a type B gas device will exclude LNG plants from the definition, eliminating this duplication. Amendments to the definition of a type B gas device will also clarify that gas flares require approval in the same way as other gas burning devices.

I would like to congratulate the minister, his staff and certainly the department for their continued efforts, care and due diligence for this massive mining industry that I have in my electorate. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (3.55 pm), in reply: First of all, I thank all honourable members for their participation in this debate. I thank the member for Callide, as the shadow minister, for his and his party’s support.

The Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced with three main aims: to enhance safety and health measures in the state’s mining industry; to streamline and simplify government processes; and to improve credit support arrangements for electricity retailers and improve customer service obligations. One of the fundamental aims of this bill is to create an environment which promotes Queensland as a destination for mining investment and the benefits to Queenslanders that flow from that investment. While Queensland has one of the safest mining industries in the world, the Bligh government has a plan to ensure this burgeoning industry achieves a balance of sustainable development and economic prosperity. This bill is the next step in that plan.

To reaffirm the Queensland government’s commitment to improved health and safety of workers in the mining industry, the bill proposes amendments to complement existing legislation which requires large mines to develop and maintain a fully documented safety and health management system. The proposed amendments will also make it a requirement for small mines employing 10 or fewer people to develop a safety and health management system. I am pleased to advise that the small mines industry has responded generally positively to this initiative. This bill also proposes amendments to enhance safety and health measures in the gas industry, particularly in relation to the certification of installations and appliances.

Turning now to the elements of the bill that relate to streamlining and simplifying government processes, which is the key to promoting Queensland as a destination which welcomes investment, the bill implements the government’s commitment to streamline processes including legislative amendments to remove unnecessary delays to mining lease applications. The proposed amendments will streamline the approvals process for mining lease applications where no objection has been lodged by removing the mandatory requirement for the Land Court to assess mining lease applications to which there are no objections. Instead, these applications will be assessed by the minister administering the Mineral Resources Act 1989. This can shorten the mining lease approval process by up to six weeks. Other amendments include amendments to simplify the approvals process for petroleum and gas pipelines that traverse both the mainland and Queensland’s internal waters and ensure that pipeline proponents only need to comply with the safety and health obligations under one act.

In relation to some issues raised by the member for Bundamba, I take the opportunity to assure her that the two new committees--the Coal Mining Safety and Health Advisory Committee and the Mining Safety and Health Advisory Committee--will function in exactly the same way as the two previous councils did. It is essentially a name change only. The act remains otherwise unchanged except for the aspect of remuneration. Members of the committee will be able to claim for travel and accommodation expenses.

On the reason members should no longer be remunerated, the Webbe-Weller report sets out the rationale for the proposed changes. But, broadly speaking, it is not a prerequisite that members are to be professionally qualified experts. Therefore, there is no presumption of an entitlement to remuneration. The committees will receive the same level of secretariat support that the current councils do. I am advised that all current members of the councils have indicated that they are enthusiastic to continue their participation with the new committees and continue to provide valuable advice to government on the important topic of mine safety.

The bill will also introduce improved credit support arrangements for electricity retailers and improved customer service obligations. The proposed amendments will improve electricity retailer credit support arrangements and customer service obligations for electricity supply in rural and regional Queensland. The proposed amendments will enhance the regulatory framework relating to retailer credit support by requiring the Queensland Competition Authority, as an independent regulatory body, to prepare and publish credit support guidelines. The guidelines must meet the needs of distribution entities in terms of minimising credit risk, while also ensuring the required credit support arrangements are fair and reasonable for retailers so as not to create an unreasonable barrier to entry.

The amendments proposed to the Electricity Act aim to ensure large market customers in rural and regional Queensland can secure access to electricity. The proposed amendment will require the retailer responsible for the premises to offer supply to these customers on fair and reasonable terms.

Whilst I was pleased to hear that the member for Callide and the LNP are in support of this bill, I cannot help but comment on just one or two comments made by the member for Callide. To paraphrase the member for Callide, it behoves me to respond to just one or two points.
Mr Seeney: I’d be disappointed if you did not.

Mr ROBERTSON: I take that interjection because I would hate to disappoint the member for Callide. I have been provoked by the member for Callide’s somewhat unkind observation about this government’s relationship with the coal seam gas industry in this state. As he took a somewhat negative position, I think it is only fair that I remind him and place on the record once again that it was this government that put in place the 13% Gas Scheme in this state and that that 13% Gas Scheme was opposed by the Liberal and National parties. Having now corrected the record, I shall return to my position of appreciating the member for Callide’s ongoing support for this legislation.

I would also like to assure all members that the Bligh government has a plan to ensure we achieve the balance between environmental sustainability and economic development. Queensland’s emerging LNG industry has the potential to rival Western Australia’s, with a number of Gladstone based LNG projects already well advanced and on track for exports to commence between 2011 and 2014.

On 17 September, the government released its Blueprint for Queensland’s LNG Industry , providing industry and the community with a clear understanding of the policy platform we have developed to support the world’s first coal seam gas to liquefied natural gas export industry. The blueprint includes commitments to create certainty for potential investors by retaining the current flat royalty rate of 10 per cent of wellhead value, upholding our commitment to allow certain components of this wellhead valuation to be determined prospectively, where necessary, and ensuring there are clear and comprehensive guidelines set out for environmental impact statements.

Furthermore, in order to secure the availability of gas for Australian users, the government has decided to implement a process to monitor the operation of the gas market in Queensland and, if necessary, to set aside and release prospective gas land for domestic supply. This measure will only be taken if supply constraints warrant such an action.

In relation to comments by the member for Callide and other LNP members on sovereign risk, it is important to place on the record the expenditure on exploration in Queensland, which has increased by over 80 per cent from $354 million in 2005-06 to a new record of $640 million in 2008-09. This is even up on the $563 million invested in 2007-08 at the height of the resources boom, and this clearly means jobs. These figures clearly demonstrate that the exploration industry is continuing to invest and that the initiatives of the Bligh Labor government to help attract resource investment dollars are actually working.

In terms of concerns around CSG water, the Queensland government recently released new guidelines to ensure the burgeoning CSG energy sector contributes to a sustainable future. I might add that I respect all members who have contributed to this debate on this particular issue. It is an important issue, and one that we do need to get right. We are taking a precautionary approach to these issues, but I welcome the ongoing interest of all members from both sides of the House on this vitally important issue, because if we do not get it right it can have significant impacts right across the landscape and on landholders. I place on record today my determination to do whatever I can to ensure that we do in fact get this right now and into the longer term.

The laws introduce new trigger thresholds for aquifers. If thresholds are exceeded, coal seam gas operators will be required to investigate. These arrangements will allow us to detect and respond appropriately where large scale CSG extraction may be impacting on groundwater to minimise the impact on the environment.

I should note that just last week I released further guidelines on how we will assess the potential impact on nearby acquifers from the extraction of coal seam gas and water from coal seams. Importantly, a specialist scientific panel will assist the department in the work that it will be doing in oversighting that. The panel will be made up of experts from outside the department to provide that necessary academic oversight. It will also be assisted by an advisory group made up of representatives from industry. Importantly for many members in this House, it will also contain representatives from agricultural industries, the grazing industry, broadscale agriculture and the community. We believe that by establishing those bodies we will provide a level of oversight in terms of the work that is done not just by the industry in the first place but also by my department.

I recognise the member for Callide’s comments about balancing the concerns of the agriculture and resource sectors and resource exploration and development. I can assure him and all members that the Bligh government is working with all parties to achieve this balance.

The Land Access Working Group was established in May 2008 and comprises relevant state agencies and the agriculture, mining, and petroleum and gas peak bodies, including AgForce, the Queensland Farmers Federation, the Queensland Resources Council and the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association. The Land Access Working Group developed a land access policy framework that was endorsed by government in November last year, and legislation is currently being drafted to give effect to the new policy. Mining, particularly the emerging industry of coal seam gas to LNG in Queensland, presents unique challenges along with the potential for significant economic prosperity for this state. Achieving this balance is not a task that should be taken lightly, and the Bligh government recognises this. That is why we have a plan to create an environment in Queensland which encourages investment whilst securing the rights and interests of landowners and the agricultural sector.

I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge everyone in those areas of the Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation that administer the mines and energy portfolio who have contributed to the development and coordination of this bill. The mining industry has the potential to provide the Queensland economy with a huge boost, and the Bligh government has a plan to ensure this happens. This bill is part of that plan and better positions Queensland as a location which welcomes and encourages such investment. I commend the bill to the House.
