XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (4.10 pm): I am quite pleased to have an opportunity--an unexpected opportunity--to make a contribution to the consideration of the Architects Amendment Bill 2010. I am very pleased to have an opportunity to engage in a debate with my honourable colleague the member for Rockhampton, because it somewhat bemuses me that he has carriage of a bill that seeks to regulate activities in this area. I am not sure who would make the most unlikely architect--the member for Rockhampton or me. I think between both of us we would be flat out drawing a mud map on a rainy day. However, it behoves us to recognise the skills and talents of architects in the great job they do in designing the built infrastructure in Queensland. Increasingly there is a growing importance of design in addressing a range of issues that are becoming more current for people everywhere.

From my portfolio perspective, energy efficiency and energy conservation have become very important. A lot of the objectives that are worthwhile pursuing in terms of achieving those greater levels of energy efficiency and effectiveness can be achieved by design--by designing buildings in the right way from the start. So I certainly do have something of an interest in this bill.
The objectives of the bill have been outlined by the minister in his second reading speech.
Ms Darling: She’s leaving you to it, Jeff.
A government member: Do you want to go for a little while longer?
Mr SEENEY: All I can say is that I am pleased the first minister gets 60 minutes.
Mr Schwarten: I won’t call relevance on you.

Mr SEENEY: Come on, pay attention! The bill before the House seeks to introduce a simplified registration scheme which adopts procedures approved by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia and adopted by architect registration boards in the Australian states and territories. The amendments will simplify the procedural framework for registering architects by recognising the AACA requirements for Queensland registration. The qualifications and experience required to be registered as an architect will not change as a result of this bill.

The whole area of registration is something that is important for professionals. With the increased mobility of professionals across state boundaries, I think in all such professions there is a need to--
An honourable member interjected.
Mr SEENEY: I am getting assistance from a whole range of people, but I can assure you that I do not need it.
Mr Hinchliffe: I’ll come over and help you.
Mr SEENEY: I can assure you that I do not need assistance from you either, my honourable friend.

Madam Deputy Speaker, as I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, the first objective of the bill is to simplify the registration scheme and adopt national procedures. National registration schemes are important because I think while there is not a lessening in the relevance of state borders there is an increase in the mobility of people across state borders. I am referring not only to the professionals themselves who are so registered but also to people who generally move from state to state. An architect who is registered in Queensland needs to be assured that it means the same thing to be registered as an architect in Victoria, Western Australia or another state. It needs to be a standard registration that they are comfortable with and have confidence in.

The second dot point in the explanatory notes that sets out the objectives of the bill states that the bill seeks to broaden the fitness to practise provisions to enable the Board of Architects of Queensland to request that a registered architect undergo a health assessment if the board reasonably believes that the registered architect is unable to competently and safely practise as an architect because of their mental or physical health and to ask the Commissioner of Police for a criminal history report providing details of convictions for offences in Queensland or elsewhere in Australia relating to an applicant architect.

The bill also seeks to permit a registered architect to register as a non-practising architect in circumstances where they do not intend to practise. It also seeks to introduce a range of miscellaneous amendments in relation to matters such as the powers of the board in the registration process, restoration of registration, staffing of the board, disciplinary and penalty provisions, and disciplinary provisions relating to formerly registered architects. As can be seen from those dot points which set out the objectives of the bill, the bill deals with pretty much administrative procedures and processes--
Mr Wells: Will you support the bill?

Mr Seeney: --and, as such, it is fairly simplistic. It should come as no surprise to honourable members that of course we will support a bill that seeks to simplify and streamline the registration procedures.

However, while the provisions of the bill themselves are reasonably straightforward and simplistic, the legislation I believe deserves the respect of this parliament. The profession of architecture certainly deserves the respect of those who sit in this parliament and those who understand that a lot of the work that architects do is sometimes not well recognised and taken for granted. I think like a lot of other professions it only becomes absolutely apparent to most people when they get it wrong. That is the case with a lot of things that are about design. When anything is designed properly and works well, then the design just about remains unnoticed. But when they get it wrong and whatever it is does not work properly, then it is very noticeable and very marked. And so it is with the work that architects do. In designing the built environment, they have a challenge to get those elements of the built environment right and to ensure that the lifestyle and living spaces that we all enjoy serve the purposes for which they are designed and for which we believe they should be designed.

I guess the challenge for architects is to deal with the long-term consequences of the decisions they make in that the decisions they make are certainly around for a long time. It is interesting to see the changes in architecture over the years.
Mr Schwarten: Wind him up! It’s got nothing to do with the bill.
Mr SEENEY: The member for Rockhampton says that it has nothing to do with the bill.
Mr Schwarten: It hasn’t got anything to do with the bill at all.

Mr SEENEY: While the bill, as I indicated, serves to streamline the registration process, it behoves us to recognise the importance of architects and architecture and to recognise that that profession has changed over a long period of time.

If we look at the built environment in Queensland we can see the range of architectural styles that have become part of the Queensland lifestyle that we enjoy today. In the parliament this morning the Speaker tabled the conservation plan for Parliament House. An important part of that conservation plan is to recognise the architectural skills involved in designing this place where we all work. As I sit here listening to some of the more boring speeches that we hear in this parliament I am always intrigued by the Corinthian columns at the front of the chamber.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! I would ask the member to please return to the objectives of the bill.

Mr SEENEY: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I am sure that the provisions in the bill before the House this afternoon will ensure that architects in Queensland can continue to provide great input into ensuring that the built environment in Queensland is one that will serve Queenslanders well for many years to come. With that short contribution, I have much pleasure in commending the bill to the House.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP)
(4.20 pm): Before I commence my contribution to this debate, I commend my colleague the member for Callide for his broad expose on the Architects Amendment Bill. I think every architect in Queensland would be very proud to know how much he thinks of them. I was enjoying some of the architecture in this building a few minutes before this bill was actually brought on. I can tell members that there are some nooks and crannies here that are certainly fine pieces of architecture.

As I rise to speak in the debate on the Architects Amendment Bill 2010, which was introduced into the House on 9 February by the honourable Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology, I would like to say from the outset that the LNP will be supporting this bill, as members have heard from my colleague. I extend my appreciation to the minister for offering myself and the opposition a briefing on this bill and the anticipated provisions within it last year. The departmental staff were most helpful, Minister, and I wish to record my thanks on the public record of this House this afternoon.
Mr Schwarten: Thank you.
Mrs STUCKEY: You’re welcome. In addition, I would like to thank my adviser James Martin for his support and assistance.

The Architects Act 2002, known as the act, regulates the registration of architects and the practice of architecture in Queensland. First regulated in Queensland by the Architects Act 1928, provisions are currently controlled by the Architects Act 1985. Some members may be wishing to have the member for Callide back as I take them through some of these facts.

The Board of Architects of Queensland, also known as the board, which was established as a result of changes to the 2002 act--an act that dissolved the board established under the Architects Act 1985--presently administers the act. The board has experienced difficulties over the years in implementing this scheme, evidenced by the actuality that the transitional provisions of the 1985 act are still being used.

The proposed amendments in this bill feature a simplified registration scheme for architects, as the honourable member for Callide has already espoused. This will be achieved through the recognition of national procedures approved by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia. Other provisions contained in this bill consist of extending the fitness to practice provisions through a health assessment in addition to the Board of Architects of Queensland’s assessment; broadening the board’s powers to apply for a criminal history in considering applicants for registration; extending the registration of an architect to include a non-practising architect presuming they meet the required provisions; and providing further grounds for the board to cancel the registration of an architect and implementing greater disciplinary processes.

A simplified registration scheme is a key platform of this legislation and competencies will no longer be prescribed by regulation. People will instead need to satisfy two criteria, those being holding an academic qualification in architecture or a pass in the national program of assessment recognised by the AACA and proven competencies in the practice of architecture. If passed, which looks most likely, these amendments will make it unnecessary to have assessment entities as before and will bring Queensland into line with other Australian states and territories.

Released by the National Competition Council in May 2001, a staff discussion paper titled ‘Reforming the regulation of the professions’ recognised that the primary objective of regulating a profession is to protect the welfare of consumers and to protect the public. This bill has been introduced to rectify areas of the Architects Act 2002 that fall short of providing for the best interests of the profession and the public as consumers. It appears the overall aim is to bring the legislation into line with similar legislative standards regulating professions such as was the case with changes to the Professional Engineers Act 2002 that were made in April 2008.

Stated policy objectives of the 2002 act were to protect the public by ensuring architects’ services were delivered in a professional and competent way and that standards of both practice and service were upheld. The bill before us today seeks to improve upon those objectives, and this is to be applauded.

Gaining adequate information about the skills of various practitioners is often difficult for consumers. More often than not, word of mouth referrals prove a frequently used and reliable method when in search of the services of various professional practitioners, and architects are no different. In some instances, potential customers may be lured by large advertisements or other marketing strategies but how do they know the service provider is honest and competent? Protection from uncertainties such as these are valid reasons why legislation needs to be updated and amended for the society we live in now.

Whilst this bill is not raising any contentious new laws I still wanted to make sure the industry did not have issues with certain aspects of it and that the value of design will not in any way be eroded by the implementation of this legislation. To this end, I consulted with key industry bodies such as the Australian Institute of Architects’ Queensland chapter, the Association of Consulting Architects, the State Architect Mr Phillip Follent and former government architects.

For the most part, industry groups are happy with these amendments, stating they are pretty much what they expected. Some general reservations as to the regulation and processes for criminal history checks and health assessments were expressed and the comment was made that there appeared to be an overly strong emphasis on criminal activity.

These abovementioned mature former government architects remember the glory days when Queensland was making a name for itself as a progressive modern city. Hosting a successful Commonwealth Games in 1982 was indeed an honour. The Brisbane games are still held as one of the very best achievements of our previous architects. Everything went so well from the moment Matilda, a 13-metre mechanical kangaroo, helped out with the opening ceremony until the finale on 9 October. I note that Matilda was in the media again recently. A service station in Tugun wanted her to be displayed on the Gold Coast. It looks like poor old Matilda lost out as councillors determined she was too large to be on view. Interestingly, the Premier is launching a bid for the Gold Coast to host the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Perhaps she should use Matilda to improve our chances.

Six years later the games accomplishment was to be surpassed by the unforgettable Expo 88. I do ask for a little latitude to share a few key facts from that wonderful Expo. As the first free enterprise funded World Expo the exposition was a considered yet calculated risk for us here in Queensland. Some 7.8 million persons needed to have visited Expo over the six months for it to have been a successful exercise. That is an average of 42,000 visits per day over the 184 days of the Expo.

Hosting Expo in Australia and in Brisbane, with a local population of just over one million persons and getting a six-month figure more than seven times that figure, was by no means a fait accompli. Not only was World Expo 88 a success in goodwill and diplomacy, it put Brisbane on the global map. It managed to pay for itself many times over with no public debt or liability and reversed an alarming trend that had occurred in previous World Expos. Thanks to the government’s foresight for this Expo and the leadership of Sir Llew Edwards and his team, the final statistics for the six-month Expo, including VIPs and staff, came to 18,574,476 visits--that is more than the whole population of Australia at the time.

Queensland experienced huge periods of growth during the seventies and eighties, yet due to the sound economic management of the government of those times--which I might add was not Labor--it did not get into debt as we see today. The ABC program Keeping the Faith asked a panel to come up with a single word to describe architecture. Their summation produced a sentence: it can delight or disturb, change our lives and finally outlive us. So with a leap of faith, we put our trust in the mind of the architect. It is interesting to note that one of the amendments focuses on the status of the mind of the architect and their fitness to practise in their chosen field, and I shall elaborate on that point later.

I had the pleasure of speaking recently with a long-serving government architect who informed me that architecture is a lifetime profession, which is why we need to streamline the regulations that are before us today. Together with engineers, he said, architects have always been the responsible party to get projects done. The language with which he spoke was emotive and inspiring, much like the architectural feats that have shaped our nation and our state of Queensland. Architects are responsible for designing our houses, hospitals, universities, schools, courthouses, churches and community buildings, our museums and public spaces. Almost everything we see in our modern society has been gauged at some level by an architect who has shaped the vision, the design and the time and made a mark in history.

When one mentions ‘architecture’ and ‘Queensland’ together, it is impossible not to acknowledge the iconic Queenslander. Compatible with our unique climate, the broad verandahs, stumps and breezeways of the first Queensland homes were practical applications that soon typified our home-grown architecture. Modern trends have of course imparted their influence on the traditional Queensland dwelling. However, the sense of openness and relationship to the land are ongoing features attributable to these origins. The relatively young Gold Coast has experienced its share of design mistakes along with a neglect of infrastructure planning to cope with our rapid growth. Our long stretch of picturesque coastline lends itself to a smorgasbord of architects’ ideas. Talks of statues of giant bronzed Aussie lifesavers positioned in the Broadwater reveal the boldness such a vibrant and youthful destination breeds.

One of Queensland’s history-making buildings is located a mere 30 minutes drive from my electorate, visible from the sandy beaches of Currumbin and piercing the skyline with unmistakable presence. I speak of course of Q1--not Q2--the Sunland Group’s record-breaking high-rise accommodation tower. Inspired by the Olympic torch, the design, construction and engineering of the world’s tallest residential tower were awe inspiring to say the least. From a sustainability aspect, though--and the minister may be interested in this--the maximum use of glass skins is probably not practical and has proven to be a magnet for lightning.

In a truly benevolent gesture, Soheil Abedian, the architect who founded Sunland Group and gave us the world’s first Palazzo Versace hotel, recently announced he would provide funds for a new architecture school at Bond University in February 2010. The school is due to open in January 2011 and the degree will take three years and four months to complete. This is exciting news for nascent designers and for Queensland, as expanding opportunities for education in architecture will allow the future visionaries of our state to develop. At a time when sustainable planning is critical for our exploding population, we must nurture and encourage the young and not-so-young minds to design wisely as living space becomes a premium.

The Architects Accreditation Council of Australia currently only recognises two educational institutions in Queensland for accredited qualifications, so it is fantastic to see the efforts of successful architects like Soheil giving back to the community. In Queensland there are 2,572 registered architects. To obtain a Bachelor of Architecture from QUT takes five years full time. At UQ a Bachelor of Architectural Design takes three years full time as an undergraduate plus one year full time for a professional Master of Architecture.

I move now to some of the changes that this bill will make. As mentioned previously, the proposed amendments are designed to update the regulations to current industry practices and are similar--but not the same--as the Professional Engineers Act. While this is a bill that is designed to bring provisions into line with national standards, it raises the substantial question of whether the new provisions create situations that can be exposed to abuses of process. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 2 of this year draws the attention of the parliament to a number of amendments within this bill which may affect rights and liberties of individuals, including rights to privacy of personal information and to gain a living by work of a person’s own choice. Section 7A deals with types of registration as an architect and the provision allows the registration of an architect under the act as a practising architect or a non-practising architect.

‘Architect’ is a controlled term and clarifies how a person can be identified as such and offers a degree of consumer protection. The term ‘architect’ is protected under the Architects Act 2002. Section 113 finds that a person who is not an architect but claims or holds themselves to be an architect is liable for a maximum penalty of 1,000 penalty units. Likewise, a person who is not an architect who uses the title ‘architect’ to promote or advertise their services will be liable for the same penalty under the act. These strict penalties are important to maintain the professionalism associated with qualified architects in the digital age, where website designers are calling themselves ‘information architects’ and offering courses to train others as such.

Non-practising architects are those who do not intend to practise during the current registration year--that is, they are academics or those not fulfilling practice requirements but still wanting to be identified as architects. It did seem unreasonable in previous legislation that if an architect chose a career path of academia they were not allowed to identify themselves as an architect, and I can see the minister is agreeing with me here. After all, they would have undergone the approved training. But there does appear to be no provision introduced to require those registered as non-practising architects to identify themselves as such, and I would ask the minister to address that in his summing-up, or we can deal with it when we consider the clauses.

As I have already mentioned, consumer protection is at the core of these amendments. An article in the Courier-Mail of 6 November 2009 saw the Board of Architects of Queensland fine a Brisbane developer for falsely claiming that some of its homes were architecturally designed. This fine of $17,500 against Paradise Homes was the first in Queensland. In addition, an employee was fined $9,000 for the offence of ‘holding out’ using the title of architect. As with other professional bodies, there is a certain image and prestige in calling oneself an architect. People using this title offer reassurance to those who employ their services that they have undertaken study and reached a level of expertise. I might say that a particular Premier who is now living on the public purse in the US had a fondness for titles and the image they created. He collected doctorates as some collect footy signatures, and I do hope the minister does not have such lofty plans.
Mr Schwarten: I have got a doctorate, actually--an honorary doctorate from the Central Queensland University. There you go!

Mrs STUCKEY: Section 16 in clause 9 deals with registration requirements. I am actually almost speechless at that comment from the minister, so I will just take it on board. With regard to registration requirements, essentially these amendments remove the current regulations that control registration and simplify the process by prescribing national standards for registration. To qualify for registration under the existing act, an architect needed a qualification identified under the relevant regulation. Under these amendments, they will need a qualification recognised by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia and to successfully complete the AACA architectural practice examination or a similar examination as approved by the board. This is bringing Queensland into line with other states and territories in Australia. According to the explanatory notes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The qualifications and experience required to be registered as an architect will not change as a result of this Bill ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I am sure there is a lot of relief in that for many students.
XML.Hansard-Body: If this bill is passed, the board will have greater control over continuing registrations. With the passage of this bill through the parliament, the board will take over the responsibility from competency assessors. A registered architect will no longer need to comply with continuing competency requirements but with continuing registration requirements which will be controlled by the board. It will be the responsibility of the board under these amendments to decide if an architect has maintained competency to continue their registration.

New section 28 deals with extending the grounds by which a board can cancel a registration, that is, if the architect’s registration to practise in Australia, another state or foreign country has been cancelled for disciplinary reasons under the relevant jurisdiction’s law; or if the architect’s membership of an association of architects in Australia or a foreign country has been cancelled for disciplinary reasons; or if the architect has contravened a condition of the architect’s registration; or if the health assessment report given to the board under proposed section 35F finds that the architect is currently unable to competently and safely practise as an architect. No doubt it is in response to the influx of incompetent overseas doctors and other professionals who have caused bungles that have affected the lives of Queenslanders that this government is applying such conditions in this legislation. The board will now have the power to cancel an architect’s registration if their registration has been cancelled in another state or territory in Australia owing to disciplinary reasons or if a health assessment denies their ability to competently and safely practise as an architect.

A new section is proposed in this amendment bill, placing the onus on the architect to advise the board of any disciplinary action taken against them by another state or territory of Australia, or a foreign country, within 21 days of the action or they face a penalty. Clause 17 carries a maximum penalty of 50 penalty units, or $5,000.

Another area covered in this bill is criminal history checks. This provision allows the board to ask the Commissioner of Police for a written report about the criminal history of a relevant person. This provision is part of the attempt to broaden the fitness to practise provisions, that is, whether the applicant has a conviction other than a spent conviction where the rehabilitation period of 10 years for an adult and five years for a child has lapsed without further conviction. Another provision states that a relevant person is an individual applying for registration, an architect applying for renewal of registration, or an individual applying for restoration of registration. There appears to be no other restriction, limitation or criteria set for when the board may exercise this power, which may well lead to issues regarding privacy.

Proposed new section 35D, titled ‘Health assessment’, allows the board to request that a registered architect undergo a health assessment if the board reasonably believes that the registered architect may be physically or mentally impaired. The board must give the subject architect an information notice about this decision. The board may immediately suspend an architect’s registration if the health assessment is not undertaken, or the architect does not cooperate with the doctor selected by the board. The health assessment report may be used only for the purposes of the act and must be destroyed as soon as practicable after it is no longer needed. If the health assessment proves that the architect is unable to practise in a safe and competent manner, then that architect may have to pay out of their own pocket for the reports, assessments or whatever else is required.

We can be thankful that here in Queensland indemnity insurance was set up with the Institute of Architects and the standard here in Australia is second to none. In China, with over 400,000 practising architects, there were no such standards of education in order to be registered. Just five years ago, China finally adopted the US standards to qualify students to be registered in order to access indemnity insurance. The board’s role here in Queensland is now extended to advance educational and professional standards for architects, but, as I have said, they are already some that we can be proud of.

More transparency is required in the tendering process for major projects. Having made that comment, it is of note that Labor’s track record on big projects is pretty hopeless. Take the North Bank experiment, where we saw people in this government wanting a concrete metropolis, wanting to spoil our river views by treating the river as a sewer and trying to build over it. We have not heard much about that proposal for some time and I would be very keen to hear what the latest update on it is. Another amendment proposes to increase the maximum penalty for disciplinary procedures from 40 penalty units to 200 penalty units, which will reflect the penalties within similar regulated professions, such as engineers.

I would like to close by adding my congratulations to Lindsay and Kerry Clare, who in March were awarded Australia’s biggest architecture prize--the 2010 gold medal for architecture--during a ceremony hosted by the Australian Institute of Architects. This talented couple have combined work and home life in a 30-year professional and personal relationship. Their public works include the Gallery of Modern Art and the chancery building at the University of the Sunshine Coast. With those few words, I once again give the LNP’s support to this bill.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (4.44 pm): I rise today to speak in support of the Architects Amendment Bill 2010, which is designed to amend the Architects Act 2002, which regulates the registration of architects and the practise of architecture in Queensland. As an engineer by trade, I have had a lot of opportunities to work with architects. I would have to say that when I first started as a junior engineer I used to think that all architects do is make buildings look nice but they spend far too much time and money in the process of doing just that. To me, all we needed was a square building with a roof, and windows are optional. Nothing is more economical than that--a typical engineer.

Over the years I began to appreciate that well-designed buildings are not only pleasing to the eye but also create a sense of joy and comfort for the occupants. Architecture can also define a city as major cities around the world are known for their architecture. I came to appreciate architecture and architects so much that I married one. As if one in-house architect is not sufficient to ensure my continued appreciation of form over function, my eldest daughter, Priscilla, this year has just graduated from UQ in architecture. So my appreciation of architecture and architects is now on the public record. None of my above statements were made under duress or out of concern for my own personal wellbeing.

Good architecture adds beauty and functionality to a city and the high standards demanded of professional architects also help ensure that public safety is protected. In this age of increased environmental awareness, we can also expect our professional architects to design buildings that not only are energy efficient in their structure but also incorporate environmentally friendly building materials and techniques. Without our professional associations of highly trained architects, our cities could soon deteriorate into unimaginative, unhealthy and inefficient conglomerations of concrete and steel buildings.

As Queensland’s population continues to grow--with growth in South-East Queensland among the highest in this nation--we need appropriate regulations and standards to ensure that our cities and suburbs, including our towns in regional areas, are environmentally friendly and functionally sound. We need to ensure that our future dwellings, commercial and industrial developments will not only accommodate a growing, ageing and culturally diverse population but that they will do so in safety and in style.

The Queensland government is aware of the need for some clarification and standardisation with regard to the registration of architects in this state. It has become evident that Queensland needs a simplified registration scheme to replace the current prescription for qualifications and competencies of architects by regulation. At present, our registration laws for architects are not in sync with those of other Australian states and territories. The proposed amendments will protect the public by ensuring that architectural services in Queensland are provided in a professional and competent manner.

This bill clarifies and standardises Queensland law in relation to the registration and accreditation of architects. It will formalise what has become current common practice, because, although some of the new requirements are not set out in the current act, they are already in use in Queensland as they are in use in all Australian states and territories. In that regard, the bill will provide that applicants for registration will need to have an academic qualification in architecture recognised by the AACA or a pass in the national program of assessment conducted by the AACA and competencies in the practise of architecture based on a period of training followed by the successful completion of the AACA architectural practice examination, or another examination arranged or approved by the Board of Architects of Queensland.

In addition, the Board of Architects of Queensland has faced some difficulties in determining the proficiency, competency and the physical and mental health of some architects. It is also proposed to introduce a further ground for cancellation of registration in situations where a registered architect has been removed from a register in any other jurisdiction in Australia.

In a similar situation to other states and territories, Queensland architects are registered by the Board of Architects of Queensland in accordance with the 2002 act. This bill will introduce a simplified scheme by adopting procedures approved by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia. In future the registration framework for Queensland architects will recognise the AACA requirements already adopted by other states.

This bill includes important provisions to protect public safety by broadening the fitness to practise provisions. This will enable the board to request that a registered architect undergo a health assessment should it reasonably believe he or she is unable to competently and safely practice as an architect because of their mental or physical health. To further protect public safety, the board will also be enabled to ask the Commissioner of Police for a criminal history report with details of convictions for offences in Queensland or elsewhere in Australia relating to an applicant.

Provisions in the bill will also permit an architect to register as a non-practising architect in circumstances where they do not intend to practise and also introduces a range of amendments in relation to matters such as the powers of the board, staffing of the board and penalty provisions, even in relation to formerly registered architects.

The board will be provided with a broader and more comprehensive range of options for dealing with disciplinary matters enabling greater flexibility in the resolution of matters once they reach the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal as well as providing a greater range of penalties and enforcement options.

The government has consulted all government departments and the Board of Architects of Queensland in the preparation of this bill. We have undertaken industry consultations with respect to amendments to the act and with the Australian Institute of Architects which has indicated its in-principle support for the proposed amendments to this bill. This bill is an important amendment to current legislation and, in the interest of public safety and clearer legislation, more in line with other states and territories.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (5.17 pm): I rise today to make a contribution to the Architects Amendment Bill 2010. The introduction of a simplified registration scheme adopts procedures approved by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia and brings Queensland’s registration in line with the registration boards in all other Australian states and territories. Whilst the qualifications and experience required to be registered as an architect will not change, the bill will have the effect of broadening the fitness to practise in these provisions. It will also enable the board to request that a registered architect undergo a health assessment if the board reasonably believes that the registered architect is unable to competently and safely practise as an architect because of their mental or physical health. It also gives the Commissioner of Police the ability to request a criminal history report which provides details of convictions for offences in Queensland or elsewhere in Australia relating to an applicant architect.

The legislation has provisions to allow a registered architect to register as a non-practising architect in circumstances where they do not intend to practise, and it introduces a range of amendments regarding registration and disciplinary and penalty provisions applicable to former registered architects.

The bill seeks to also introduce an alternative simplified registration scheme without the need for assessment entities. The board will continue to assess fitness to practise requirements, register architects, carry out disciplinary processes, enable criminal history checks and request that an architect undergo a health assessment if again the board reasonably believes that the architect is unable to competently and safely practise. Whilst one would assume there would be adequate checks and balances from an engineering perspective to ensure that no substandard architectural plan slips through the rigours of building codes, this legislation would provide a further safety mechanism for the public. Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (5.22 pm): I am pleased to make a short contribution to the Architects Act 2002. I would particularly like to discuss the role of the Board of Architects of Queensland under the new arrangements proposed by this bill. Later I will touch briefly on the issue of health assessments and criminal history checks.

These amendments will introduce a simplified registration scheme which will adopt procedures approved by the Architects Accreditation Council of Australia, the AACA. These procedures have already been adopted by architects registration boards in other Australian states and territories. As such, it is considered that these amendments will simplify the procedural framework for registering architects by recognising the AACA requirements for Queensland registration. However, it is important to note that the qualifications and experience required for registration as an architect will not change.

Under this proposed simplified registration scheme, the qualifications and competencies for the registration of architects will no longer be prescribed by regulation. Instead, the act will provide that applicants for registration will need to satisfy two criteria. Firstly, applicants will need an academic qualification in architecture which is recognised by the AACA or a pass in the national program of assessment conducted by the AACA. Secondly, applicants will require competencies in the practice of architecture based on a period of training, followed by the successful completion of the AACA architectural practice examination or another examination arranged or approved by the Board of Architects in Queensland.

Although not currently set out in the act, these requirements are already in use in Queensland through transitional provisions and are used in all other Australian states and territories. Further, I am pleased to advise that the Board of Architects of Queensland will continue to assess fitness to practise requirements, register architects and carry out disciplinary processes. As such, the board will also continue to have a significant role in ensuring that the high standard of architectural services in Queensland is maintained.

I also want to touch on the issue of health assessments and criminal history checks for architects. In order to further enhance the public protection provisions already in the act, the bill will require registered architects who by reason of any physical or mental capacity are unable to competently and safely practise for six months to notify the Board of Architects of Queensland. Once the board receives such notification, the proposed amendments will allow the board to suspend registration during any period of incapacity.

Circumstances may arise where registered architects do not advise the board of their incapacity. In these circumstances the bill introduces an amendment which entitles the board to direct a registered architect to attend a health assessment if the board suspects that the architect is suffering from a physical or mental condition which affects their ability to practise. In addition to the above, the act currently allows the board to take into account whether an applicant for registration as an architect has a conviction for an indictable offence in deciding whether that applicant is fit to practise. However, if the board wishes to inquire into the criminal history of an applicant, it would be required to write to the Commissioner of Police requesting such information, and the provision of the information would be at the discretion of the Commissioner of Police. As such, this bill introduced a provision which allows the board, if it considers it appropriate, to ask the Commissioner of Police for a criminal history report relating to an applicant. This will allow the board to ascertain, with the assistance of the police report, which convictions may be relevant to the application for registration being considered. However, any report provided to the Commissioner of Police may be used only for the purposes of the act and must be destroyed as soon as practicable after it is no longer required.

It is understood that such requests to the Commissioner of Police for criminal histories would be rare and likely to be no more than one or two a year. As such, the amendment is also consistent with provisions in the Professional Engineers Act 2002 and, importantly, the Legal Profession Act 2007. I firmly believe these provisions will further enhance the public protection objectives of the act. I commend the bill to the House.

All architects and engineers originally came out of the building industry. They always like to think they are a bit better than the building industry, but in reality they are an integral part of it. While the member for Callide was commenting on Corinthian columns and so forth, I could not help thinking he is a revival Renaissance man. This building is an example of revival Renaissance. The Louvre is a very similar building. The Zwinger building in Dresden also has very similar architecture. Architecture has played a very important part in our history, as many members have pointed out including the member for Gaven, who gave us a history lesson on some aspects of it. I particularly thank the government members who were solidly relevant in their comments on the bill. I do not think there was a great deal of relevance from the member for Gaven, although what he had to say was very interesting.

The members for Aspley and Gladstone asked whether or not it was a bit heavy handed to have police checks. I think the member for Gladstone was suggesting there could be some exploitation in terms of asking people for a check on a person’s health.

I will share a little illustration with members. This provision applies to engineers as well. We put our trust in architects and engineers. The idea that we put our trust in somebody who is found to be mentally unsound and the board is not able to do something about it is a situation that has existed. We had a person who was deemed to be of unsound mind and took somebody else’s life when he was of unsound mind. He was put into Wolston Park. He put his address down as Wolston Park. Papers to renew his membership as an architect were sent to Wolston Park. This was done while he was under the care of the Mental Health Act. Clearly that person could not participate in this industry yet could have lawfully held himself out to be an architect. That person has since been rehabilitated back into society and he has been given his registration back. There has been some controversy over that. This does happen. For example, we could have a person who has dementia in charge of a major project and the family knows about it but nothing can be done about it. That is why these provisions are in this bill.

Going to the other extreme, we could have somebody who is guilty of fraud project managing, as an architect does, a job and using their trust account to put a person’s money into. That person could be paying them a lot of money. It is a consumer protection issue. It is something that is not objected to by the industry because, after all, they do not want the industry tainted by people who drag the industry down. Quite frankly, from a regulation point of view, I know that the board was very uncomfortable about not having the power to take somebody off the register when they were made aware that that person was of unsound mind. That is the reason for these provisions.

When this issue was first raised with me with respect to engineers I raised the very same question that members are raising now. They are legitimate questions to raise. I think the shadow minister was questioning--and I might have missed it--whether or not someone could hold themselves out as an architect--

Mrs Stuckey:
There is no provision for people who were registered as non-practising to identify themselves as such.

Mr SCHWARTEN:
They can still call themselves an architect but they are nonpractising. It will be prohibited under the law. Those persons cannot hold themselves out as practising architects. Is the shadow minister suggesting that we should put some further qualification on it?

Mrs Stuckey: I was going to address that in the clauses, but we can do it now. It seems to be an area that still needs a little bit more tightening. How are they going to identify themselves as non-practising architects if they are now included, which we agree is a sensible thing to happen?

Mr SCHWARTEN: That is a fair point. I know in the military they say ‘major general retired’. They cannot advertise themselves as an architect. They cannot practise as an architect. They can still call themselves an architect but they cannot hold themselves out, as the act says, as an architect--in other words, they cannot advertise their services as an architect. I could be known as Robert Schwarten, architect, but I could not practise in that regard.
Mrs Stuckey: It is status for them.

Mr SCHWARTEN: It is. I do not have any problem with that. I can understand where they are coming from in that regard. If they are an engineer they want to stay an engineer and be recognised as an engineer but they just cannot practise. This is a consistent approach.

I do not intend to take any more time of the House except to say that these provisions freshen up the 2002 act. I said when we brought the act in in 2002 that we would continue to be vigilant and continue to be guided by the profession and the board as to the amendments required. This simplifies the practice when people are applying to be architects. That is the crucial issue. The regulations were cumbersome. Trying to put a national focus on that was proving to be a challenge for the board. I think this has modernised it eight years down the track. What will be required in another eight years, who knows?

I thank all members for their contributions. I thank the people in the Department of Public Works and on the Board of Architects for the work that they have put in. I thank my own staff, and particularly Burgess Stephenson, for their work. I commend the bill to the House.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 16, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 17--

Mrs STUCKEY
(5.36 pm): I am mindful of time as well so I will try to be fairly brief. I did want to ask the minister about clause 17 as it inserts a new section. This clause places the onus on the architect to advise the board of any disciplinary action taken against them by another state or territory of Australia or in a foreign country within 21 days of the action or face a penalty. That penalty is some 50 penalty units or $5,000, which is quite significant.

I am very interested to hear from the minister how these new rules will be advertised. Is there a plan for it? How can the government ensure all architects know about this? It is a fairly short time frame for people who are moving here from interstate to become aware of it. I am wondering how this new rule will be circulated.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I think the member is suggesting that we need to ensure that everybody knows about these penalties. As I understand it, they will be put on the board of architects website. Is that the question? I understood the member to be saying that when a penalty was enforced against somebody we need to know that it had been enforced. Have I got the bull by the horns there?

Mrs STUCKEY: I am referring to the fact that there will now be a law where the onus will be on the architect to advise of a disciplinary action--and they only have 21 days to do so--before a quite severe penalty is imposed. I am wondering whether it is fair for people to be expected to find out about this new law in that time.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I think they will all know about it. I have never met more informed people than architects in these sorts of situations. I think 21 days is the legislative standard. I do not have any fears about 21 days being a problem for notification. There has been a lot of discussion with the architects themselves. They do not have any problems with this and neither does the board.
Clause 19--

Mrs STUCKEY (5.39 pm): This clause deals with the criminal history check. The LNP did say that it had some issues with this, as did some sections of the industry. In the current legislation--not the bill before us today--there is an obligation for the board to obtain written consent from the person undergoing the check or the investigation. Section 44 of the 2002 act relates to an investigation by the board of conduct in providing professional services as an architect, but this is not the same as considering their past criminal history in determining their eligibility for registration. What we have in this new legislation is that the board must give the subject architect an information notice about the decision. I am wondering what the need was to strengthen this. Perhaps it is in line with the Professional Engineers Act and is part of streamlining across-the-board. I know the minister has also mentioned specific cases as to reasons for disciplinary action. Is this the same reasoning behind this amendment, or is there another reason?

Mr SCHWARTEN: No, the member has got it in one. That is basically it. The only area of contention when we raised it was what would happen to that information once we got it. It is to be destroyed after that so it does not get put into other people’s hands. So that was the only area of contention.

Mrs STUCKEY: I am glad that that was the case. The other question I have is how the board is going to assess those criminal accusations, and really it is a matter of seeking some clarification from the minister. Under fitness to practise the board may regard whether the applicant has a conviction other than a spent conviction for an indictable offence, an offence against this act or an offence relating to the practice of architecture in another jurisdiction. After the expiration of the rehabilitation period, I understand that the person need not disclose their past criminal convictions and officials considering the person’s fitness for a profession have to disregard that conviction. However, this is subject to specific legislative provision like that included in this bill, enabling an official to request a copy of a person’s criminal history from the commissioner of the Police Service. Is this proposed amendment going to change the prescription of the existing 2002 act to include them by way of this legislative provision requesting that history from the police? If that is the case, is that not greatly suppressing their rights and liberties?
Mr SCHWARTEN: No, is the answer to the member’s question.
Mrs STUCKEY: Would the minister like to explain that a bit further?
Mr SCHWARTEN: It is the existing act from 2002. It has not changed. That is all I can say--that is, no, it will not. It is not going to change from the 2002 act provision.
Clause 20--

Mrs STUCKEY (5.42 pm): Clause 20 relates to the health assessment which is another area that we had some concerns with. There are quite a few sections under proposed section 35, so I will include a couple here. I refer to allowing the board to request that a registered architect undergo a health assessment if it reasonably believes that they may be physically or mentally impaired. I know the minister gave an example of this earlier, but I am wondering what indicators would lead the board to proceed with the request for a health assessment. Also, the board can suspend registration if the architect does not undergo the health assessment or cooperate with the doctor. I am just wondering whether the minister could perhaps explain cooperation a little more, because in a lot of these cases in the real world where people do not get a choice to see a doctor they may not, for some reason, get on because of personal clashes or other different reasons. I wonder if the minister would address that issue.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I could give the member the circumstance where say, for example, the person has dementia. The member asked how the board would act on it. That would probably come about by a complaint. It may be a complaint from their work colleagues. It may be a complaint from a consumer. It may be a complaint from their immediate family. It would generally tend to be on a complaint basis. It would come to the board’s attention through that process. There is not any intention to go around and peer into all of the architectural practices looking for people with dementia or anything like that.

Having done that, we then need to give the board the power to enforce it. If we give the board the power to do it, we then have to give it the power to carry it out. If someone does not want to cooperate, we have to find a way to ensure that they will. I guess the only way we can do that is to say, ‘If you don’t go and have a medical assessment then we will presume you to be a person who is not fit and proper.’ That is basically what the effect of this will be. I know it is a bit harsh and it rattled me a bit when it came to my attention, but I can see no other way really of saying to somebody, ‘This is fair dinkum.’ We cannot make it optional for them. There has to be some causal circumstance after it. In my view, the only way to do that is to say, ‘If you don’t treat this seriously, if you don’t cooperate, if you don’t see this doctor of our choosing nominated by the board’--and the board would take advice on who that doctor might be--‘we’ll suspend your registration.’ If we did not do that, basically we would have a part of this bill that could not be acted upon. I just do not see how we would enforce it otherwise.

Mrs STUCKEY: I thank the minister for that, because the circumstance that he just outlined is valid. However, not all cases would be a case of dementia, and they are very sad indeed. Often those people do actually have glimpses of normality and they do not realise when they are perhaps not in the moment and they have lapsed. But I guess what I am really interested in is if there is a choice of doctors. If there really was a personal clash, is there the opportunity for the board to have more than one doctor? I also have a couple of other issues I want to ask about while I am on my feet. I was also interested in the appointment of the health assessor, and this is to do with the board choosing that doctor. It only needs to be satisfied that the chosen doctor does not have a personal connection with the subject architect. I am wondering what other criteria are employed with the board’s appointment of this person given the fact they have this power to decide the future of this person. Does the board have a preferred list? Is it a specialist? What is required? Can it call a psychiatrist if it needs to? I thought that a power that was invasive on an individual and that could perhaps permanently affect their work would have some tighter guidelines.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The member makes a good point. The board has to make that decision, but its decision is then appealable to QCAT. So there is a handbrake there, if you like, to stop any of those excesses. If somebody believes they were being victimised or being unfairly treated, they have the power to take that to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal.

Mrs STUCKEY: Thank you, Minister. It is an area that I would ask the minister to look into more. I am not sure how many instances happened in the Professional Engineers Act or how many will happen under this bill, but to the person involved and their family it could be very meaningful for them. The other issue I wanted to ask about in this clause is that if the health assessment does prove that the architect is unable to practise in a safe and competent manner the architect may have to pay for the reports and the assessment et cetera. I am wondering what sorts of costs we are talking about here. How broad is this assessment? How expensive could it be? Could this go on for months? Could it result in being referred out to other people? After the initial consult with the doctor, does it then go on to other referrals if that is required, because we would hope there is a degree of speciality here if someone’s career is being terminated.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I concur with the member’s view on that. My understanding of it is that the board would be as extensive as it needs to be. So in other words, if you have to involve other specialists--if the doctor concerned was of the view that they were not in a position to do it--they could refer it to somebody else who has a specialty in a certain area. I am comfortable that all of the checks and balances are in this system to allow people to get a fair assessment and are as intrusive as they have to be to satisfy the board. In other words, if someone has to go before a psychiatrist, for example--
Mrs Stuckey: And have checks?

Mr SCHWARTEN: That is exactly right. That is not a problem. I know that in the case that I do know about, there was no doubting whatsoever that that was the case. But our big problem is that we have never had the power before to say that somebody can be referred under these circumstances and it is very important that we do that.
