XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Mount Garnet Races and Rodeo; Country Racing
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (5.52 pm): In fewer than three weeks the small township of Mount Garnet will come alive for its annual and iconic Mount Garnet Races and Rodeo. This is one of the supreme events on the country calendar throughout Queensland, if not Australia. This iconic event started more than 75 years ago and now has the reputation of being the bush version of the Cairns amateur races. The rodeo is also priding itself on the celebration of 40 years of rugged, tough competition.

The Mount Garnet Races and Rodeo is where the city meets the bush to renew acquaintances and friendships and for country people to share that social interaction that is lost through the tyranny of distance. This May long weekend provides an enormous financial boost not only for the region but also for Far North Queensland and has been an important fundraiser for the Royal Flying Doctor Service, sporting clubs, the School of Distance Education, local P&Cs and the list goes on. Praise must go to the continuous commitment and efforts of the hardworking members of past and present committees and supporters of the race club and the rodeo association who have made this event what it is today.

Unfortunately, a raft of problems loom arising out of issues to do with Queensland Racing and the Licensing Commission. These issues have come out of left field. Unreasonable demands and red tape seriously threaten the continuation of this iconic weekend event. New laws have created massive costs of at least $60,000 alone to meet licensing laws that enforce heavy security measures and which are no more than overkill in the bush. Other requirements imposed are to provide street lighting to camping areas. Part of the ambience of camping is to sleep under the stars, cook a good feed and boil the billy.

On top of all that, Queensland Racing has forced country race clubs to erect inside and outside running rails, amounting to an extra cost of some $30,000, as well as tens of thousands of dollars for special amenities. Licensing laws have forced heavy security measures. This is an overkill in the bush. These excessive rules and massive costs will overburden the clubs and could plunge this successful club into financial ruin. I believe that all agencies must sit down every year and thrash out workable and realistic solutions to prevent the demise of these rural events. The same rules that apply in Brisbane do not fit with country racing. It is a totally different environment. It is paramount that the minister for racing venture out and have a look at the uniqueness of the bush and the difference between it and the city.

Queensland Racing needs an overhaul. It does not recognise or understand the importance of country race days to small communities. It has prioritised TAB meetings at the expense of non-TAB meetings. Queensland Racing needs to be held accountable for its decisions. Country clubs are continually being kicked in the guts by the hierarchy of Queensland Racing. Rural communities need to be allowed to stage special race events, which were time-honoured traditions for many years before Queensland Racing took control.

Country racing and rodeos are the lifeblood of these rural communities. The government needs to protect their survival for future generations and not be responsible for their decline and ruination. The focus should be on fixing the issues and not being intent on working against the hardworking efforts of the race committees in these rural communities.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (5.55 pm): Netball is Australia’s most popular women’s team sport. For many Australian girls and women of all ages, it is their first sport of choice. This is no different in the Greenslopes electorate, with the Metropolitan Districts Netball Association, based at Wembly Park at Coorparoo, giving southsiders the opportunity to play and participate in this fantastic sport for more than 35 years.

On Sunday, 28 March 2010, I was delighted to be able to officially open the association’s annual representative carnival. The 2010 carnival gave the opportunity for players from 135 teams from 34 associations, as well as their friends, family members, supporters and spectators from the Sunshine Coast, Caboolture, Pine Rivers, Redlands, Ipswich and northern New South Wales and all points in between, to participate in, or otherwise be part of, a wonderful day of competition. More than 1,500 people participated in or attended the annual carnival.

The carnival competition included 12 years teams all the way through to 17 years teams and some senior teams. I am pleased to report that the Metropolitan 14 years team went through the tournament undefeated. I want to pay tribute this evening to the hardworking members of the association’s executive, particularly the association’s president, Trish Jachimowicz, for their efforts in making the carnival such a success. Each week people such as Trish, vice-president Geoff Moloney, treasurer Christine Gould and others such as coaching and development convenor Sue Maidment and volunteers such as Mal and Kay Kelly, who sit on the desk at Wembley Park each and every Saturday, give the opportunity for literally hundreds of girls and young women to experience fun, excitement and team sport at its very best. Mal and Kay Kelly’s daughter played for Metropolitan and now their granddaughter enjoys the fun of netball. I want to thank them for their volunteer work for the club.

I also wish to recognise the wonderful work of other volunteers, such as umpire Hayden Lenz, and coaches Jamie O’Connor, Camille Dowling and Amanda Stag, among others. They represent the hundreds of mums and dads, family members, friends and helpers who make volunteer sport happen in the Greenslopes electorate and in other parts of Brisbane’s southern suburbs each week.

It was also wonderful to see one of Australia’s all-time netballing greats, Vicki Wilson, who coaches the association’s 15 years team, urging her players on in one game that I watched. I know that Vicki has at times described herself as a ‘Metro girl through and through’ and to see her giving back to the sport at a grassroots level was remarkable.

The Metropolitan Districts Netball Association is a community focused sporting club. It strives to do whatever it can to be a good neighbour to local residents and fully supports the community use of the club’s grounds. I thank the association for letting me be part of an important day in their annual sporting calendar. I look forward to doing what I can to support them as their local state member of parliament.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (5.58 pm): I rise to speak about an issue that is of increasing concern across Queensland and one which affects a number of people in the Aspley electorate and that is the closure of caravan parks and its impact on long-term residents who reside in them. Although the Aspley electorate is primarily represented by stand-alone residential housing, town houses and villas, around 800 residents live in caravans or manufactured homes within the three caravan parks located in the suburbs of Aspley and Carseldine. It is expected that two of the three caravan parks, Aspley Acres and the Alpha Accommodation Centre, will be closed in the next few years as preliminary approval has been granted by the Brisbane City Council for 780 units to be built on the two adjoining sites. Although within the unit complex there will be around 120 affordable housing units, the reality is that the majority of residents in those two caravan parks will not transition into this new development.

Caravan parks play a vital role in Queensland’s housing stock and have provided a safety net of low-cost housing in Queensland for the financially and emotionally vulnerable. Indeed, half of caravan park residents earn below $500 per week as compared to 21 per cent of households across the state, and 20 per cent of caravan park residents earn less than $250 per week as compared to 8 per cent state-wide. I can advise the House that the residents in both Alpha and Aspley Acres certainly fall into those categories.

But the reality is that park owners, having had to contend with escalating costs associated with public liability, utilities and massive land tax bills, have either sold out to developers or have opted to develop the land themselves. As a result, over 40 parks across the state have had to close. Members would have heard about the Alpha Accommodation Centre at various times in the House and rarely in glowing terms. It could be described as hotpot of dysfunction and disadvantage and very often violent. However, it has provided accommodation for individuals who have been institutionalised or who suffer from mental illness or alcohol or substance abuse. Many of the residents have been listed with TIKA or have been banned from charitable shelters for behavioural issues. It has filled a void in the housing sector that has not been able to be met otherwise.

It is important that we understand that there are also residents of manufactured homes who are long-term residents of the caravan parks. These are good, honest community members who simply made a lifestyle choice to reside in a park community. They have worked hard to purchase their manufactured homes, but are now finding that options for long-term leases in metro caravan parks almost impossible to secure. Indeed, once these parks are shut in my electorate, the closest parks to relocate to are in Esk and Gympie.

The closure of Aspley Acres and Alpha Accommodation must be viewed in the context of the significant loss of housing options on the north side of Brisbane. I call upon the Minister for Communities to ensure departmental readiness for the closure of these parks as it is estimated that up to 600 people could be seeking high-priority social housing assistance, which I am advised by the department will be the largest relocation ever undertaken.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (6.01 pm): I am sure members will join me tonight in acknowledging the enormous contribution of Ray Goodey and his wife Frances to the Beenleigh and Logan community. Ray Goodey is a newspaper man through and through. In 1962 at the tender age of 17 years Ray started in the newspaper industry working for a daily newspaper in New Zealand. Ray’s distinguished career in the newspaper industry has seen him work in New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Chermside and, for the last 21 years, in Logan and Beenleigh. Ray’s career has outlasted many of the changes in this fast-changing industry including the loss of hot lead, the computerisation of printing, computerisation of journalism and the introduction of online news.

Ray has been an integral part of the Quest Community Newspapers group, in particular in Logan, for the last 21 years but is best known to me and others as the editor of the Albert and Logan News for the last 12 years. Ray is renowned for his love of the job and the newspaper game. Most people thought that he would never retire, or at least that Frances would have to physically remove Ray from the office of the Albert and Logan News .

Ray’s commitment to his wife Frances and his four daughters is well known. That is why Ray, at the young age of 65, is retiring as editor of the Albert and Logan News . Ray has been battling his own personal health issues in the last 12 months. At the launch of the Beenleigh Cane Festival this year, Ray was telling me just how torn he was between his love of the newspaper game and his work and his desire to spend some quality time with his family while he battles cancer. As well as his colleagues at the Albert and Logan News , Ray will be missed by the Logan and Beenleigh community. Ray saw his responsibility as going beyond simply writing the news to being a community leader. Ray has, for many years, been a judge for the Beenleigh Cane Quest, the key event on the Beenleigh calendar. Ray has been a judge for many years, seeing many Beenleigh young people grow and mature through the Cane Quest.Ray has also been seen as an honest broker within our community, chairing many local mayoral debates in Logan--many heated debates at that. Ray’s contribution to the business community has also been recognised with life membership of the Logan Chamber of Commerce.

As we here know all too well, politicians need newspapers more than newspapers need us. Ray had a great understanding of what the people of Logan and Beenleigh wanted to know. Ray never gave credence to political point scoring, but was always prepared to put the local into local news. I know every member of this House, both past and present, who know Ray and Frances will join with me in wishing Ray well in his battle with cancer and wishing them well in his retirement. While the Albert and Logan News will continue to be a strong voice in our community, he will be sorely missed by us but warmly welcomed by his family.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (6.04 pm): I rise to speak in support of all the members in our communities who have been touched by a most disturbing statistic released two weeks ago on 31 March 2010. Data, compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, reveals that across Australia 2,191 people took their own lives in 2008 and the ABS has revised upwards by 173 the number of suicides in 2007, bringing that total to 2,054. For 2008, 37 per cent of coroners’ cases have not yet been concluded, meaning the suicide rate could rise even further, with experts believing the final 2008 figure could reach 2,500.

These statistics are an inexplicable waste of life, the catalysts for which are many and varied, including breakdown of relationships, financial and employment pressure, drug and alcohol dependency, depression and other mental illness. The figure of 932 suicides registered for men aged 44 or younger was more than double the 450 road fatalities in that same age group for the same period but received much less attention. There has regularly been much media coverage and systematic action in attempting to stem the road toll. Rightly so, across Queensland, and indeed right across Australia, we see an almost never ending tsunami of initiatives to lower the road toll, whether they be education, legislative or law enforcement. Just imagine, however, if that road toll figure I mentioned of 450 suddenly became the other figure of 932. There would be, justifiably so, an outcry from all sections of society. Yet unless one has a vested interest, for example as a clinician or a person touched by suicide who are in themselves victims, discussion generally about the incidence of suicide is almost inaudible.

Every year there are tens of thousands of people who are unexpectedly taken from their loved ones in the most tragic of circumstances. Others, whilst not unexpected, tragically die from illness. These deaths are mostly unavoidable. I do not pretend to have an answer to the problem of suicide but we as members of the community and members of this parliament need to constantly remind ourselves of the need to be vigilant in offering all available resources to clinicians, community groups, schools and families in trying to combat the incidence of suicide. I wish for a time when all the efforts and initiatives come into alignment and the incidence of suicides has been greatly reduced in this state. I call upon this parliament to do whatever it can as a united group to help people in this situation. Those statistics are real. Double the number of people killed in car accidents are killing themselves. I think we need to pull together on this one and do whatever we can do to help.

Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (6.06 pm): There are many ways for the unemployed to gain skills, confidence and experience that will lead to employment. Apart from the many training opportunities such as those offered under the Skilling Queenslanders for Work program, there are individual social enterprises that have a positive community benefit far beyond the primary focus. Established in 2008, the Social Enterprise Hub in Logan City, with coordinator Andrew Hamilton, has assisted in setting up a number of social enterprises which are showing great promise. Tasty Fresh Community Catering was established at the Logan Women’s Health and Wellbeing Centre. With a very well-established network of organisations and a commercial kitchen, the catering service was a natural option. Team leader Elizabeth Loughlin has a great background and vast experience in food preparation as well as her considerable leadership and people skills. This business is giving employment opportunities to the women of Logan and spreading the message of healthy food choices. The hub offers support in many areas such as training workshops, developing a business plan, matching with a business mentor, market research and assisting with training of a new employee.

The Rock Indoor Climbing and Adventure Specialists operate out of The Spot at Browns Plains and offers adventure based activities from indoor climbing to overnight camps, particularly for marginalised young people. The activities provide mental, social, emotional and physical benefits to the participants. Blueprint Distribution Centre offers employment and training and intends establishing a distribution centre providing safety equipment and clothing to community based workplace and training programs. CityCare Technology employs people in its program to recycle computers which, of course, has great environmental benefits. It refurbishes the system and sells second-hand computers, as well as giving IT advice and repairs at discount prices to those on low incomes. It also supplies computers and parts to the overseas market.

MultiLink Community Services, which runs programs for people from culturally diverse backgrounds, has established interpreting services and is at present building up its clientele. The latest social enterprise is one which I spoke of in this place recently, the Style It Up Hairdressing and Beauty Salon at Career Keys which will give juniors experience in a real-life salon thus ensuring they are work ready and able to step straight into the workplace.

These examples of local, targeted small enterprises show that a local community is able to offer sufficient support throughout local networks to be able to sustain jobs and grow a small business. I would like to commend Andrew and his team and those who are guiding these enterprises through their establishment phase. The aim of these enterprises is to develop them so they are self-sustaining and are able to offer employment to local people, particularly those who have found it difficult in the past to gain employment.

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (6.09 pm): It appears that the transport minister is relying on frustrated Gold Coast commuters abandoning the ‘Bombay Express’ as the solution to overcrowding on Gold Coast trains. The latest TransLink Tracker data confirms that Gold Coast commuters are giving up in frustration. The Gold Coast rail line, or the ‘Bombay Express’, could have lost as much as, indeed more than, 20 per cent of commuters since March 2009 when comparing the latest figures available. But even on these reduced numbers, Gold Coast trains are still the most overcrowded trains on the TransLink network during peak times.

The latest TransLink Tracker was released by the minister just before Easter. It shows that, although there was no increase in train services to the Gold Coast during the period, the number of overcrowded trains in morning peak hours has dropped from six out of seven in the March 2009 survey to just four out of seven in December. On afternoon peak services, overcrowding has dropped from five out of eight in March 2009 to four out of eight in December.

The minister could point to a few other possible explanations for the reduced commuter traffic. An increase in unemployment of Gold Coast commuters is one possibility, but that is not something this government would want to suggest. It would mean unemployment had increased by up to 20 per cent on the Gold Coast, and clearly that is not the case. The reduction in overcrowding during a period when an estimated 8,500 new residents have moved in to the Coomera area in the past nine months can only be put down to one thing. The real answer is that commuters are walking away from Gold Coast trains because they are sick and tired of standing for over an hour every day just to get to work and then experiencing more of the same in the afternoon. Standing for two hours every day to get to work and back is just not on. Is it any wonder locals call it the ‘Bombay Express’?

Commuters deserting the train is bad news for traffic congestion on the M1, too. We see entry onto the M1 heading north becoming gridlocked every morning and it is repeated in reverse every afternoon. It is all-round bad news for everyone living on the northern end of the Gold Coast when it comes to getting to work in Brisbane. The choice is between standing up for two hours every day or fighting to get on to the M1 and then heavy traffic all the way to Brisbane and back.

We have got the Coomera Town Centre planning proceeding on schedule, but there is no plan from this minister or this government to fix the already overcrowded trains. What I fear is that this could become a deal breaker for the developers. What is the point in developing the Coomera Town Centre as a transport hub around the Coomera Train Station and encouraging the use of public transport if there is no plan to fix the already overcrowded trains?

The transport minister admitted to me that Gold Coast trains are the most overcrowded in the TransLink network, but she said that she does not have any answers to the overcrowding problem. I call on the minister to get serious about this--get a plan together and show the people of the northern Gold Coast that she does not consider them second-class citizens.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (6.12 pm): In early May the focus of national tennis will again be on Brisbane as we host a Davis Cup tie for the first time in a decade. The last Davis Cup tie in Brisbane was in 2000, when we played Brazil and won the tie 5-0 in what was the semifinal round. Unfortunately, we went on to lose to Spain that year. In 2000 Australia’s Davis Cup team was spearheaded by Patrick Rafter and Lleyton Hewitt. This year I am certainly hoping that Lleyton will be out on centre court at the Pat Rafter Arena again representing Australia.

When this government announced that we would build a State Tennis Centre in Tennyson, our vision included Brisbane again being able to host Davis Cup ties and ensure that the people of Brisbane can enjoy the best of Australia’s tennis talent. Hosting a Davis Cup tie is about delivering on the vision for tennis in Brisbane but also about building the inspiration for local children to play tennis and go on to represent their country on their home court in Tennyson.

This Davis Cup tie comes about as a result of a partnership between the state government and Brisbane City Council, through Queensland Events and Brisbane Marketing, putting together a bid with Tennis Australia to secure the event. One of the challenges of hosting the event comes with the playing groups preferring a clay playing surface. Whilst there are clay outer courts at Tennyson, centre court has a hardcourt surface. In order to host this event, centre court Tennyson will be transformed into a clay surface, with a world standard clay court built on top of the existing centre court. This bumping in of an alternative surface demonstrates the flexibility of the venue and the initial planning of the centre to enable the stadium to be used for a range of tennis demands.

World-class tennis at Tennyson has so far been showcased at the annual Brisbane International for the last two years. These events are known for their accessibility, with outer court ticket prices starting at $9.90. The Davis Cup tie continues this accessibility, acknowledging of course that there are no outer court matches. A Davis Cup tie consists of two singles matches on day 1, doubles on day 2 and reverse singles on day 3. Adult ticket prices for the days of singles games are under $40, with a series ticket for all three days costing less than $100.

Local residents also need to be assured that traffic movements will be managed for the event, with the three days--7 to 9 March--dedicated as event days. Yesterday I met with Queensland Events to be briefed on aspects of the event and also sought information relating to traffic and parking. I am advised that ticketing will include public transport costs, that additional train services will stop at Yeerongpilly station and that event days will include local parking restrictions. Once a clearer indication of expected patronage is known, local residents will be written to. Local Quest papers will also include event information, and I have also requested that local Councillor Nicole Johnston be briefed on event management plans.

This Davis Cup tie will be a great tennis event for Brisbane. It will showcase our stadium and our local area, and many local people will have a great opportunity to see world-class tennis on their doorstep.

Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP) (6.18 pm): The Gateway Upgrade Project is a fantastic project running through my electorate that will provide great benefits to all of the residents of Chatsworth, indeed to all Queenslanders. I am very happy to announce that tomorrow I will see another step in the Gateway Upgrade Project being completed, with another length of road being upgraded to six lanes. I am very happy about that.

Any infrastructure project of this size is sure to cause some inconvenience to residents. Some residents who live along the roadworks have been inconvenienced over time and I would like to acknowledge them and thank them for their patience and understanding as this has gone on. However, there are a number of areas alongside the Gateway where I have sponsored petitions by residents who have asked the minister to look at increasing some of the noise barriers to assist them with reducing the noise impact from the upgraded Gateway. I am very happy to say that the minister has come out a number of times--and I thank him for that--and has met with the residents. We are having ongoing talks with Main Roads and the Gateway Upgrade Project team to try to fix that.

One of the issues that has been raised is the LA68 standard that we use. The LA68 standard is a measurement of noise over time. Whilst I understand it is an internationally recognised level, I have some concerns about measuring noise over a period of time. The fact is that it is measured over an 18-hour period in a day. Whilst that background noise has been reduced--particularly by the asphalt which has been laid and which has reduced the noise by three decibels--the residents are concerned about the fact that the noise is measured over time. Under the LA68 system, if I came into your room and rang a bell every 10 minutes for six hours, the noise averaged out over 18 hours would be perfectly fine, but we all know that we would be very tired.

The noise of a bell is obviously not happening, but what is happening along the Gateway Bridge is that there is significant noise from exhaust brakes from heavy vehicles throughout the night. The main issue that has been raised with me is what we can do to try to reduce that. I have spoken to the minister on behalf of the residents of the Chatsworth electorate and I have asked him to talk to the heavy vehicle industry and try to find some way to reduce the noises coming from the heavy vehicles which are using the Gateway Arterial so as to improve the quality of life for the residents of Chatsworth.
